body: The news about Sir Salimullah Medical College & Mitford Hospital running without any essential drugs, including life-saving ones, for the last two months once again reveals the disheartening status of the country's health- and medi-care services system. Lack of supply of about two hundred such medicines for more than eight weeks sends dreary signals to patients who depend on this hospital located in the old part of Dhaka city. And that patients undergoing surgery are left on their own to buy drugs which are vital from stores outside the hospital premises is another dreadful worry. This proves inefficiency of the medical administration in the country. The absence of essential drugs reportedly originates from financial mismanagement of the hospital authority, the health directorate of the government and Essential Drug Company Limited (EDCL), the firm that provides pharmaceutical products to the government-run hospitals. On the one hand, EDCL has held up their supply to Mitford Hospital which owed quite a large amount of money to the former; and on the other, cash sanctioned for this hospital by the financial wing of the health directorate is not sufficient to resume this supply immediately. The apparent lack of co-ordination and financing among these authorities are affecting the patients. This asymmetrical anomaly must not be allowed to continue. The health directorate should evaluate whether there is a need to raise budget allocations for the hospitals, the hospital concerned should be more cautious about handling drugs so that these don't find way illegally into the stores outside the hospital, and EDCL is expected to be more flexible about supplying medicine so that no patient aches in absence of a 'pathedrine'.

title: US military justice failed: Rape victims
body: Former US troops who were raped during their time in uniform recounted their traumatic experiences at a Senate hearing and demanded changes to the military's justice system. Four victims, three women and a man, told lawmakers Wednesday in poignant testimony how they had been sexually assaulted and harassed, that their attackers had escaped punishment and that they suffered retaliation and intimidation under a legal code that offered them little recourse. "The military criminal justice system is broken," Rebekah Havrilla, a former Army sergeant, told lawmakers. Havrilla said she was raped by a member of her unit at the end of her tour in Afghanistan in 2007, where she served as a bomb disposal specialist. Her rapist later posted photos of her online taken at the time of the assault, prompting her to report the crime to military authorities.

title: Action against 103 female students of RU likely
body: RAJSHAHI UNIVERSITY, Jan 7: The Proctor Office of Rajshahi University is preparing to take legal action against some 103 female students of 4 dormitories of the university for defying the sunset laws, Proctor and hall office sources said. The break up of the students are: Monnujan Hall 45, Toposy Rabeya Hall 30, Begum Khaleda Zia Hall 15 and Begum Rokeya Hall 8. The list of the girls has already forwarded to the Proctor. Dr Nasima Zaman, Provost of Monnujan Hall said despite repeated order, the girls come back to hall at 9 or 9:30 pm instead of stipulated time 6 in the evening.

title: Rickshawpuller stabbed to death in Patuakhali
body: A rickshaw-puller was stabbed to death, allegedly in a feud, at village Pukurjana of Itbaria union in Sadar upazila on Sunday night. Rickshaw-puller Khalilur Rahman, 50, was stabbed to death on Sunday night at the local bazaar at village Pukurjana when he got into an argument with fellow card players over the upcoming Upazila Parishad(UP) election. Local people said Khalilur had been working for a member candidate and they alleged followers of the other candidate killed him. However, police suspect that Khalilur's fellow players might have killed him following a feud over the card play. Election candidates and the supporters are panic stricken and a tense situation is prevailing at the union. No case had been filled till the writing of this report on January 12 night.

title: 51 anti-Indian bases in Bangladesh, says Tripura CM
body: Chief Minister of Tripura Manik Sarkar yesterday said his government has definite information that there were 51 bases of anti-India organisations in Bangladesh. "It's the ISI (Inter-Services Intelligence of Pakistan) and the CIA which are funding these terrorists for their survival in Bangladesh," said Sarkar at a 'Meet the Press' at the Kolkata Press Club yesterday. However, Sarkar did dot blame Dhaka for the 'anti-Indian bases conducting their operations in Bangladesh'. "They have their own problems to look after. The impetus should be from our side to try and find out a solution. But strangely that National Democratic government at the Centre plays a silent role," he said. When journalists asked him about the involvement of the CIA, Sarkar replied, "It was they who gave birth to the ISI. So, they should also be held responsible for all the activities that the ISI carries on today." The Tripura chief minister added that intelligence departments of his government had a detailed report as to where the 51 bases were in Bangladesh and the total amount of firepower and manpower they had. "We have given the entire report to the Central Government in Delhi. And our reports have matched the facts that they had gathered." Citing the growing dangers of terrorism as the main obstacle to Tripura's development, Sarkar said he had also asked the Central Government to take certain preventive measures. "But they have not done so," he said. "I had asked for fencing off the entire 156 kilometres that separate Tripura from Bangladesh. Along with that I had also asked the Central Government in Delhi to start discussions with the Bangladesh government regarding the dismantling of these camps in a joint operation. But they have not done so. "... Unless a joint effort is made by the Bangladesh and the Indian governments in tackling the ultras, development in Tripura will not take place. Mind you I am always talking about a joint operation." When asked whether his government was willing to start discussions with the Bangladesh government on this issue, he pointed out, "This is an international matter. We can be a part of the discussion if the Indian government wants us. But we cannot start it." The Tripura chief minister stated that he was optimistic about an immediate launch of the bus service between Agartala and Dhaka. "I am sure it will start by the middle of this year." Asked what he thinks about use of roads in Bangladesh for a transit to Tripura, Sarkar said, "We surely want that. Tripura is hemmed in by Bangladesh on three sides. But then you cannot only think of us. Bangladesh also has certain opinions regarding transit. Their opinions and proposals will also have to be considered. "But if transit does take place it will really be beneficial to us. We just cannot demand the rights for transit. We have to consider the merits and demerits. And above all, we have to see to it that the interest of Bangladesh is never hampered." He was also admitted that Awami League leaders like Joynal Hazari and Shamim Osman had taken refuge in Tripura immediately after the change of government in Dhaka. "They were in Tripura for sometime last year. But at present we have no idea about their whereabouts," he concluded.

title: BSF rescues 30 Bangladeshi enclave residents
body: India's Border Security Force (BSF) rescued 30 Bangladeshi agricultural labourers who were about to be washed away in a sudden rush of the Teesta river water at Lalmonirhat's Dahagram-Angarpota enclave Wednesday evening. They had gone to Quaderer Char under Dahagram, some 500 metres from Indian border, on Wednesday morning to harvest maize, but in the evening there was a sudden rush of water coming from the upstream and they did not have any boat to return to the mainland, said sources at Border Guard Bangladesh's (BGB) Dahagram camp. When the water was rising, BSF men from the nearby Chandni camp in Cooch Behar district of West Bengal watched the situation through binocular and rushed to the char with speedboats. The char later went under water. "If BSF didn't rescue us and give us shelter, we must have been washed away," said Hazrat Ali, 44, a rescued man living in Dahagram. "We will be grateful to BSF forever...If they didn't come we must have been dead; our families didn't get our bodies," added Noor Hossain, 42, of the same village. Labourer Zahurul Islam said they went to the char by a boat, which was supposed to come back and take them back home in the evening but the boatman could not sail in the strong currents. Mustafizur Rahman, executive engineer at Water Development Board's Dalia office, said the average depth of water was 30 metres in the morning, while in the evening the river flowed at 53 metres, the danger level being 52.4 metres. Islam Hossain, 46, of Angarpota village, said, "We got shelter in the BSF camp, had meal, and received good behaviour from BSF men." The BSF men returned them to their homes on Thursday morning. The people of the enclave, which falls in Cooch Behar, prayed after Juma congregations yesterday, thanking the BSF men.

title: Khaleda blames it on AL
body: Prime Minister Khaleda Zia yesterday blamed the recent US decision to include Bangladesh in the terror-risk list on "irresponsible activities and statements of a particular party". "The party and its leaders have launched an anti-Bangladesh propaganda since it lost the last general elections," she said at the fifth national council and 20th founding anniversary of the Jatiyatabadi Sramik Dal at the Paltan Maidan in the city. The propaganda apparently influenced Washington to impose immigration restrictions on Bangladeshis, the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) chairperson said. Khaleda also brushed aside Awami League President Sheikh Hasina's claim that the four-party alliance government was to blame for the US decision. "My government is not responsible at all. It was she and her party who had influenced the decision with anti-Bangladesh statements at home and abroad." She said the party portrayed Bangladesh as a communal state when in power to then US President Bill Clinton during his visit in March 2000. The party's propaganda had influenced Clinton's decision to cancel all scheduled programmes including a visit to the Savar National Mausoleum, Khaleda said. The US president spent the whole day in hotel, only attending a Bangabhaban programme, she added. Without naming the AL chief and senior Indian ministers, Khaleda said, "They used similar words in their statements against Bangladesh. They said the same things at the same time." "It is unfortunate that senior leaders of that country made such false and imaginary allegations against Bangladesh. This is nothing but a deep-rooted conspiracy against Bangladesh." The party's campaign and the subsequent US restrictions has thrown hundreds of thousands of Bangladeshi students and workers overseas into uncertainty and panic, the prime minister told the Sramik Dal leaders and activists. "Can the leader be called patriotic? They (AL) have put our independence, sovereignty and economy in jeopardy and are still trying to isolate the country from the world only to avenge their defeat in the elections." However, she said, such campaigns would not be successful, as Bangladesh "has a reputation of being a moderate and democratic country in the world". Khaleda said she firmly believed that the US "knows Bangladesh as a moderate country" and would drop the country from its terror-risk list and withdraw the immigration restrictions. Turning to the industrial sector, the prime minister said her government would close down all losing concerns and set up new ones to create employment for the laid-off workers. About closure of the Adamjee Jute Mills, she said the laid-off workers had been paid their dues and could start small-scale businesses of their own. Besides, the government has plans to convert the mill area into an export processing zone or an information technology (IT) village that would create thousands of jobs. BNP Secretary General Abdul Mannan Bhuiyan, State Minister for Labour and Manpower Lutfar Rahman Khan Azad also addressed the meeting, presided over by Sramik Dal President and Food Minister Abdullah Al Noman. International Labour Organisation (ILO) Director Gopal Bhattacharya, Sri Lankan Minister for Housing and Plantation and General Secretary of the Ceylone Workers Congress SAR Thondaman, President of the Nepal Trade Union Centre Laxman Basnet and Representative of IFCTU P Haridasan also spoke at the inaugural session.

title: OMS of rice, flour from Monday
body: Food Minister Abdur Razzaque yesterday said the open market sale (OMS) of rice and flour would be launched across the country on Monday. “Under the OMS programme, rice and flour will be sold among people at fair prices,” he said while talking to reporters at his ministry. The OMS programme had been running on limited scale, and now it would be launched on a massive scale, he told reporters after Mike Robson, country representative of FAO in Bangladesh, met him at the ministry. Each family can buy a maximum of five-kg of rice at Tk 24 per kg and the same amount of flour at Tk 20 per kg a day under the programme, the minister said. He hoped that the country's food production would increase in the coming days if the current favourable weather persists. “The government has taken up various steps for boosting food production. The rice production has already increased. "The government has also redoubled its efforts to achieve food autarky as it is giving priority to ensuring food security and nutrition,” he said. Referring to his meeting with the FAO representative, the minister said the FAO official lauded the government's initiatives taken up for ensuring food safety in the country.

title: Kallis, Cullinan shine
body: CAPE TOWN, Jan 4: Daryll Cullinan made a fighting century to keep South Africa on top on the third day of the fourth Test against England on Tuesday, despite a fiery performance by England fast bowler Chris Silverwood, reports AFP. Cullinan, whose 10th test century equalled the South African record held by opener Gary Kirsten, made 120 in a South African total of 421, a first innings lead of 163. Left-arm spinner Paul Adams bowled the only over England had to face before the close in their second innings and conceded a four to Mark Butcher, reducing the deficit to 159. Silverwood, 25, was England's hero, taking a career-best five for 91 in his fourth Test match. The Yorkshireman, who joined the tour as a replacement following an injury to Dean Headley, showed immense spirit as he kept charging in and bowling at high pace, despite stifling 34 degree heat. England seemed likely to have an uphill battle on a good batting pitch when South Africa resumed at 200 for one but they struck blows at crucial times as South Africa lost six further wickets for the addition of 107 runs. England skipper Nasser Hussain handled his bowlers skilfully, using them in short bursts to combat the heat. Cullinan kept his composure, however, and found a solid partner in wicketkeeper Mark Boucher, who made 36 in an eighth wicket stand of 90 in 126 minutes, which ensured South Africa would have a substantial lead. Cullinan batted for 351 minutes, faced 255 balls and hit ten fours and a six. Kirsten's run of form ended, however, when he was out to the first ball he faced Tuesday, edging Silverwood to wicketkeeper Alec Stewart without adding to his overnight 80, ending a second wicket stand of 158 with Jacques Kallis. Kallis, who also started the day on 80, went to his sixth Test century before being caught at first slip by Mike Atherton off Darren Gough for 105 in the first over with the second new ball. South African captain Hansie Cronje continued a run of poor form when he was caught by Michael Vaughan at gully off Caddick for nought. Selection convenor Rushdi Magiet said, however, he would assure Cronje that the selectors had full confidence in the man they have appointed until the end of the season. Recalled Jonty Rhodes was caught by Chris Adams at second slip off Silverwood for 16 and Lance Klusener was bowled by Gough for three, trying to force a straight ball to the offside. Shaun Pollock was also caught by Adams at second slip off Caddick for four before Boucher helped Cullinan extend South Africa's lead. England were without allrounder Andrew Flintoff, who suffered a fractured bone in his left foot while bowling Monday. It was announced Tuesday that Flintoff had been ruled out of the rest of the tour. It was also announced that six England players who are flying out to join the team for a triangular limited overs series after the Test series would arrive five days earlier than originally planned. The players, Mark Alleyne, Mark Ealham, Ashley Giles, Graeme Hick, Nick Knight and Vikram Solanki, will join the team on Friday and will be available for a three-day match against a South African invitation team starting Sunday, England's last first class match before the fifth and final Test starting at Centurion on January 14. The triangular series, starting on January 21, involves South Africa, England and Zimbabwe.

title: Double-decker vs. articulated buses
body: An interesting and thought-provoking article on double-decker buses was published in the pages of an English financial daily on 18th April. It deserves serious consideration and financial evaluation by BRTC authorities. The proposed interesting idea of having only all standing room passenger facilities on some buses running on the busy routes particularly during office time deserves a trial by BRTC. This facility can ease the peak hour rush to some extent and can be cost effective fuel wise. BRTC should carry out a realistic cost benefit analysis between normal and all-standing bus services. I firmly believe that the standing service buses will be viable even if passenger fares are reduced by 25 percent! Further, it will be interesting to compare the operating costs between normal sitting service double-decker buses and the articulated long buses introduced recently by BRTC. A total cost benefit analysis definitely has been done by BRTC, before going for the articulated buses from India. It will be appreciated if the dailies can look into it, and publish it for public interest, as no other considerations should come in analysis of this important cost-benefit projection on operating the two types of buses!

title: Discussion on prizebond held
body: A discussion on how to make the prizebond project more popular and attractive was held at the Bangladesh Bank conference room in the city on Wednesday. The Governor of Bangladesh Bank, Lutfar Rahman Sarker, presided over the meeting, says a press release. Speaking on the occasion the Governor sought opines of all present at the meeting to help make the project more popular. Deputy Governor Dr. Mohammed Sohrabuddin, Ataul Haq, senior officials of the bank, Managing Directors of commercial banks and officials of National Savings Bureau attended the meeting.

title: International Animation Cartoon Festival Bangladesh 2013
body: C.C.B in association with Ifad Eggy has organised a three-day International Animation Cartoon Festival Bangladesh 2013 beginning from today. This is the first ever such event in the country where seventeen countries including Bangladesh will play seventy animated cartoons for the children. The three-day event is being held at the Bangladesh Shishu Academy Auditorium and it will end on March 31.

title: Businessman kidnapped in Khulna
body: KHULNA, Jan 21: Armed miscreants kidnapped Sultan Bepari, a businessman of Khulna city at midnight on Thursday from Nirala Bazar under Kotwali thana. Police could not rescue him till filing of this report at 8 pm today. The incident took place when Sultan Bepari was returning home with Taka 18,600, said FIR recorded with Khulna thana. Police said the kidnapping is a sequel to previous enmity over financial matters.

title: 16,860 nomination papers of 6 southern districts valid
body: A total of 16,860 nomination papers have been found valid for 325 union parisad (UP) bodies of six southern districts in Barisal division for the ensuring polls. Official sources said, at least 536 nomination papers have been cancelled after scrutiny in these districts for various defects. Highest number of nomination papers have been submitted in Barisal district while highest number of nomination papers were cancelled in Bhola district. A total of 325 chairmen, 2,925 members and 975 women members under women reserved seats will be elected in these union parishads of this division in the next polls. The actual number of candidates will be known after the withdrawal of the candidatures on January 9 next. A total of 477 Chairman candidates, 2,753 member candidates and 805 women candidates are contesting in 81 unions of Barisal district. One hundred forty eight chairman candidates, 983 member candidates and 291 women candidates will contest in 31 unions of Jhalakathi district. In Bhola district some 288 chairman candidates, 1943 member candidates and 587 women will contest for 60 union parishad bodies. In Patuakhali district, 317 chairman candidates, 2,007 member candidates and 615 woman candidates have been contesting in 65 unions while 210 chairman candidates, 1,302 member candidates and 387 woman candidates in Barguna district for 38 union parishads this year. Besides, 279 chairman candidates, 1,731 member candidates and 484 woman candidates are contesting in 60 unions of Pirojpur district in the polls.

title: Death anniversary
body: Today is the first death anniversary of renowned photo journalist Shawkat Jamil Khan. Jamil suffered a massive stroke while he was on duty as a senior photo journalist of The Daily Star and breathed his last on this day in 2012. On the occasion, Jamil's wife Shahida Yesmin and other family members have arranged a Qurankhwani and a doa mahfil at his 10/B, Segunbagicha residence in the capital today. All well-wishers have been requested to pray for the salvation of the departed soul.

title: Heroin seller, 3 others arrested
body: Police arrested a heroin seller, Fazlu Mia, with 100 small packets of heroin yesterday from the city's Sramajibi Hospital area under Kotwali thana, police said. Fazlu Mia was arrested at around 1:45 pm while he was selling the drug. Later, based on his information, the police arrested his three associates - Hasem, Jewel and Kattri. Legal action has been taken against the accused persons.

title: Nipah kills boy, anthrax affects four people
body: Nipah virus claimed life of a boy in Magura while four people were infected with anthrax in Sirajganj on Sunday. A two-year-old boy was killed by nipah virus at Ghosgati village in Shalikha upazila of Satkhira on Sunday. The deceased was identified as Abdullah, son of Akram Ali of the village. He died at Jessore General Hospital in the morning, reports UNB. District Civil Surgeon Dr. Muhammad Shafiqul Alam said Abdullah fell sick after drinking date juice on Thursday. He was admitted to Magura hospital. As his condition deteriorated, he was shifted to Jessore General Hospital on the same day where he died on Sunday morning. The civil surgeon suspected that Abdullah might have been attacked by nipah virus after taking date juice. The boy's blood has been sent for laboratory test at Mohakhali in Dhaka city, said hospital sources. In Sirajganj, at least four people were infected with anthrax, a bacterial disease that spreads from cattle, in Baghabari Paschimpar village in Shahjadpur upazila on Sunday, reports our Pabna correspondent. Upazila health officials primarily identified the symptoms and said that the patients were being treated at the health complex. The infected patients are Sonai Pramanik, 22, Liton Hossain, 19, Rahima Khatun, 25, and Nayan Miah, 20, of Baghabari Pashchimpara village in the upazila. Residential Medical Officer at Shahjadpur upazila health complex Dr. Abdur Rahman said, two anthrax-infected came to upazila health complex on Sunday. After confirming their infection, a medical team visited the village on the same day and found two more infected with the virus. They are now undergoing treatment, he said. Dr. Rahman said that the patients contacted the disease while handling the meat of an infected cow at the village on February 27. He sores on the infected people show the symptoms of anthrax, he added. Sample of the cow meat has been sent to Dhaka for diagnosing, he said.

title: Army can’t be silent observer: Khaleda
body: BNP Chairperson Khaleda Zia addresses a rally at Matidali in Bogra on Sunday. Photo: Banglar Chokh Opposition leader Khaleda Zia said on Sunday that the army cannot play “a silent spectator” if peace remains absent in the country. Thanking the army personnel for not opening fire on people in Bogra “like what police did” on March 3, she expressed hope that Bangladesh Army would “play its due role in proper time” to maintain peace in the country. Khaleda was referring to deaths of nine people when Jamaat-Shibir men tricked locals with so-called sighting of Delawar Hossain Sayedee in the moon and clashed with law enforcers, attacked police stations, vandalised and torched different offices in the northern district. “The army is the part of Bangladesh and, therefore, has responsibilities towards the country. The army men cannot watch like silent spectators when people are being killed,” she said while addressing a wayside rally at Matidali intersection in Bogra Sadar Upazila. “The army will play its due role in proper time.” Addressing the first rally on her way to Joypurhat, the BNP chairperson also said army personnel go abroad for maintaining peace. But if there is no peace in their own country, foreigners would then say that the army is only capable of maintaining peace in other countries. “So, I ask all quarters to think about it.” Terming the Awami League-led government as “most autocratic, blood thirsty, killer and the most corrupt”, she threatened of crippling the whole country to force it to step down. The BNP would announce fresh agitation programmes on Monday to make its one-point topple government movement a success. The programmes will start from March 26, she added. Alleging that people of no community or religion are now safe as long as Awami League remains in power, Khaleda said: “The government is carrying out genocide one after another.” She urged people to wage resistance against what she termed government-sponsored killing and repression on the citizens of the country. Weapons, bullets, bombs will be of no use when people wage united movement, she warned the government. Asking people to join the movement “to save your sons, daughters and husbands”, the opposition leader threatened, “If necessary, we will paralyse the whole country.” The opposition led by the BNP would not act passive now, she said. “We will no longer shed tears from now. We will wage resistance and Bogra will be the door of the movement,” she told a cheering crowd of Bogra, a stronghold of the party. Khaleda also called upon people of all professions, including civil administration and police members, to engage themselves with the mass people. The opposition leader offered condolences and distributed cash among the families of seven victims who were shot dead on March 3 in Matidali. In Joypurhat, Khaleda said the government had stopped bus and launches during the opposition's ‘Dhaka Cholo’ programme. If necessary, come to Dhaka for one more time and return to homes after ousting the government from power, she made the call while addressing a mourning rally at Salaipur High School ground in Panchbibi upazila of Joypurhat in the afternoon. Joypurhat district unit of BNP organised the rally in memory of the death of four people during the recent violence across the country. The opposition leader said the prime minister must be accountable for all killings after coming to power. "Wherever you go, you will have to face trial," she warned the prime minister. BNP leaders including Mirza Fakhrul Islam Alamgir, Selima Rahman, Sadeque Hossain Khoka and Mirza Abbas accompanied her in the visit. On a two-day visit to Bogra and Joypurhat, the BNP chief reached Bogra Saturday night and spent the night at the local circuit house. They headed back for Bogra later and visit a Hindu temple in Gabtoli upazila that came under attack by religious bigots recently. Later, Khaleda addressed a rally at Aria Bazar School premises in Shahjahanpur upazila around 8:00pm. She demanded deployment of army to maintain law and order during the next parliamentary elections. The government should bring changes in the Representation of the People Order (RPO) in this regard, she said. "Without the deployment of the army the next general polls won't be free and fair," Khaleda said at the rally in the evening. After the rally, she started for Dhaka around 9:00pm. The former prime minister was scheduled to visit Bogra on Friday but postponed the tour until yesterday to mark the three-day mourning over the death of President Zillur Rahman.

title: Naga leaders set for peace talks in Delhi
body: Two exiled separatist leaders of a rebel group in the restive northeastern Indian state of Nagaland were due to hold peace talks in the Indian capital Thursday to end one of India's longest-running ethnic rebellions, officials said. Guerrilla leaders of the National Socialist Council of Nagaland (NSCN), Isak Chishi Swu and Thuingaleng Muivah, arrived in New Delhi overnight from Amsterdam. At least 200 Naga supporters, dressed in traditional headgear and wielding spears and machetes, welcomed the NSCN leaders at the Indira Gandhi International Airport in New Delhi singing "We shall overcome." "We have come here to meet the Indian leadership and the people of India for continuing the peace talks successfully," the 72-year-old NSCN chairman Swu told journalists on his arrival. The NSCN, fighting for an independent homeland for the Naga tribes, has been holding peace talks with the government since a ceasefire was struck in 1997. But it is the first time in 37 years that the NSCN will hold peace talks on Indian soil. Talks between the NSCN and the government emissary have previously been held in several Asian cities with Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee meeting the rebel leadership in 2001 in the Japanese city of Osaka. On Thursday, the two NSCN leaders were due to visit Rajghat, a memorial to Mahatma Gandhi, the leading figure in India's freedom struggle. Later in the day they will hold talks with New Delhi's chief peace negotiator, K. Padmanabhaiah. In the evening, Swu and Muivah are expected to meet Vajpayee.

title: Garments workers to gherao BGMEA
body: Eight garments workers' union will gherao the BGMEA office tomorrow Eight garments workers' unions will gherao the BGMEA office tomorrow to realise their five-point demand, reports UNB. A press release signed by Bangladesh Textile Workers League (BTWL) president ZM Kamrul Anam yesterday also stated that the unions have expressed solidarity with SKOP called today's work-stoppage programme. The unions include BTWL, Combined Tailor-workers Federation, Garments Workers League, Garments Workers & Employees Federation and Garments Workers Federation. BSS adds: Bangladesh Garments Sramik Kalyan Samity (BGSKS) said the garments workers will not observe today's strike, 'for the sake of the country's economy as well as their livelihood.' The strike has been called at a moment when the foreign entrepreneurs are coming up with their investments, being encouraged by the government's policy, a BGSKS press release said. This strike will only serve the interest of some political and worker leaders, it said.

title: Forced labor and Syedpur Airport construction
body: Syedpur Airport and runway constructed by Bengalis who were forced to provide labor in 1971. Photo: Lt. Col. (Retd.) Quazi Sajjad Ali Zahir, Bir Protik Forced labor is any compulsory labor service particularly those demanded by a dominant military force on prisoners of war, detainees or conquered civilian population. In 1971, after Pakistan Army moved in force in Syedpur and surrounding villages, they were given reception and congratulated by the non-Bengali population for capturing Syedpur and for conducting massacre on Bengali population. Pakistan Army and their collaborators who were mainly non-Bengalis in Syedpur used fear and threat on the Bengali population. The Bengalis were interned in the town area of Syedpur. Pakistan Army undertook a project in Syedpur in which they planned to use the Bengali population of Syedpur town and nearby villages as forced laborers. They planned to construct a large airport in Syedpur. There was an existing airport in Lalmonirhat and another abandoned airport in Thakurgaon. They considered Syedpur to be a safe place to construct an airport as the non Bengali population of Syedpur was totally in their support. They planned to construct a large runway so that large air crafts with troops and arms could land in Syedpur for supporting the operations of Pakistan Army in north Bangladesh. Their decision was also influenced by the fact that the ferry route across Jamuna River was insecure as Mukti Bahini guerillas were frequently conducting operations and causing casualties in the river. 23 Infantry Brigade of Pakistan Army was given responsibility to construct the airport. Army decided to construct the airport by using Bengalis as forced laborers. They brought about three thousand people from Syedpur town, Hazarihat, Motlabari, Kamarpur, Laxmanpur, Kashirampur, Shonara and other places of North Bengal. They examined the three thousand persons and out of them selected eight hundred younger and stronger people and interned them by force into three educational institutions namely Syedpur High School, Syedpur Darul Wulum Madrassa and Syedpur Technical School. The detainees were threatened that they would have to work in the Syedpur airport and anyone who tried to escape would face death. Every morning at 8 o'clock about 35-40 trucks used to line up in front of the three concentration camps. The trucks were of military and civilian models. With every truck they used armed soldiers and non-Bengalis to guard the laborers. The detainees used to be ordered to mount the trucks. If anyone delayed in mounting the truck, they used to be kicked and whipped. This was a common scenario every morning. The trucks used to drive the people to the airport area. After disembarking, the detainees had to dig the earth, break the stones, carry the earth and the stones and construct the airport runway. Through out the day they had to work in extreme heat. In return at mid-day they used to be given a hard bread and water. The bread was so hard that it could not be chewed. The detainees used to dip the bread in water and eat it. Under such brutal condition many detainees used to fall sick or even faint. If anyone fell down, he used to be beaten by whips mainly carried by the non-Bengalis. The non-Bengalis used to discuss and point at the sick workers and say that it was no point keeping them there and their name was to be put in the Kharcha Khata (Note book of expandable) indicating that they would be killed. Many of the sick were carried away and they never returned. If any detainees argued or tried to run away he used to be carried by truck to Syedpur cantonment never to return. Out of fear the people kept working inspite of their sickness and tiredness. Escaping from the airport site or from the living quarter was impossible as both the places were guarded by soldiers with weapons. Among the non-Bengalis who tortured the interns' maximum were Jahan, Ejahar, Matin, Hashmi, Qaiyum, Sultan Khan, Mojahar, Ismail, Mohiuddin, Kalua Dhopi, Swampad, etc. Some of the detainees who survived later are Moinul, Enamul, Mahbub, Shahidul, Ziaul Huq, Wadud, Kashem Ali Mollick, Kasoruddin, Abdus Sattar, Abdur Rashid, Mizanul Huq, etc. Pakistani officers who were in charge of the airport project were Major Javed, Captain Gul, Subeder Fateh Khan. Capt. Gul used to be seen with a revolver in his hand threatening to kill the detainees. Subder Fateh Khan used to beat the detainees with whip even if they fell sick or became unconscious. Some of the detainees who were killed in the airport area were Mansur Ali, Gomiruddin, Abdul Gafur, Abdus Samad, Sultan, Kalam, Hishabuddin, Rafiqullah, Bechu Miah, Abdul Motaleb, Rajob Ali, Afzal, Hatem Ali, Shahadat Hossain, Mofiz Uddin, Abdul Kalam, Jamir Uddin.. Rest of the names could not be obtained. It is known from local people that out of eight hundred detainees about 350 died while working in the airport. The work in Syedpur airport started in June, 1971 and continued till November, 1971. The runway was completed. After November, 1971, when the possibility of a major war was predicted by Pakistan Army, they stopped further work in the airport area. Pakistan Army named the airport “Zum Zum” after the name of the Holy water from the Holy well of Mekkah. But it is unfortunate to remember that so many innocent people in this airport had died begging for water. On 16 December, 1971, Pakistan Army surrendered to the joint forces of Indian Army and Mukti Bahini and the place of surrender was decided to be the Syedpur airport. 23 Brigade Commander Brigadier Iqbal Shafi and his officers and men stood in line in the runway preparing to surrender. Pakistan Army's 25 Punjab, 48 Punjab, 8 Punjab, 26 Frontier Force regiments and 83 Mujahid battalion were all lined up. Among them the 26 Frontier Force Regiment who was involved in supervision of forced labor in the same airport. The 26 Frontier Force Commanding Officer Lt. Col. Hakeem Arshad Qureshi in his book “The 1971 Indo-Pak War: A Soldier's Narrative” writes that they had to surrender in the airport which they (soldiers of 26 Frontier Force Regiment) built on self help basis. This was a statement far from truth. The airport was never built by 26 Frontier Force Regiment soldiers. 26 Frontier Force Regiment was mainly deployed in full strength in Dinajpur area during 1971. It was the interned Bengalis who constructed the airport as forced laborers. When the time for surrender came, Lt. Col. Hakeem Arshad Qureshi shouted 'Zamin Fung' (ground arms) and the surrender was complete. The officers and men of Pakistan Army collectively performed the shameful act in the airport where they had killed so many. They did not lay down their lives but only their arms in the line of duty. Hardly anyone of new generation of Bangladesh knows as to how Syedpur airport was constructed. The writer is a Freedom Fighter.

title: Last journey to Bangabhaban
body: A car carrying late president Zillur Rahman’s body crosses Karwan Bazar area as the veteran politician makes his final journey to Bangabhaban, the official residence of the president, Thursday. His body was flown back home from Singapore in the noon. Photo: Palash Khan. A little over four years ago, Bangabhaban was decorated to welcome him as the guardian of the nation. There was celebration, people from many walks of life stood up with smile to greet the honest, veteran politician. Now they are there again, this time to see him off as Zillur Rahman starts a journey from where no-one comes back. Draped in a national flag and put in a car decorated with flowers, the body of the late president reached Bangabhaban Thursday afternoon. Members from the armed forces offer guard of honour to late president Zillur Rahman after his body was taken to Bangabhaban. Thursday afternoon. Photo: TV grab. Hundreds of people lined up besides the Airport Road to pay tribute to Rahman as a motorcade carrying his body was being taken to Bangabhaban from the Shahjalal International Airport. The body of the eighty-four-year-old veteran politician arrived at the airport around the noon, a day after he breathed his last at Mount Elizabeth Hospital in Singapore. A special flight of Biman Bangladesh Airlines Ltd brought back the body. His coffin was brought down from the aircraft around 12:10pm. Ten generals of Bangladesh Armed Forces carried the coffin to a makeshift dais. Acting president and Speaker of the Parliamentary Abdul Hamid and Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina paid tribute to the president placing wreaths. Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina talks with dignitaries at the Darbar Hall of Bangabhaban. Photo: TV grab Family members of the president, cabinet members, ministers and lawmakers were also present there to pay homage to the president. Rahman’s first namaz-e-janaza will be held at Hazi Asmat College in Bhairab at 9:00am on Friday, said the President’s Press Secretary AKM Nesar Uddin Bhuiyan. The late president’s body will be flown by a helicopter on Friday morning. The president's body will be taken back to the Bangabhaban where the foreign diplomats are scheduled to pay homage to him at 12:30pm. The second janaza will be held at the South Plaza of the Jatiya Sangsad Bhaban at 3:30pm Friday. The body will be kept at the mortuary of Combined Military Hospital in Dhaka before being flown to Bhairab, according to sources of Prime Minister’s office. He will be laid to eternal rest besides his wife’s grave at the Banani graveyard around 5:00pm Friday. Rahman was admitted at Mount Elizabeth Hospital on March 10 as he was flown to Singapore by an air ambulance for critical lung infection a day after he was rushed to Combined Military Hospital in Dhaka. Leader of the Opposition Khaleda Zia signs the condolence book at Bangabhaban. Photo: TV grab. Rahman was admitted at Mount Elizabeth Hospital on March 10 as he was flown to Singapore by an air ambulance for critical lung infection a day after he was rushed to Combined Military Hospital in Dhaka.

title: BNP faces derision and rejection from AL, Left
body: The BNP-led opposition unity on a four-point charter of demands and threats of a street agitation to oust the Awami League government have met with derision from the ruling party and condemnation from the Left. The ruling party calls the unity "fragile", terming it a coalition between BNP and "autocratic and fundamentalist" parties. Government leaders find no substance in the opposition demands either. Besides, the Left parties are also critical of the opposition coalition calling it "a rightist and reactionary polarisation". These parties also view it as a "virtual alliance of power-hunters." The opposition unity suffered a setback on the very day it virtually began its journey as one of the partners -- Islami Oikya Jote - found itself divided on the issue. Furthermore, one of the opposition demands has also raised legal questions -using ID cards for voters in the forthcoming mayoral and municipal elections. Chief Election Commissioner Mohammad Abu Hena, in an interview with The Daily Star Wednesday night, said there was no law making ID cards mandatory for local polls. The CEC also called this demand "unrealistic" and "impractical", adding the voters' card project would not be complete before the local elections. In the backdrop of the new polarisation, the AL presidium is due to meet on January 12 to take stock of the latest situation. Nevertheless, the opposition parties are optimistic about their unity because, as one top BNP leader puts it, the people are very much with them. The BNP plans to expand the coalition by bringing the Left parties into the fold, but the JP is opposed to the idea, according to sources in the two parties. A top AL leader, Suranjit Sengupta, says three of the opposition demands are matters to be taken care of by the Election Commission while he finds no basis for the fourth -- the alleged repression on the opposition activists. On rest of the fourth demand -- release of all political detainees and withdrawal of "false" cases against the opposition leaders and workers, he said, ''It's purely a matter of the judiciary. Any government intervention is undesirable." Sengupta also describes the BNP-JP unity as "a natural alliance of the parties overthrown by the people". On Jamaat-e-Islami, another partner, he says "the anti-Liberation party" has been allied with the BNP for long. BNP secretary general Abdul Mannan Bhuiyan suggests a solution to the voters' ID card issue on a priority basis. "The EC can distribute such cards among the voters of four metropolitan cities and then to the municipal areas. But we want it mandatory for all local government polls." Asked to justify their demand for CEC's exit, Bhuiyan claims the major political parties have lost confidence in him. "He must go for the sake of fair polls." About political cases, the BNP leader keeps blaming the government for not "honouring" its earlier agreements on the matter. "The number of arrested opposition workers now stands around 1500. We want their release immediately." BNP standing committee member Moudud Ahmed looks at the demand for voters' ID cards as a political issue, not a legal one. "We want it in 30 days, that's all. I'm not going to reply to what the CEC said. "What did the EC do in the past two-and-half-years? Did they lay eggs? What else did the EC do except holding some by-polls over the time?" Insisted, on the CEC's point, Moudud says, "We want the government to amend the law. It can be done in two minutes by promulgating an Ordinance. That ID card is not mandatory to use in the local government polls is a lame excuse by the CEC. It's not a matter of amending law but the government's intention." "As per law, every voter must have an ID card. But do they all have the cards? No matter if they use it in the local polls or general elections. The EC has failed to issue such cards to all voters in the last two-and-half-years. Why did they do? There's a political motive behind non-issuance of the cards." JP presidium member Kazi Zafar Ahmed warns the government must step down if it fails to meet the opposition demands within the stipulated time of 30 days. The deadline expires February 5. Zafar thinks it is not impossible for the government to withdraw "false" cases against the opposition leaders and workers if it is sincere about resolving the crisis. Meanwhile, leaders of different Left parties talked to the BSS yesterday on the BNP-JP-Jamaat-IOJ coalition and their demands. Mozaffar Hossain of NAP termed the opposition alliance "a rightist and reactionary polarisation" and suggested the "people should take care of these forces". Workers Party general secretary Rashed Khan Menon said, "This coalition will expedite the legitimisation of the razakars and the autocrats." JSD leader Hasanul Haq Inu commented the opposition unity would trigger "a new wave of politics of killings and conspiracy". On CEC's resignation, he said the change would not ensure free polls. "The election must be freed from black money and muscle power."

title: BNP-JP dispute over
body: After five days' hectic negotiation, the BNP-led opposition alliance yesterday resolved the dispute over composition of the All Party Action Council (APAC) as the Jatiya Party bowed down to three others parties. The structure of the APAC, finalised by the Liaison Committee on January 13, remained unchanged. As the dispute was resolved, secretaries general of the four parties also signed a circular on guidelines for formation of APACs at all levels. The circular will be sent to all district units of the parties today, with an advice for formation of APACs at all levels immediately, sources said. APACs will now be formed in all metropolises, district headquarters, municipalities, thanas, wards and unions with 'not more than 101 members' each. Each unit will have a convenor to be chosen from among local opposition leaders on consensus. The dispute had cropped up as a section of JP leadership including its Secretary General Naziur Rahman Manjur raised objection over the structure of the APAC. He had brought a number of amendments and proposed formation of a Central Steering Committee (CSC) to replace the Liaison Committee. But the proposal and the amendments were rejected by the BNP. Jamaat-e-Islami and Islami Oikya Jote supported the BNP stance, the sources said. The dispute was resolved at meetings of the secretaries general of BNP and Jatiya Party yesterday and the day before. BNP Chairperson Khaleda Zia and JP chief HM Ershad had also roles in it, sources said. On Monday night, Khaleda Zia sent BNP leader Major (Retd) Manjur Qader to Ershad with a message urging him to ask Naziur to accept without any delay the APAC structure finalised earlier by the Liaison Committee. Ershad called Naziur instantly and advised him to resolve the dispute "at any cost" by yesterday. Naziur then invited BNP Secretary General Abdul Mannan Bhuiyan and the party's representative in the Liaison Committee, M Shamsul Islam MP and Anwar Zahid, to his residence yesterday. During one and a half hour's talks from 3:30 pm, Naziur withdrew his proposals, and the meeting okayed the previous APAC structure. Mannan and Naziur then signed a circular on guidelines for formation of APACs at all levels. Secretaries general of Jamaat-e-Islami and Islami Oikkya Jote signed it later on the day. At the meeting, both the sides agreed that from now on, secretaries general of the four parties would attend Liaison Committee meetings regularly. After the meeting, BNP hurriedly called a meeting of the Liaison Committee at the official residence of Leader of the Opposition Khakleda Zia to inform the committee about the developments. The liaison body is expected to meet again in a day or two to discuss fresh agitation programmes to be announced from separate public meetings of the four parties in the city on January 23.

title: Shantibahini men assembling in temporary HQs at Dudukchhari
body: RANGAMATI, Jan 5: Members of Shantibahini, the armed wing of the Parbattya Chattagram Jana Sanghati Samity, have reportedly started assembling in their temporary headquarters at Dudukchhari in Khagrachhari district for surrendering arms and ammunition as per the CHT peace accord, reports BSS. Sources said the armed cadres of the PCJSS reportedly abandoned their hideouts in the hill district of Bandarban about a week ago, the sources said. Administrative and security officials stationed at Bandarban told BSS over telephone that necessary preparations have also been taken to deal with other terrorist groups, apparently active in the district in jeopardising normal life. Meanwhile, a total of 869 tribal refugees returned home today, the fifth day of the sixth phase of repatriation from Kathalchhari refugee camp in Tripura, official sources said.

title: 100 injured in B'baria clash
body: At least 100 people, including four policemen, were injured in a clash between residents of two villages under Brahmanbaria's Sarail upazila yesterday centring the alleged harassment of a girl of class X. Riot police from Brahmanbaria Police Lines, called in after local police failed to bring the situation under control, fired 160 shotgun rounds and 44 teargas shells to disperse the villagers and end the nearly three-hour-long clash around 1:00pm. Police arrested 12 people from the spot while the injured policemen were admitted to Sarail Upazila Health Complex. Of the injured, one Rafiqul Islam, who received bullet wounds, and 21 others were sent to Brahmanbaria Sadar Hospital while the remaining received first aid at the health complex and local clinics. Eyewitnesses and police said a youth of Uchliapara village had engaged in an altercation with another from Sayedtula village on Thursday night after the latter allegedly harassed the former's sister. The youths and their supporters engaged in clashes in and around the two villages from around 10:00am. Their relatives, armed with sharp weapons, followed suit, said the eyewitnesses.

title: India to ensure security
body: NEW DELHI, Jan 11: India Sunday pledged to protect Pakistani diplomats and cricketers from Hindu zealots who have threatened violence against them, reports AFP. "The diplomats are safe," Home Minister Lal Krishna Advani said after a Hindu militant group that has vowed to disrupt Pakistan's first cricket tour of India in 12 years threatened Islamabad's diplomats as well. Advani, considered a hawk among India's ruling Hindu nationalists, said persistent differences between New Delhi and Islamabad should not be allowed to extend to sports and culture. He voiced the hope that Pakistani cricketers would tour India as scheduled for January 21 despite Hindu militants' threats to stop them from playing for alleged support by Islamabad to Indian terrorists. "I hope they will come," Advani said. "I want them to come." "This (federal government) has taken appropriate action against vandalism," he said, adding: "We have tried to ensure full and fool-proof security to the players." On Sunday, newspapers reported that police had found Hindu militant pamphlets near the Pakistan embassy here warning diplomats would be harmed if the Pakistani team arrived in India. A police officer said the two-page pamphlet was signed by the "acting president" of the New Delhi chapter of the Hindu militant Shiv Sena Party which rules Bombay. Security was immediately beefed up at the embassy, police said. Joint commissioner of police US Dadwal said: "Appropriate measures have been taken for the security of the diplomats. We are trying to track down the people who have signed the pamphlets." Shiv Sena activists dug up the cricket pitch at the New Delhi's Ferozeshah Kotla Stadium, venue of the first Test, last week, in a bid to prevent the match. Eight Shiv Sena supporters were arrested overnight, newspapers said. Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee on Saturday blamed "a handful of people" in India and Pakistan of trying to sabotage efforts to normalise relations between the two countries. The Pakistani team, which last played a Test in India in March 1987, is to arrive here January 21 for a two-Test series, the Asian Test Championship opener against India and a triangular one-day series also featuring Sri Lanka. In 1991, Hindu fanatics vandalised the pitch at Bombay's stadium days before Pakistan were to start a limited-over series in India. Pakistan cancelled that tour, and two more in 1993 and 1994, because of security fears. They played in India during the 1996 World Cup and the Independence Cup the following year without any problems. The police, meanwhile, urged newspapers in the Indian capital to report to them any information which could help prevent sabotage by Hindu militants. The militants have in the past tipped off photographers before staging violent attacks. The Shiv Sena says India should not have sporting links with Pakistan as long as Islamabad supports Muslim separatists in Kashmir and insurgent groups elsewhere in the country.

title: Hugo Chavez: Symbol of Latin American socialism
body: Hugo Chavez, the symbol of Latin American socialism, passed away after a long battle against cancer. Vice President Nicolas Maduro announced in a televised address: "We have just received the most tragic and wakeful information." As soon as the news was announced, supporters gathered at the city's main square, Plaza Bolivar, and began chanting "Chavez lives, the battle continues." People wearing the red beret sang a popular folk song with the words, "Those who die for life cannot be called dead." Chavez was given a state funeral in Caracas on March 8, attended by millions of supporters and left-wing leaders from across the globe who have been inspired by Chavez's doctrine of Bolivarian 21st century socialism. His death will also trigger a presidential election to be held within thirty days. His designated successor, Maduro, is likely to face Henrique Capriles, the losing opposition candidate in the presidential election that took place in October 2012. Until then, according to the constitution, the interim president should be the head of the national assembly. World leaders from various parts have sent massages of condolence. US President Barak Obama said: "At this challenging time of president Hugo Chavez's passing the United States reaffirms its interest in developing a constructive relationship with the Venezuelan government. As Venezuela begins a new chapter in its history, the US remains committed to policies that promote democratic principles, the rule of law and respect for human rights." Robert Menendez, chairman of the US Senate Foreign Relations Committee, called for free and fair elections to replace Chavez. "Hugo Chavez ruled Venezuela with an iron hand and his passing has left a political void that we hope will be filled peacefully and through a constitutional and democratic process, grounded in the Venezuelan constitution and adhering to the Inter-American Democratic Charter." In June 2011, Chavez revealed that Cuban surgeons had removed a baseball-sized tumour from his pelvic region. After that he underwent several rounds of chemotherapy and two more operations in what he described as a "battle for health and of life." Before the presidential elections in October 2012, aides claimed that he was well enough to complete a full term. Since his operation in December Chavez has been visited by family members and several of his closest political allies, including Fidel and Raul Castro of Cuba, Ecuadorian President Rafael Correa and Bolivian President Evo Morales. He returned from Cuba on February 18 at his own request. Since then, he had been treated at Carlos Arvelo military hospital in Caracas. Hopes for recovery dimmed on March 4 when minister of Communications, Ernesto Villegess said that the president's condition had declined due to a new and serious respiratory infection. In 2002, he survived a short-lived coup which began after a large anti-Chavez street protest ended in deadly shootings. Dissident military officers detained the president and announced that he had resigned. But, within two days he returned to power with the help of military loyalists while his supporters rallied in the streets. Chavez emerged a stronger president. He defeated a subsequent opposition-led strike that paralysed the country's oil industry, and he fired thousands of state oil company employees. Chavez used his country's vast oil wealth to launch social programmes that include state-run food markets, new public housing, free health clinics and education programmes. Poverty declined during Chavez's presidency amid a historic boom in oil earnings . He travelled around Argentina, Uruguay, Chile, Columbia and finally Cuba for the support of his movement. Fidel Castro met him and after several days they became friends. Returning to Venezuela he failed to gain mainstream media attention for his political cause. A debate soon developed in the Bolivarian movement as to whether it should try to take power in elections or whether it should instead continue to believe that military action was the only effective way of bringing about political change. Whilst remaining fiscally conservative he introduced measures in an attempt to alleviate the poverty of the Venezuelan working class. He immediately set into motion a social welfare programme called 'Plan Bolivia 2000' which he organised to begin on February 27, 1999. Plan Bolivia 2000 involved 70,000 army officers going out onto the streets of Venezuela where they would repair roads and hospitals, offer free medical care and vaccinations and sell food at cheap prices. At the start of the 21st century Venezuelan was the world's 5th largest exporter of crude oil with oil accounting for 85.3% of the country's exports. The previous government wanted to privatize this industry with US cooperation but he curbed foreign control by nationalising much of it under the state-run oil company and started spending the money mostly for public welfare purpose. On September 26, 2009 he, along with Argentina, Brazil and Bolivia, set up a regional bank. He was the most outspoken leader and often humorous critic of the US, the war in Iraq and George Bush, whom he described as a "donkey" and a "devil." Chavez kept his nation flush with oil in exchange for its well-trained doctors and teachers. He said: "Since I haven't failed you in the fourteen years I promise I won't fail you in the next presidential term. Because Chavez doesn't lie. Because Chavez doesn't sell out. Because Chavez is the people. Because Chavez is truth. Because all of you are Chavez. We all are." Really so; after his death hundreds and thousands of his followers cried "We are Chavez." We salute Chavez from Bangladesh. Jorge Cashenada, former Mexican foreign minister and NBC's Latin American policy analyst said: "Chavez will be remembered as someone who generated over fourteen years an international presence and impact beyond his own talent and personal charisma."
