title: Trade deficit narrows on sluggish imports and strong remittance flow
body: The trade deficit has contracted 29 percent year-on-year on the back of falling imports and rising remittance between July and January. At the end of the seventh month of fiscal 2012-13, trade deficit stood at $4.34 billion, down from the $6.14 billion recorded in the same period a year ago. Central bank officials said the reasons behind the narrowing trade deficit were the rise in exports and the drop in imports. Imports fell 3.34 percent and exports rose 8.28 percent in that period, according to Bangladesh Bank data on balance of payments. A dull investment scenario and low demand for petroleum during the period account for the decline in imports, added the officials. Import of food grains fell 40.33 percent, capital machinery 21.59 percent, industrial raw materials 6.26 percent and petroleum 3.33 percent, as per BB's letter of credit settlement statistics. Inward remittances rose around 20 percent and net foreign direct investment accelerated more than 12 percent to $785 million during the period. Consequently, the overall BoP saw a record surplus of $2.93 billion, which was $813 million in the deficit in the same period a year ago. As the BoP position improved so did the foreign currency reserves -- to a very healthy state. On February 12, the reserves stood at $13.38 billion and as per the import bill on December 12, it is sufficient to pay for 5.29 months' imports. The reserves stood at $13.80 million on March 19, according to data from BB. The growing reserves means the taka is appreciating by the day against the dollar. The dollar fetched Tk 78.57 on March 19, lower than Tk 81.79 on the same day a year ago.

title: The emperor's new clothes: The new Commonwealth Charter and CHOGM in Sri Lanka
body: Last week was the Commonwealth week. As the Commonwealth begins celebrations on the theme "Opportunity through enterprise" it may see its own opportunities and credibility dwindle to zero by the time its prestigious Heads of Government Meeting is held in Sri Lanka this November. According to announcements last Monday, the Commonwealth Heads of Government meeting (CHOGM), will go ahead in Colombo despite Sri Lanka's atrocious human rights record. Ironically, last Monday was also the Commonwealth Day when the Queen signed a new Commonwealth Charter that promises human rights, rule of law and democracy. As the world prepares to censure Sri Lanka at the UN Human Rights Council this week, the Commonwealth is preparing to honour Sri Lanka with its premier meeting, even if it is at the cost of all the values it just reiterated. This need not happen. The Commonwealth has mechanisms to scrutinise, censure, suspend and expel countries that seriously and persistently violate its core principles of democracy, rule of law and human rights, and it must use them. Australia, Bangladesh, Canada, Jamaica, Sierra Leone, Tanzania, Trinidad and Tobago, and Vanuatu currently make up the Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group (CMAG) -- the Commonwealth's watchdog body. For the moment Maldives, another member, is suspended and will be discussed at its April end meeting in New York. But, the elephant in the room is Maldives' bigger island neighbour -- Sri Lanka. In 2009, Commonwealth Heads of Government initiated measures to reform the organisation and save it from irrelevance. Under pressure of reforms, in 2011 CMAG agreed to fully examine all serious or persistent violations of Commonwealth values, instead of acting against just the unconstitutional overthrow of governments. Now the proof of the pudding is in the eating. CMAG and the Commonwealth have time and again failed to arrest Sri Lanka's long running human rights abuses. Sri Lanka is instead now being rewarded with the position of hosting the Commonwealth's most prestigious meeting. This has caused great dissension among members-states and is contradictory to the opprobrium Sri Lanka faces from the international community and at the UN. The very fact that the organisation is still willing to conduct its premier meeting in a country that is being internationally charged with grave international humanitarian law violations and serious human rights abuses is enough to question the Commonwealth's commitments. Outside the Commonwealth, outrage over Sri Lanka's behaviour has been mounting steadily. In 2011, UN Secretary General's Panel of Experts on Sri Lanka found credible allegations of war crimes during the last months of Sri Lanka's civil war that concluded in 2009. This year another report commissioned by the UN Secretary General on the UN's own behaviour during that time came out with chilling and credible accusations of systematic and planned violations of humanitarian law. A report by the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights released last month pointed to the same violations and added that little had been done toward making those responsible accountable in any way. In every case Sri Lanka has challenged the motivation of international institutions and rejected allegations outright. Even recommendations made by a flawed domestic commission of inquiry are yet to receive any serious attention. Last year the UN Human Rights Council passed a resolution on Sri Lanka asking it to at least implement these recommendations. Now, in the absence of any results, the Council is preparing for another resolution later this month. Meanwhile human rights violations continue unabated. Disappearances and crackdown on dissent has been rife, with journalists and judges being attacked and killed. The North remains militarised, amid muted and fearful allegations of abuse. Majoritarian ethno-religious extremism is on the rise in the absence of protection from the government to the populations of the country. In January Sri Lanka impeached its own chief justice and replaced her with a favourite, in the face of international clamour, through a process found illegal by the country's Supreme Court. In the absence of specific precepts, the standard for interpreting the breach of broad Commonwealth values has always depended on the moral strength of its leadership. For current leaders, it appears that internationally documented egregious wartime violations and grave ongoing abuses do not breach Commonwealth thresholds. While it is unbecoming to shelter in the vagueness of lofty values, it is even worse to gloss over specific standards. The Commonwealth's Latimer House Rules clearly lay down specific values that may not be breached. It requires that separation of powers and the independence of the judiciary are maintained without interference. The Commonwealth secretary-general has a mandate to act through his good offices in times of crisis. While what happened with the chief justice of Sri Lanka was an apparent breach of values by any reading of the Latimer House Rules, instead of holding Sri Lanka accountable, the secretary-general stated, after a recent visit, that he welcomes "the recognition of the need for change, to ensure that any such process" (the impeachment) "in future is free of contention and does not call into question Sri Lanka's commitment to the independence of the judiciary and separation of powers." As it is now becoming apparent the secretary-general's good offices seem to be neither redeeming the Commonwealth's flagging relevance nor underscoring its credibility. CMAG's April meeting can repair all this. It has the power to formally take Sri Lanka under scrutiny and set benchmarks that need to be fulfilled. Within CMAG, Canada has already taken a strong stance. Its prime minister has said he would not attend CHOGM in Sri Lanka without substantial progress on the human rights front. Australia, which has been relatively ambiguous, has an opportunity to show its commitment to Commonwealth values. Bangladesh, as Chair, will have a vital moment to take the lead in upholding the Commonwealth's belief in democracy, rule of law and human rights.Bangladesh's own current examination of war crimes will no doubt be a clear reminder that accountability cannot and must not be buried away anywhere. Trinidad & Tobago (T&T) was host to the 2009 CHOGM that first called for Commonwealth reforms and also decided to delay Sri Lanka's offer to host the 2011 CHOGM to 2013 due to early concerns about its record. T&T, where the notion of reforms was officially born, will have the important responsibility of protecting its legacy of hosting one of the most progressive CHOGMs in Commonwealth history. Tanzania, which stood resolute in the Commonwealth's battle for justice against apartheid, will not want to see itself weak and vacillating in upholding the association's core principles. The island states of Jamaica and Vanuatu have the opportunity to indicate the power of small states in upholding values and influencing others on points of principle. With its weak and underperforming record the Commonwealth may prefer to be the proverbial ostrich that buries its head under the sand. But CMAG member states should realise that their choices at the April meeting may well be the only opportunity the Commonwealth has to right itself, if it is to escape historic ignominy and lose its credibility when Sri Lanka hosts the 2013 CHOGM. If CMAG fails to act, only sad laughter could acknowledge the Commonwealth Charter of rights that was adopted last week and the fact that its president will go on to Chair the Commonwealth till 2015. The writer is Director, Commonwealth Human Rights Initiative.

title: Micromax wants deal with Ericsson after court order
body: India's Micromax promised on Tuesday to try to work out a patent deal with Ericsson after the Swedish equipment-maker sued the leading domestic handset maker for alleged patent infringement. The company issued the statement after an Indian court Monday gave an interim ruling in favour of Ericsson, which had filed an $18-million suit against Micromax, accusing it of using its patented technology to make mobile phones. The suit marks the first high-profile Indian patent litigation case amid a number worldwide, notably between Apple Inc of the United States and South Korea's Samsung Electronics Co. The court told Micromax to work out what is known as a Fair, Reasonable and Non-Discriminatory, or FRAND, licence agreement with Ericsson. Handset makers often rely on technologies owned by other firms to make their mobile phones and conclude a FRAND licence agreement when doing so. "Micromax is committed to negotiating a FRAND licence with Ericsson as Ericsson has undertaken to provide" such a licence to Micromax," the Indian company said in an emailed statement. Micromax was also told to pay Ericsson royalties of up to two percent of the sale price of the disputed handset devices and deposit the sum with the court. A spokesman for Ericsson was not immediately available for comment.

title: JUTA's rejoinder and Star's reply
body: In a clarification on the news item "JUTA demands formation of new probe body" published in The Daily Star Friday, president and secretary of Jahangirnagar University Teachers' Association (JUTA) Dr Sharif Enamul Kabir and Dr M A Matin denied that the JU teachers were unaware of the meeting between JUTA leaders and the Prime Minister (PM). The decision to meet the PM had been taken at a meeting of the JUTA executive committee. The clarification also said that it was not decided that the teachers would go on a strike after the holy Ramadan. Our reply: The report said that teachers criticised JUTA leaders as "they met the Prime Minister (PM) keeping the other teachers unaware of it". The fact is that the teachers at the general meeting of JUTA, held on Thursday, 31 December '97 were critical of the JUTA leaders as the "decision was not made at a JUTA general meeting prior to the meeting with the PM", a number of teachers who attended the meeting told The Daily Star. Regarding the teachers' strike, our report was that the issue was only "proposed at the meeting" and there was no indication in the report that it was decided or resolved at the meeting.

title: Main Eid congregation in Nat'l Eidgah at 8:30am
body: The main congregation of Eid-ul-Fitr, the largest religious festival of the Muslims, will be held at the National Eidgah on the High Court premises at 8:30am on Eid day. However, the venue of the main jamaat will be shifted to the Baitul Mukarram National Mosque in case of inclement weather, Religious Affairs Minister Principal Motiur Rahman said yesterday. Besides, five more congregations will be held at the national mosque, he told an inter-ministerial meeting at his office. The law enforcement agencies will remain alert during the Eid congregations to fend off any untoward incident, the minister added.

title: Fitra fixed at Tk 60
body: Fitra has been fixed at minimum Tk 60 per head this year. Islamic Foundation has fixed the amount at a meeting today. Member Secretary of National Fitra Fixation Committee Maulana AMM Sirajul Islam presided over the meeting. A press release of Islamic Foundation issued after the meeting said per person Fitra has been fixed at minimum Tk 60 and maximum Tk 1650 this year taking into account the market prices of wheat, ata, dates and other items. Fitra can be given in cash or kind. Fitra is 'wajib' for all members of a family and should be paid to the poor people before the Eid Jamaat. Prof Siraj Uddin Ahmad, principal of Government Madrasa-e-Alia, Dhaka, Dr Saiyed Abdullah Al Maruf, assistant professor of Arabic Department of Dhaka University, among others, attended the meeting.

title: Session jam in JU on rise
body: Session jam in Jahangirnagar University (JU) is on the rise as there exists no effective measure to monitor the academic activities. "Once reputed as the session-jam-free university, JU is now running behind the academic session by two years," a top university official told The Daily Star. Giving his reactions, a teacher in the Social Science Faculty, preferring anonymity, said, "The university is lacking in leadership and the administration is busy with exercising powers, groupings and teachers' politics.""Academic activities of the university did not progress due to lack of proper leadership though the situation was almost calm and quiet during the last three years," the teachers who is also a Syndicate member told The Daily Star. He also underscored the need for regular monitoring of academic activities. In a meeting held recently, chairpersons of the departments and deans of the faculties unanimously observed that the academic activities should be monitored regularly to restore discipline and regularity in the academic arena. Irregularity of the teachers in taking their routine classes, deteriorating teacher-student relationship, faulty examination system and unscheduled closures were identified as the main reasons for the session jam, teachers, officials and students observed while talking to this correspondent. Due to this situation, classes and examinations are not completed according to the schedule. Students and teachers also came out with contradictory versions regarding the session jam at the university. Students have alleged that a large number of teachers are not regular in taking their classes while the teachers have denied the charges right away. Blaming the students for 'sterility' and stalemate in academic activities the teachers said the students were not regular in their classes. "Teacher-student relations have also deteriorated owing to this accusations and counter accusations," commented a senior professor requesting anonymity. The academic activities experienced a big blow as the university came under an unscheduled closure for 280 days during the last five years. When the university was closed sine die in 1993, academic activities remained suspended for 103 days. Another unscheduled closure claimed 51 days of the same session. In the session 1994-95, JU again suffered from unscheduled closure of 24 days, which was followed by another 54 days in 1995-96 and 13 days in the 1996-97 sessions. Triggered mainly by political unrest, students' strikes, clashes between Chhatra League and Chhatra Dal, and Islami Chhatra Shibir's armed attempt to capture the campus led to these unscheduled closures. Prior to these unrest, teachers were also assaulted by the Chhatra Dal workers in the university which led to a teachers' strike in the university. At present, there are six academic batches in the university instead of four as per the academic capacity. Examinations of the students of session 1991-92, the oldest batch, are yet to be completed while they were scheduled to pass out in 1995. Delayed by 18 months, the first year classes of the session 1996-97, began only on January 4 this year. The students of 1992-93 session have spent four years and a half to complete their three-year honours courses recently. About 18 months behind the schedule, they started their classes on December 22, 1993. Classes of the students of the session 1993-94 began on December 3, 1994 and they are scheduled to sit for their honours final examination by March next. The students of the session 1994-95 and 1995-96 started their first year classes on January 16, 1996 and February 18, 1997 respectively. Each of these batches is now set for their second year and first year examinations respectively after about 18 months in one academic year. No examination of the batches could be started according to the examination schedules set by the examination office as classes were not completed in time, examination office sources said. Abu Taher Mojumder, a senior professor of English Department held teachers' politics responsible for this situation and suggested to curtail the number of elections as the teachers have to remain busy with around five or six elections every year. "Teachers should be dutiful and the administration should take measure to restore the teachers' accountability," he added, emphasising on motivation of students in this regard. A top ranking official in the Registrar Building said, "The administration is aware of the absentee teachers, but no action is taken against them fearing agitation and pressure by teachers' groups aimed at attaining their political gain. "Regular monitoring of academic activities is a must to eliminate the session jam," he added. Talking to The Daily Star, president of JU Teachers' Association (JUTA) Prof Jasimuddin Ahmed said, "Authorities should have integrity to ensure academic progress.""Authority's lack of integrity is proved through the rare holding of meetings of academic Council," he continued. Referring to the academic calendar preferred recently, he said, "Academic calendar would be meaningless if it is not implemented."The vice-Chancellor of the university Prof Amirul Islam Chowdhury said, "We have prepared an academic calendar and it will be implemented in taming the academic backlog.""Examination system has been revamped and we have been monitoring academic activities regularly to improve the situation," he added.

title: Police asked to take stern action against terrorists at DU
body: As violence again flared up on the Dhaka University Campus, the law enforcing agencies have been asked to take stern action against the trouble-makers, reports UNB. Highly placed police sources said the top level of the government expressed resentment after the recent acts of terrorism on the campus. Law enforcers were specially asked not show mercy to the activists of Bangladesh Chhatra League, the student wing of the ruling party, as some of them are tarnishing the image of the government. The trouble erupted on the campus last week between the two rival factions of BCL, mainly over the submission of tender and establishing supremacy in the halls. An activist of BCL was stabbed following the trouble between the two groups which control most of the DU residential halls. Police said that in line with the government directive, they raided two BCL-dominated halls and arrested five of its activists, including two outsiders, on Monday. "Following fresh directive, the police action will continue and new steps will be taken against the terrorists, irrespective of party affiliations," said a senior police official.

title: Police prepare list of over dozen godfathers
body: Police prepared a list of more than a dozen godfathers, who allegedly patronise the notorious terrorists in the capital city, reports UNB. The list, which include politicians both from the ruling and opposition parties and business tycoons, was made by the detective branch after the recent arrest of top gangleaders, officials said yesterday. They said the ring leaders, especially "Sweden" Aslam and Bikash mentioned some names of stalwarts, including ministers and MPs, as their patrons. According to the officials, the DB investigators will seek permission from the Home Minister, police headquarters and Dhaka Metropolitan Police to interrogate those named by the top terrorists. The police authorities had announced cash awards for four wanted gangleaders of the city. Of them, Aslam and Bikash were arrested. Two others are Prakash, brother of Bikash, and Joseph.

title: Pak PM to make 'private' India visit
body: Pakistan Prime Minister Raja Pervez Ashraf will visit India for the first time this week for a day-long pilgrimage to Ajmer Sharif, officials in both countries said yesterday. "Pakistan's prime minister will be in India on Saturday. This is a private visit and he will be accompanied by his family and other officials," an Indian government official said on condition of anonymity. "He is not expected to meet any Indian political leaders. This is clearly a religious and spiritual trip," he told AFP.

title: Girl's body recovered
body: Body of a teenage girl was recovered from Meghna River under Monpura upazila on Friday. The deceased was identified as Mamuli Akhter, 18, daughter of Salauddin of Rahamanpur village in the upazila. Locals saw the body at about 6:00am and informed police. Sub inspector at Monpura police station Mohammad Ali said that the deceased 'went missing' on March 8 after her husband divorced her recently. Police sent the body to hospital for autopsy. They could not say whether it was case of suicide or murder.

title: Indian ex-airforce chief home raided
body: Detectives raided the home of India's former air force chief yesterday as part of an investigation into alleged bribes paid to secure a $748 million contract for 12 Italian helicopters. Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) spokeswoman Dharini Mishra said former air chief marshal SP Tyagi's home was among more than a dozen addresses targeted in the raids. The CBI had filed a "preliminary enquiry" report last month into the alleged scandal, then linking four companies, four Westerners and seven Indians to the bribery allegations.

title: Greenidge to take over youth side
body: Gordon Greenidge the technical director of coaching is scheduled to arrive back in the city today. But the West Indian opener, who went to England to celebrate the Christmas and New Year with his family, will not be around during the tri-nation tournament involving India, Pakistan and Bangladesh. It was learnt that Greenidge will accompany the South Africa bound national youth team that will participate in the second world youth cricket championship. The team leaves the capital on Jan 8. Jalal Ahmed Chowdhury will act as coach of the national side during Greenidge's absence.

title: Govt to track persons making ill comments about Prophet
body: The government will form a probe committee to identify persons who made derogatory comments on Prophet Muhammad (pbuh) on Facebook, blogs, internet, print and the electronic media. Mahbubul Haque Shakil, prime minister's special assistant (media), told The Daily Star that the decision was taken yesterday to take action against them. Although he did not elaborate as to when the committee will be formed and who will be in it and when it will start working and few other related questions, he said the law ministry would soon notify the public about the committee.

body: 'This country belongs to people of the hills and plains, Muslims, Hindus, Buddhists and Christians' Tarique Rahman returns home after 17 years in exile A psychological reset for BNP, a moment of political recalibration for Bangladesh Zubaida, daughter Zaima reach Gulshan residence হাদি হত্যার ন্যায়বিচার নিশ্চিতে যা যা করা হয়েছে, উপদেষ্টাদের শাহবাগে এসে তার ব্যাখ্যা দেওয়ার দাবি জানিয়েছে ইনকিলাব মঞ্চ।

title: Journalists in Ctg blast bomb attack on press
body: CHITTAGONG, Jan 5: A protest rally of the journalists and newspaper owners association today strongly deplored the bomb attack on the Daily Azadi and demanded immediate arrest of those responsible for the incident, reports BSS. Held at Chittagong Press Club auditorium the rally was presided over by the President of Chittagong Union of Journalists (CUJ) Ataul Hakim. President of Chittagong Press Club Abu Sufian, Managing Editor of the Daily Azadi M A Malek, Editor of the daily Purbokone Taslimuddn Chowdhury, News Editor of the Daily Azadi Sadhan Dhar, journalists Obaidul Haq, Mohammad Yusuf, Kazi Jafrul Islam, M Nasirul Haq, Farook Iqbal, Swapan Mahajan, Aktherun-Nabi, Sayed Murtoza Ali, Helaluddin Chowdhury, Shahidul Alam, Samir Barua, Jashim Chowdhury (Sabuj) and Ashoke Chowdhury spoke at the rally. CUJ General Secretary Nurul Ameen conducted it. Speakers at the rally said continued bomb attacks on newspapers and press club are deplorable in any civilised society. An identified circle is behind it as part of its evil design. "This identified circle is repeating such incident as no action was taken against the attackers in the past which led journalists and newspaper offices to a state of insecurity," they said. The Daily Azadi, the oldest Bengali daily in Chittagong came under bomb attack by a band of miscreants last night. The journalists leaders urged the government to take effective steps to ensure freedom of the press and security of the journalists. The meeting unanimously decided to keep six inches space blank in the dailies of Chittagong for next ten days in protest against the incident.

title: Colin makes difference
body: South Africa batsman Colin Ingram jumps into air in celebration after scoring a century in the first ODI against Pakistan at Chevrolet Park in Bloemfontein yesterday. PHOTO: AFP Colin Ingram hit an unbeaten century to set up a comfortable 125-run win for South Africa in the first one-day international against Pakistan at Chevrolet Park on Sunday. The left-handed Ingram made 105 not out as South Africa piled up 315 for four after being sent in to bat. Pakistan could only make 190 in reply. Ingram made his runs off 103 balls with ten fours. It was his third one-day international century and his second against Pakistan. He shared partnerships of 120 for the third wicket with captain AB de Villiers (65), 62 for the fourth wicket with Faf du Plessis (26) and 50 off only 23 balls with Farhaan Behardien, who hammered 34 not out off 14 deliveries. Graeme Smith and Hashim Amla set an aggressive tone with an opening partnership of 72 after South Africa were sent in, with both batsmen going for their shots against Junaid Khan and Umar Gul despite the Pakistan new ball bowlers getting some early assistance from the pitch. The South Africans opted for the batting power play immediately after the compulsory first ten overs but lost Smith when he gloved an attempted reverse sweep to be caught behind off Saeed Ajmal, one of four spin bowlers in the six-man bowling attack, for 30. Amla made 43 before he was caught at deep square leg off Mohammad Hafeez. De Villiers and Ingram then set South Africa on the way to a big total with a run-a-ball stand during which they kept the score moving quickly against the Pakistan spin bowlers with deft placement and good running between wickets. Pakistan made a bright start with Mohammad Hafeez and Nasir Jamshed putting on 42 for the first wicket off 43 balls before the suffered a double blow. Jamshed was caught at slip by Graeme Smith off Rory Kleinveldt for 25 and Hafeez fell for the same score in unlucky fashion when a drive by Younis Khan was deflected by bowler Kleinveldt into the stumps for Hafeez to be run out. Asad Shafiq fell cheaply and Pakistan were unable to build substantial partnerships with captain Misbahul Haq top-scoring with 38. Shahid Afridi hit 34 off 16 balls before he was last man out but his innings was never likely to alter the outcome. Afridi hit three sixes, including a massive strike which sailed out of the ground and into a car park. Kleinveldt, whose first two balls were hit for four, came back strongly to finish with four for 22 in 5.2 overs, while Ryan McLaren took three for 19. The win gave South Africa a 1-0 lead in the five-match series. The second match will be in Centurion on Friday. .SCORES IN BRIEF SOTH AFRICA: 315 for 4 (Smith 30, Amla 43, De Villiers 65, Ingram 105 not out, Du Plessis 26, Behardien 34 not out; Ajmal 2-53) PAKISTAN: 190 all out (Hafeez 25, Jamshed 25, Younis 30, Misbah 38, Malik 19, Afridi 34; Kleinveldt 4-22, McLaren3-19) Result: South Africa won by 125 runs. Player-of-the-match: Colin Ingram.

title: Chronology of deaths during joint drive
body: October 17... Shafiqul Islam, 16, son of Dudu Mia, dies as the army opens fire on an agitating crowd in Bogra. Md. Yakub Ali, 40, organising secretary of the Uttara thana unit of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP), dies in the capital after being picked up by the army. His body is handed to relatives the next day. Jahangir Hossain, 38, a BNP activist, is picked up by the army from his Pallabi residence in the city and dies in custody. Relatives receive Jahangir's body the following day. October 19... Abul Khayer Molla, 50, a BNP activist and freedom fighter, dies at the Gopalganj Sadar Hospital after army arrest and interrogation. October 21... Afzal Hossain, 25, a businessman, dies at the Savar Combined Military Hospital after being picked up from a tea stall and interrogated by an army team. October 22... Amirul Islam Rocket, 35, general secretary of the Bhola district unit of the Awami League, dies at the Bhola Sadar Hospital, a day after arrest. Saifuzzaman dies in Gaibandha following his arrest by the joint forces the day before. October 23... Nazmul Islam Milan, 40, a Jubo League activist and ticket seller of a cinema, dies at the Rajshahi Medical College Hospital hours after his arrest by the army. October 25... Abdul Aziz Sardar, 47, general secretary of the Pangsha thana BNP, dies two days after his arrest by the troops on October 23. October 26... Khorshed, 35, a day-labourer of Kalapoka Ramgati, dies at the Choumuhuni station, allegedly beaten by the army while asleep. October 27... Masum Biswas, 38, an activist of the Khulna Jubo League and cousin of AL lawmaker Sheikh Helal, dies at the Dhaka Medical College Hospital (DMCH), three days after his arrest in Khulna on October 23. October 28... Kala Chand Tripura, a constable of the Pekua Police Station in Cox's Bazar, dies at the Chittagong Medical College Hospital (CMCH), four days after being beaten by an army team. Abul Hossain Litu, 27, dies in his poultry farm at Savar following alleged torture by the army. The army claims Litu fell from the rooftop of the farmhouse and died as he tried to escape. October 29... Jamir Uddin, a suspected criminal, dies at the Gopalganj Thana Health Complex in Sylhet hours after his arrest by the army. Abu Syed Delu, 22, died at the Chest Disease Hospital in the capital a week after his arrest. October 30... Jennifer Syed King, 25, a Jatiyatabadi Chhatra Dal (JCD) activist, dies at Panchagar, a day after his arrest. Tota Mia, 37, a Jubo League activist, dies at Madaripur within four hours of his arrest. November 1... Mizanur Rahman Busha, 40, an activist of the Chuadanga unit of the Jubo Dal, dies at the Khulna Medical College Hospital, two days after his arrest on October 29. November 3... Lebu Mia, 45, a farmer of Baithakhali in Habiganj, dies. He was arrested on October 30 and handed to the police. November 4... Abdul Haque, 32, a microbus driver, dies at the Osmani Medical College Hospital, ten days after his arrest on October 25. He was sent to jail although he was sick. November 7... Rashedul Hasan, 35, an assistant film director, dies at the DMCH. He was picked up from his Tejkunipara residence on November 2 and the next morning found unconscious in front of his house. November 8... Saiful Islam, 22, an activist of Chhagolnaiya Jubo Dal, dies at the Feni Sadar Hospital hours after being arrested with crackers. He was handed to the police in a critical condition. November 9... Abu Sufian, 30, dies at an army camp in Mohammadpur. November 10... 73-year-old Haji Abul Kashem dies at the Tangail General Hospital nine days after arrest. November 19... Zahirul Islam Mia, 25, president of Ward No. 82 unit of the Jubo Dal, dies at the Mitford Hospital after, according to army, residents of Shyampur beat him up and handed him over to the troops. An unidentified man, aged about 40, dies at the Mitford Hospital after being handed to the Keraniganj police by the army in a critical condition. November 20... Tasu Mia, 45, a businessman at the Nilkhet Bakusha Market, dies at an army camp, a day after his arrest. Army claimed that he was run over by a passenger bus. November 21... Masum, 30, dies at the DMCH two days after he was picked from Fatullah. A day labourer, Hakim, dies at the DMCH eight days after being caught in crossfire between the army and criminals at Gabtoli in the city on November 13. Shariful Mallik, 26, dies on the way to the Khulna Medical College Hospital. He was arrested from Rupsha on November 1. November 25... Arju Mia, 38, a BNP leader and president of the Poura Rickshaw Sramik Dal, dies at the DMCH. He was picked up from Bora of the Poura area and admitted to the Gazipur Sadar Hospital in a critical condition. November 30... Tipu Biswas, 35, a Khulna Jubo Dal activist, dies in army custody. December 10... Abdus Sattar, a businessman, dies at the Bogra Mohammadpur Hospital, two days after being picked up by the army. December 14... Nabi Hossain Kahn, 50, a rickshawpuller, dies at Narsinghdi after being picked up by the army. His body was found in a pond in Raipura. December 15... Jasim Uddin, 25, dies at the CMCH hours after his arrest. December 16... Shafiuddin Swapan, 35, a Jubo Dal leader, dies at the DMCH. Omar Faruk alias Tiger Faruk, 46, brother of Narayanganj city BNP joint convenor Abdus Sattar, dies at the DMCH after arrest the day before. Ibrahim Khalil Ibu, a Chhatra League leader of Kotbari Rampur in Comilla, dies at the DMCH, a day after his arrest. Mir Jahirul Rabin, 22, student of Tejgaon College, dies at the DMCH after being picked up by the army on December 4 and admitted to the hospital on December 8. Abu Barek Rubel, 24, of Charandeep of Buripukur, succumbs to his injuries prior to his admission to the Boalkhali Hospital after being picked up by the army during a drive to nab robbers. December 20... Yusuf, 34 of Rangunia, dies at the CMCH. January 3... Mohammad Rashed, 25, dies at the CMCH. He was arrested along with firearms from Sandwip on December 25 night. January 6... a leader of an outlawed party dies few hours after he was arrested in Pabna. January 8... Abdul Khaleq Sarkar, 28, a poultry businessman, dies at the Gazipur Sadar Hospital. He was arrested from Shafipur Bazar on January 6.

title: Shunte Ki Pao! to compete at Cinema du Reel
body: Kamar Ahmed Simon's documentary “Shunte Ki Pao!” (Are You Listening!), has been selected for the main international competition at the 35th Cinema du Reel in Paris, one of Europe's biggest documentary festivals. The film also recently opened the 10th Asian Forum for Documentary. The film, based on the lives of residents of a small village in coastal Bangladesh, had earlier been screened at the biggest documentary festival in the world, IDFA, and was the opening film at Dok Leipzig, the oldest documentary festival. The film had also won three European grants, and was the first Bangladeshi film to be ever invited to the prestigious Berlinale, being one of the nine films chosen for the editing lab of the Berlinale Talent Campus programme. Director of the film, Kamar Ahmed Simon, informed that the Bangladesh screening of the film has been hampered by distributors' lack of interest to show it, after the censor board took a lot of time to clear it without any curtailing. Although they had plans of screening the film through film societies, they had to put it on hold since the Shahbag Movement began in the country in February.

title: Fracas in BB
body: Bangladesh Bank, the central bank of the country, looks diminutive today after what happened within its precincts on Monday. The rumpus was on a high dare-devilry rating with 40-50 employees storming into GM (admn)'s chamber and ransacking it to a point where he had to duck under the table only to be a sitting target for kicks and punches from the intruders. The GM desperately ran for shelter at the governor's chamber. There he and the Bangladesh Bank governor paid audience to spiteful remarks with a blistering demand shouted at them for their immediate removal from office. All this was said to be the handiwork of Bangladesh Bank Employees' Association, the vanquished party in the last CBA election which was won by Bangladesh Bank Karmachari Samity with a narrow margin. Although no organisation supporting any political party is legally allowed to function in Bangladesh Bank, some reports suggested that the incumbent Karmachari Samity has had a pro-BNP image while its rival Employees Association has been known for its leanings toward the AL. Some leaders of the party which had lost the election demanded transfer of a few key officials allegedly responsible for victimising their supporters. The GM apparently refused to concede this angering them a good deal. Some observers even tend to look at it as part of a scheme plotted outside the bank to exert pressure on the governor lest he took some decisions which were on the anvil. If it is a case of rivalry between the election winner and the loser then it needs to be addressed by utmost neutrality in the administration and by reminding all concerned that they are debarred from showing off any clout of national political parties, overtly or covertly, according to BB rules. We would like to see deterrent action taken on the culprits and an uncovering done of the machinations behind the outburst, if any. This looked like a tall order for the 3-member inquiry committee headed by Harinarayan Majumder, an executive director of Bangladesh Bank, especially when he was given 24 hours to file the report. Nothing like solving the problem internally, but if need be, expert trouble-shooting advice should be sought from the finance ministry without hesitation. At all events, we want discipline restored to Bangladesh Bank. It cannot afford its institutional efficiency and prestige, as the central bank of the country, to be playthings for the union leaders, past or present.

title: Anniversary of death of Sir Salimullah today
body: A memorial meeting and discussion in observance of the 85th death anniversary of eminent politician of the sub-continent and founder of Muslim League Nawab Sir Salimullah will be held in the city today, reports BSS. Wreaths will be placed at the mazar of Sir Salimullah at their family graveyard at Begum Bazar at 3 pm. A milad mahfil, Qurankhwani and special prayers will also be held there.

title: Dilemma for BJP
body: The two-party system is still a far cry in India. In fact, if one were to add up national and regional parties, the number comes to around 30. Still, three formations have come to emerge. There is the Bharatiya Janata Party, with 12 regional allies, Congress with six and the United Front retaining the 14-party alliance. What it means is that no political party will get a clear majority in the next Lok Sabha because they have themselves limited the scope of winning 272 in a house of 543. They share seats with the parties with their allies. The BJP, which once said that it would go it alone, has realised that it has to have the support of other parties. No doubt, the argument is that this time its purpose is to create a niche in the south and the other non-Hindi speaking states and to fight on its own in the elections that will follow the present one. Yet, it is an admission that it cannot come to power on its own. The coalition, which it ran down in the past, has come to be accepted as the future pattern. This has naturally diluted the BJP's poll plank. It argues that the party has no other option in the political climate that prevails in the country. This is true. What it does not realise is that when it would want to return to its own agenda, the territory vacated by it might have been occupied by the fanatics. It would be increasingly under pressure to go back to its original stand. But the party is in no position to disturb the set up it has so labouriously built in the states, where it does not count. The question it should ask itself is : Can it pursue the diluted programme without alienating its committed voters? So far the BJP has stood for a stridentHindutva, which has been spelled out in the terms of Hindu Rashtriya, the common civil code, the scrapping of Article 370, which gives a special status to Kashmir, and the building of Ram temple at the site where the Babri masjid stood before demolition. The removal of the mosques sharing the premises of temples at Mathura and Varanasi has been deferred for the time-being. It is no more a secret that the parties with which the BJP has aligned itself are against such demands. Some of the allies have said so publicly. In fact, the very dilution has attracted the parties which were opposed to the BJP earlier. Its leader, Atal Behari Vajpyee, has said that the BJP will not pursue its own programme because it will have to accommodate the programmes of other parties. It is a good statement to cement relations with the allies but is it good enough for the BJP's traditional voters? When the Jana Sangh, before it was rechristined as BJP, had a stand which was wishy-washy. Then it never crossed a double digit in the Lok Sabha. It was able to increase its tally to 90 in 1977 after Gandhian Jaiprakash Narayan made them it of the Janta Party, which swept the polls in the wake of Mrs Indira Gandhi's authoritarian rule. But then came a stage when the Jana Sangh members had to choose between the RSS, its mentor, and the Janata Party. They left the Janata Party and founded the BJP. LK Advani then announced that they would go it alone. That was the time when they began to play the Hindu card. The new policy was focused on an appeal to Hindus in the name of religion and it articulated such causes as would foment religious sentiments, to the exclusion and discomfort of the Muslims and secular forces. There were pressures on the BJP to give up its Hindutva stand to expand its base. But the BJP did not change. It reaped the dividends and, as a result, its number rose to 161 in the last Lok Sabha. The party became the single largest group in the House. It was evident that the stand of Hindu chauvinism won them seats. The voters, who have stood behind it, have a specific image of the party. Can it now turn its back to them and say that it has changed or diluted its policy because of certain considerations? The danger in such an eventuality is that those who have put faith in the BJP because of its Hindu face may feel betrayed and may even distance themselves from it. It is difficult to believe that the BJP will do so, particularly when the RSS is the boss. Only the other day did I see Vajpayee in knickers, standing in salute before RSS Chief Raju Bhaya, published in a newspaper. The cat is out of the bag. How can the BJP which is an instrument of the RSS can make a departure from the basic philosophy of Hindu Rashtriya. It would tantamount to the tail wagging the body. In fact, RSS ideologue Govindacharya let the cat out of the bag when he said an interview that it was "practical idealism". It meant the party has adopted a strategy for winning. He went on to explain: "It may also be termed as a tactical act of self-defence." What Govindacharya said was that the situation demanded the BJP to act in a particular way so that it could have alliance with different parties in different parts of India. But 'practical idealism' is the not a phrase which the BJP supporters in rural areas will understand, presuming that the urbanites will. They have hitched their wagon to the BJP because it held out certain promises, the promises of Hidutva, common civil code, etc. They may not appreciate the point of strategy, which the BJP emphasises, to get a foothold in the south, Orissa or West Bengal. The diluted stand of the BJP may make fanatic bodies like the Vishva Hindu Parishad (VHP) more attractive. However, the only saving grace for the BJP is that the VHP is also an instrument of the RSS. It will see to it that VHP does not come in the way of the BJP. In any case, Govindacharya's observations should be a warning to persons like George Fernandes and Ram Krishna Hegde, still parading as anti-communal in their approach. They say that the BJP has changed. If it is a strategy, then how? The RSS ideologue argues that it is 'practical' to pursue the line which the party has taken at present. To read anything more than that is foolish. Fernandes and Hegde are seasoned enough to know that. By associating with parties which, till recently, had secular credentials, the BJP expects the percentage of votes (20.29 per cent as against 20.80 per cent by Congress) it polled in the last election to increase. People sitting on the fence or those who have weakened in their faith in secularism have already begun to feel that the BJP is after all not that communal when people like Fernandes, Hedge and MGK Menon, the renowned scientist, have joined hands with it. The real danger that the BJP faces is that in an effort to win the non-BJP voters it may lose some of its support. Its appeal is on the basis of clothes ofHindutva it wears. By putting on some other clothes, it may be found acceptable but it may lose the people who have stood by it for years. The fielding of LK Advani, so far saying 'no' to the Lok Sabha, is meant probably to sustain the hopes of hardliners that all that the BJP is doing is to get a majority. If, by a quirk of circumstances, it attains 272 seats in the Lok Sabha on its own symbol, Advani would be the prime minister. If the majority is through the allies, the soft Vajpayee would occupy the chair. And, in any case, Govindacharya has made it clear that Vajpayee is only a 'mask'.

title: Sammilita Parishad sweeps BGMEA polls
body: Sammilita Parishad leader Atiqul Islam has won the biennial elections of Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Association, securing 21 out of 27 posts. Two panels -- Sammilita Parishad and Forum -- contested the polls for 2013-14. The Parishad won 15 of 20 posts in Dhaka and six of seven in Chittagong, said an election board official. The results were announced on Monday morning at the BGMEA office in Dhaka. Islam, managing director of Islam Garments Ltd, will take over as the new BGMEA president on March 21 according to the trade body's schedule. Parishad's rival Forum panel led by Rising Group Managing Director Mahmud Hasan Khan bagged five posts in Dhaka and one in Chittagong. The elections were held on Sunday in Dhaka and Chittagong with a turnout of 88 percent, the highest in the trade body's history. A total of 2,812 out of 3,196 votes were cast in Dhaka and Chittagong, according to the election board data. In the BGMEA election, voters pick a total of 27 directors -- 20 from Dhaka and seven from Chittagong. The elected directors will select a president and four vice-presidents. And the first vice-president will come from the Chittagong region. “I have no complaints as the election was held peacefully. I am satisfied with the election arrangements,” said Forum leader Khan after the voting.

title: Acute water shortage grips Ctg South Halishahar
body: Some unscrupulous residents of South Halishahar of Chittagong city are making a quick buck by illegally selling water obtained from domestic connections, causing an acute water shortage. With water available in the mains for only 24 hours every week, these residents, usually housed at the entrance of alleys, use powerful motors to quickly fill their reserve tanks. This leaves other residents living farther down the alleys with very little or no water at all, compelling them to sometimes purchase it from these illegal water traders. The acute water shortage became prominent since October 2011, when Chittagong Water Supply and Sewerage Authority (Wasa) decided to provide water in South Halishahar from Tuesday noon to Wednesday noon. “As soon as water arrives, these traders fill up numerous jars and large reserve tanks in their houses to sell later on,” said Abul Hossain, a resident suffering from the water shortage. Every day over 1,500 jars, each with a capacity of 20 litres, are sold to different households, shops, restaurants and businesses for Tk 20 each, said Abul. “We requested these traders to stop their business for at least two hours so that we can collect water for our households, but they do not pay heed to our request,” he added. A good number of these traders are active in Cement Crossing, Bandartilla, Kazir Goli, Alishah Para and Narikel Tola areas under South Halishahar. On a visit to Narikel Tola recently, a number vans filled with water jars were found parked outside some houses. The locals were quick to name some of the traders -- Mohammed Rafiq, Khalil, Jasim Uddin, Alamgir, Jamal Uddin, Shahnoor and Nur Mohammed. Jasim was found filling a jar on his yard and admitted of his involvement. Shahnoor, Jasim's neighbour, said, “You can find nearly 100 others involved in this business. If the business is illegal then Chittagong Wasa would have taken action against us.” Accusing Chittagong Wasa officials of taking bribes to remain silent on the issue, the locals said to have made several complaints to a metre reader of Chittagong Wasa, Md Kamal Khan, with no result. Admitting that he had received the complaints, Kamal claimed that he had not found the traders “red handed”. The locals said if Chittagong Wasa and other authorities concerned do not take steps immediately, more people would be encouraged into the illicit business and cause a huge amount of revenue loss. Chittagong Wasa charges Tk 6.57 per 1,000 litres of water from domestic consumers while the rate is Tk 18.62 for commercial consumers. Running a water supply business requires traders to have, among others, a license from Chittagong City Corporation, a commercial connection from Chittagong Wasa, and approvals from Bangladesh Standards and Testing Institution, Department of Public Health Engineering and the district civil surgeon. None of the traders have the aforementioned. Chittagong Wasa Chief Revenue Officer Khaled Mahmud said, “We do not allow anyone to sell Wasa water until they have commercial connections, water plants and the approvals required.” He said mobile courts would be conducted in the areas once every week.

title: 10 killed, 37 injured in road accidents
body: At least ten people were killed and 37 others injured in separate road accidents in Mymensingh and Gaibandha yesterday and the day before. Of them, six people were killed and 30 injured in truck-jeep collision in Mymensingh and four people were killed and seven injured in two separate road accidents in Gaibandha. Our Correspondent from Mymensingh reports: Six people were killed and 30 others injured, 11 of them seriously, in a road accident at Dhigharkanda under sadar thana on Dhaka-Mymensingh Highway yesterday. Police and witnesses said, the accident occurred when a Dhaka-bound truck with day labourers on board collided head-on with a Mymensingh-bound jeep belonging to CARE at Dhigharkanda at about 11:30 am. The driver of the truck lost control over the vehicle and fell into a roadside ditch killing six people on the spot and injuring 30 others. Of the dead, five were identified as Saidul, 14, Emdadul, 13, Shajahan, 15, Saiful, 25, and Ashadul, 25. The other person could not be identified till filing of this report. The injured were admitted to Mymensingh Medical College Hospital. UNB adds: Four people were killed and seven others injured in two separate road accidents in Gabindaganj thana of Gaibandha district on Wednesday. Police said a Rangpur-bound microbus hit a rickshaw van at about 8.00 pm on Dhaka-Rangpur highway killing three people on the spot and injuring seven others. The deceased were identified as Rezaul, 30, Anwarul, 35, and Safiqul 25. The injured were admitted to Gabindaganj Thana Health Complex and Rangpur Medical College Hospital. All the victims were travelling in the rickshaw van. Local people put barricade on the Dhaka-Rangpur highway and damaged several vehicles following the accident. However, police removed barricade and brought the situation under control. In another accident, Afsar Ali, 35, a gram police, was killed when he fell down from a speeding baby taxi at Bottola in Gabindaganj thana the same day. Two separate cases have been filed with Gabindaganj thana in these connection.

title: Health chiefs caught stealing Tk 20 cr
body: The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Health Ministry has detected massive corruption in procurement by six civil surgeons who are alleged to have misappropriated over Tk 20 crore in the last financial year. They were in charge of buying medical equipment, furniture and fittings for Sadar hospitals and thana health complexes. Price of a 25-taka 60-watt ordinary bulb was shown at Tk 1852, a 400-taka steel tray at Tk 17,000, a 3,000-taka steel rack at Tk 24,000 and that of a two-taka blood testing slide at Tk 13. These are some of the examples of glaring irregularities done in the purchase of equipment for hospitals in Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha, Naogaon, Chapainawabganj and Munshiganj districts, according to a committee report. In some cases, equipment and furniture were purchased without any requisition from the thana health complexes concerned and vouchers did not tally with work orders in some others. The report said that the civil surgeons of the six districts gave the work orders, and that the irregularities were done by them in connivance with the suppliers and some officials of the ministries of heath and finance. Most surprisingly, funds were released from the finance ministry without delay. In many cases, funds were disbursed on the day bills were submitted. A deputy secretary and a senior assistant secretary of the health ministry and an assistant secretary of the finance ministry were involved in the irregularities and the officials did not inform their higher authorities about disbursement of the funds, the report said. The report was prepared after five months' investigation by a sub-committee headed by Tajul Islam. The report was submitted to the Chairman of the Standing Committee Dr. Kazi Abu Yusuf last week and its findings were the main topic of discussion at its Wednesday's meeting, sources said. The Committee recommended that the persons involved be suspended immediately, misappropriated funds refunded and inquiry started by the Anti-corruption Bureau and the health ministry. Investigation against eight more civil surgeons on purchase of hospital equipment are going on now, the sources said. The report also said that such irregularities had been going on at least for the last 15 years but could not be detected despite repeated allegations because earlier reports by parliamentary standing committees were often found "biased" as those were headed by the health minister. Among the six, Naogaon district civil surgeon allegedly misappropriated the highest amount of Tk 7.56 crore, according to the report. The funds, as shown by the civil surgeon's office, were used for purchasing new furniture, wall painting and repair work. In one lot, price of a 400-taka steel tray was shown at Tk 17,000 in the voucher and the contractor was Messrs Prema Enterprise of Rajshahi, the report revealed. The security money deposited was only Tk 10,000 whereas as per rules at least five per cent of the contract value is to be deposited as security money. The report also mentioned that the civil surgeon, after spending the amount, had asked for an extra MSR (Medical and Surgical Requisition) allocation of Tk 7 crore. It was however, refused later on. For Lalmornirhat district, the extra amount allocated was Tk 4.19 crore. The contractor who supplied the items was Taslim Uddin of Shehab Bazar, Rajshahi. The contractor had supplied 4 -inch leucoplast medicated dressing to the Civil Surgeon's office at the rate of Tk 480 each whereas its retail price in the market is only Tk 35. A saucepan was shown to have cost Tk 7,400, which normally costs not more than Tk 400. In Gaibandha, steel racks worth Tk 3,000 each were purchased at the rate of Tk 24,000, 80-taka buckets at Tk 450 and 25-taka 60-watt ordinary bulbs at the rate of Tk 1852 each. The civil surgeon of Kurigram spent an extra amount Tk 1.2 crore. In Munshiganj, the extra amount for MSR was Tk 3.74 crore. Four lakh pieces of blood testing slides were bought at the rate of Tk 13 each against the price of only Tk 2 and 30,000 pieces of hand gloves at the rate of Tk 140 each against the market price of Tk 15 only. The contractor was Tofazzal Hossain of Rajshahi. The names of the civil surgeons are Dr Shamsuddin Ahmed of Kurigram, Dr Abdus Samad and former civil surgeon Sheikh Abdul Jalil of Lalmonirhat, Dr MD Shahidullah of Gaibanda, Dr Abdullah Hashemi of Naogaon, Dr Binod Bihari Shaha of Chapai Nawabganj and Dr Azizur Rahman of Munshiganj.

title: UN arms inspectors give mixed verdict on Iraq
body: UN inspectors on Thursday gave a mixed interim report on Iraq's arms programs, providing ammunition both to those backing US preparations for a possible conflict and for the anti-war camp. Chief weapons inspector Hans Blix said his teams had so far found no "smoking gun" but added Iraq had failed to answer many questions about its armaments. Baghdad said it would do so. Washington appeared unimpressed with Blix's double-edged comments. "The problem with guns that are hidden is you can't see their smoke," a White House spokesman told reporters. "We know for a fact that there are weapons there." Blix's remarks, made to reporters as he prepared to brief members of the UN Security Council, were interpreted by the markets as making war more likely, and oil prices quickly rose. In the nearly seven weeks since inspections resumed in Iraq, he said, "we have been covering the country in ever-wider sweeps, and we haven't found any smoking guns." But Blix, head of chemical, biological and ballistic arms inspections, said he was dissatisfied with the 12,000-page document Iraq submitted in December after the UN Security Council demanded it give a full account of its arms programs. "We think that the declaration failed to answer a great many questions," Blix said." He said it was up to Iraq to show it did not have banned weapons, not for his staff to prove it did. "Iraq cannot just maintain that it must be deemed to be without proscribed items as long as there is no evidence to the contrary," he said. AP adds: Weapons inspectors have delivered a tough message to Iraq: Opening doors and submitting old declarations isn't enough to satisfy the United Nations, and Baghdad must prove that its arms programs have been destroyed. Chief inspector Hans Blix and Mohamed ElBaradei, who is in charge of nuclear inspections, told the UN Security Council on Thursday they have found no "smoking gun" since UN inspections resumed on Nov. 27 - but that doesn't mean there isn't one. The top inspectors plan to fly to Baghdad on Jan. 19-20 to tell senior officials they must provide "credible evidence" about Iraq's nuclear, chemical, biological and missile programs; beef up the list of scientists Iraq handed over in late December; and answer a host of questions on outstanding issues ranging from anthrax production to missing high explosives.

title: Forex reserves cross $25b
body: Bangladesh's foreign currency reserves crossed $25 billion yesterday, setting a new record. The reserve of $25.02 billion is enough to meet the country's import bills for more than seven months, Kazi Sayedur Rahman, general manager of the forex reserve and treasury management department of Bangladesh Bank, told The Daily Star. The reserves first crossed the $23-billion mark on February 26 and $24 billion on April 29 this year. The central bank attributed this large reserve sum to export earnings, remittance, foreign direct investment and the private sector's foreign-sourced loans. Declining import bills for food grains and petroleum oils also played an important role in fuelling the reserve, according to a statement by the central bank. Exports grew only 2.8 percent to $28.14 billion and remittances 7.21 percent to $13.87 billion in July-May of the outgoing fiscal year, compared to the same period in the previous year, according to data from the central bank. On the other hand, imports (freight on board-basis) increased more than 12 percent to $33.46 billion during the first 10 months of the fiscal year till April. According to analysts, the private sector's increasing dependence on loans from foreign sources has had a major role in the country's forex reserves figure every month. Government data shows that the private sector took $4.89 billion in loans from abroad in 2014, up from $4.06 billion and $1.79 billion in 2013 and 2012 respectively. The growing reserves of foreign currency have helped the central bank maintain a stable exchange rate over the last couple of years and provided a more favourable economic environment. However, fluctuations in the exchange markets can result in gains and losses in the purchasing power of reserves. For example, Bangladesh holds a majority of its reserves in US dollar-denominated assets, and if the dollar weakens, it will result in a relative loss of wealth.

title: 4 killed in Comilla road crash
body: Four passengers of a bus were killed and 11 injured as the vehicle fell into a roadside ditch after hitting a truck stationed on Dhaka-Chittagong highway in Chauddagram upazila of Comilla last evening. Two of deceased were identified as Ansar Fakir Russel, 40, of Morrelganj upazila, and Sujon, 27, of Sadar upazila, of Bagerhat while the identities of the other dead victims could not be known immediately, reports a correspondent from Comilla. The bus of Baneshwar Paribahan hit the stationed truck at Miabazar around 7:30pm after and fell into the ditch, leaving 15 passengers injured, said Nijam Uddin, in-charge of Nayabazar Highway Police Outpost. Among the injured, Russel and Sujon succumbed to their injuries one hour at Chauddagram Upazila Health Complex while the rest at Comilla Medical College and Hospital. The accident took place when the bus was heading for Pirojpur from Chittagong.

title: Salma Kaniz's solo painting exhibition opens tomorrow
body: The 1st solo painting exhibition of Salma Kaniz Ahmed will be inaugurated at Zainul Gallery of Institute of Fine Arts tomorrow at 10:30 am. Abdur Razzak, Minister of Water Resources will inaugurate the show as Chief Guest while Prof Bulbon Osman will be present as special guest. Prof Mahmudul Haque, Director of the Institute of Fine Arts, will preside over the ceremony. Some 22 pieces of art by the artist, resident in Ohio USA, will be exhibited at the show which will remain open from 2:00 pm to 8:00 pm daily until January 19.

title: Cannes waves flag for US auteur films by giving top prize to "Elephant"
body: France's love-hate relationship with US cinema remained intact Monday after the Cannes movie festival bestowed its Palme d'Or on an auteur film by US director Gus Van Sant that confronts America's problem with violence. "Elephant", a documentary-style movie about a school massacre that strongly resembled the real-life 1999 Columbine high school shootings, took the coveted award at the closing ceremony in this French Riviera town Sunday. In doing so, it elbowed past 19 other contenders, including "Dogville", the latest production by Cannes' favourite son, the Danish director Lars von Trier, which almost all critics had expected to win. Van Sant, who is best-known for "Good Will Hunting", "Drugstore Cowboy" and "My Own Private Idaho", also picked up the Best Director prize -- an unusual double honour from the nine-person Cannes jury that this year included US director Steven Soderbergh and actress Meg Ryan. "To win is kind of miraculous and fortunate and lucky," Van Sant told a media conference after receiving the awards. He was the first American to win the prestigious Palme since Quentin Tarantino took it for "Pulp Fiction" in 1994. His film, made for a US cable network on a meagre three-million-dollar (2.5 million euro) budget with a mostly non-professional cast of real students in a school in the American west, was not meant as a criticism of America but more "a musing about school violence," he said. The title came from a highly acclaimed 1989 BBC documentary about Northern Ireland. Diversity is one of Cannes' signature themes, however, and that was reinforced with the award of the runner-up Grand Prize to "Distant", a Turkish film by Nuri Bilge Ceylan that explores the emptiness of life and loneliness in the city. A French-language Canadian film, "The Barbarian Invasions", that was probably the most popular entry seen in the week and a half long festival, earned a Best Screenplay award for its writer and director, Denys Arcand. It also took the Best Actress prize for Marie-Josee Croze, who played a heroin junky helping a dying man cope with his pain. Overlooked was the Clint Eastwood-directed "Mystic River", a psychological thriller that used its all-star cast of Sean Penn, Kevin Bacon and Tim Robbins to good effect. For many of the 30,000 industry types and journalists accredited to the event, and for the tens of thousands more movie fans who flocked to the Riviera for a glimpse of celebrities, the real high point came early on, with the out-of-competition premiere of "The Matrix Reloaded" in the presence of Keanu Reeves and its other stars. Little else lived up to Cannes' reputation for over-the-top cinematic hype except for Arnold Schwarzenegger's shameless plugging of his upcoming and as-yet unseen "Terminator 3: The Rise of the Machines" in a seaside publicity show and exclusive party. Many of the official screenings seemed to be grim celebrations of death. The little humour to be found was in "The Barbarian Invasions" or in non-competing fare such as the wryly polished French animation "Belleville Rendez-Vous", about a Tour de France cyclist kidnapped and taken to a pastiche Manhattan to race for sinister Mafia types.

title: 'You only prove to yourself'
body: Sri Lanka batsman Kumar Sangakkara plays the ball towards point during his century on the first day of the first Test against Bangladesh at the Galle International Cricket Stadium yesterday.Story on page 16. PHOTO: AFP It's always a pleasant experience to hear a player like Kumar Sangakkara speak. One of Sri Lanka's biggest sports personalities spoke like his bat's gentle touch after the first day's play at the Galle Test against Bangladesh where he made a splendid hundred. The following is an excerpt from the freewheeling encounter with reporters at the press briefing room of the Galle International Cricket Stadium yesterday. Question (Q): How satisfying it is to back to runs after the injury lay-off? Sangakkara (S): Very satisfying. Going into this match I had only batted three or four days and I had worked really hard on those sessions. I really wanted to get off the first ball and I was lucky that it was short and wide. That really gives you lot of confidence and after that it was a case of getting my rhythm back. Q: How difficult is it after Matara episode? S: You get used to this kind of things (as he was called back from Matara following the crisis between the players and the board). You have to be a bigger person and you need to get your preparation right. Such is life and my job is to get ready for the Test Match and that was what I was concentrating on. Q: Say something about the hundred? S: My idea was that the bowlers were tired and I wanted to get past 300. If we are able to pass 300 on day one that makes it easy to make a declaration after a session or so in the second day. Lahiru Thirimanne was batting really well and my job was to try and accelerate and score runs quicker so that the team will be in a good position. 361 is a good score and it gives us a position to bat first one session and then Angelo can decide when he wants to declare. Q: How does it feel to pass Sunny Gavaskar? S: He was a fantastic batsman. I am very privileged to have had a career where I am able to go past him. Still I am two centuries (actually three) behind him. Hopefully I can go beyond him on that count too. Q: See any improvement in Bangladesh bowling? S: They have had bowlers who have come and gone. Unfortunately most of their bowlers haven't had a consistent run in the national side. Mashrafe Mortaza I think was their best bowler. He can swing the ball and I have found him difficult to play. They have always had spinners, who bowl well but unfortunately their best spinner Shakib is not here. But still they have been that unpredictable side. The fast bowler Abul Hasan was very quick. He has got something in him. But over the years, bowling has been inconsistent. But I am sure they have lot of depth and they will be looking for consistency as they go along. Q: How do you feel about missing yet another double hundred? S: It was disappointing. But If I had got to 160 or 170 and had the team been past 300 then I would have blocked, but it wasn't to be and that's the way it goes. Q: There is talk about Sri Lankan's greatest batsman being between you, Mahela and Aravinda de Silva, how do you look at this matter? S: I would go with Aravinda an Mahela. There's Anura Tennekoon and Roy Dias as well. If you ask Sir Viv Richards, he always says, 'Tennekoon, Dias, de Silva' 'Tennekoon, Dias, de Silva'. When Sir Viv says you listen. He knows what he is talking about. I don't put myself in that category. I have scored lot of runs, but they made batting look a lot easier than I do. Q: Is there anything to prove after contract issue? S: It's never about proving anything. The only person you prove is yourself. Q: How does it feel to get equal with Mahela's hundreds? S: It's a great privilege. Getting runs and scoring more hundreds – sometimes you can say there is a selfish element, but if you keep doing that, you benefit and your side benefits as well. Q: What is the secret behind your great success? S: There's no secret. It's just working hard. When I made my debut I thought I was very lucky, But then I realised it was about doing as much work as you can the right way. I've been lucky to have a long career. It's just that really. Q: Next goal? S: More centuries, more runs and more wins. I think that's what motivates all the guys who play.

title: HC asks govt not to arrest Salahuddin Quader & his brother
body: The High Court yesterday asked the government not to arrest Salahuddin Kader Chowdhury and Giasuddin Kader Chowdhury in the cases in which they were earlier granted anticipatory bail by the court, reports UNB. The court also gave opportunity to the government to file counter reply by tomorrow against the allegation made by the two BNP lawmakers in two separate petitions with a prayer for direction not to arrest them. The matter will come up for hearing on Thursday next. Barrister Rafique-ul-Hoq with Barrister Moudud Ahmed appeared for the petitioners before the High Court division comprising Justice Mozammel Hoque and Justice Awlad Ali. They submitted to the court that they only prayed for an order that the petitioners cannot be arrested in the cases where they have been granted bail by the High Court on December 3 last, nor can be arrested under Special Powers Act or under any preventive detention of law before and after the parliamentary sessions called from January 14. In reply, Attorney General Barrister K S Nabi submitted before the court that there is no attempt of arresting the petitioners in the cases where they have been granted bail by the High Court.

title: S Korea's defence nominee resigns
body: In a fresh blow to South Korea's new president, Park Geun-Hye, her nominee for defence minister stepped down yesterday at a time of elevated military tensions with North Korea. Ever since his nomination, Kim Byung-Kwan, a retired four-star general, has been dogged by allegations of wrongdoing related to his recent stint working as a broker for an arms trading firm. Park accepted Kim's decision and asked the incumbent defence minister to extend his term, citing public anxiety over North Korea, her spokeswoman said.

title: Shahbagh defies hartal
body: People from all walks of life defied the 18-party alliance's hartal yesterday and flocked to the Shahbagh intersection to express their support for the six-point demand of the Shahbagh protesters. The protesters continued their movement for 42nd day yesterday, and sang songs of rebellion, recited poems and screened documentaries from a stage near public library. Many cultural organisations, such as Bangladesh Udichi Shilpi Gosthi, Slogan 71 and Teerandaj, have been performing on the stage since March 4. "As many as 10 lakh signatures have been collected from Shahbagh alone, while many people have taken the petition for capital punishment for all war criminals to different parts of the country promising to return the forms with signatures from their locality" said Maruf Rosul, a key organiser of the movement. The petition signing started on February 22 and was scheduled to end on March 7. It was later extended till March 22.

title: Projonmo '71 may split
body: Projonmo '71, an organisation of children of martyrs of the Liberation War, is heading towards a formal split over formation of a new central executive committee. There are two groups in the organisation, one led by its former president Saidur Rahman and the other by former general secretary Tawhid Reza Nur. The two groups have been organising separate programmes on different occasions for some time now. A central executive committee of the organisation was formed when it was floated on October 29, 1991. The tenure of the committee expired after two years but no new committee was formed. The group led by Saidur Rahman at a press conference at the Jatiya Press Club yesterday announced a 25-member central committee with Anwarul Kabir Milu and Hedayet Hossain as president and general secretary. The new committee was rejected by the other group calling it "unconstitutional and illegal". Saidur Rahman claimed at the press conference that formation of a new committee become urgent as some office-bearers of the former committee, including general secretary Tawhid Reza Nur had made the organisation inactive by not doing any organisational activities. Saidur also alleged that leaders of the other group had met the Prime Minister without taking any opinion from the then president and majority of the office-bearers of the organisation. Nur, leader of the other group in a statement yesterday alleged that the new committee was formed secretly, ignoring the opinion of the majority and violating the constitution of the organisation. The statement was signed by six office-bearers of the former committee. Nur alleged that leaders of the other group remained inactive due to differences on principles and had been using the organisation for petty personal interest. Nur claimed that they organised Muktijuddaha Mela and Bijoy Mela, observed the death anniversary of Jahanara Imam, donated money to the Prime Minister's Relief Fund and met the Prime Minister after taking opinion from majority of the office-bearers. Under this circumstances, the committee declared yesterday is "illegal" and majority members of the Projonmo '71 can not accept it, he said in the statement. The statement was also signed by former vice- president Rabiul Aftab, joint secretaries Ashif Munir and Salma Nargis, publication secretary Farzana Chowdhury Nipa and publicity secretary Babul Chowdhury Dey. At the press conference Saidur also put forward some demands including formation of a Shaheed Family Welfare Trust, housing facility for the families of martyrs, for welfare of the children of the martyrs. The demands include housing facilities for, setting up of separate liberation war based museum both centrally and locally, preparation of a definite list of the martyrs of 1971 and invitation of martyrs families in all state functions, formation of a Shaheed Family Welfare Trust and observance of national mourning day in honour of the 3 millions martyrs of the war of independence. He was reiterated the organisation's demand immediate trial of all war criminals in a special tribunal

title: ROK keen to invest more in EPZs
body: South Korea is keen to invest more in the Export Processing Zones in Bangladesh. This was disclosed by the South Korean Ambassador in Bangladesh K H Lee while inaugurating a South Korean industry, D&S Mode (BD) Ltd in the Comilla Export Processing Zone on Saturday, says a press release. D&S Mode, the first industry in Comilla EPZ, will produce sweater and acrylic yarn. The South Korean envoy said his country wants to be the partner of progress in Bangladesh. With this end in view, the South Koreans are coming in a big way to invest in the EPZs. The Koreans, he said, are interested to invest in the medium and small scale industrial units in the Bangladesh Export Processing Zones. Referring to the under-construction Korean EPZ in Chittagong, Lee said, with the commissioning of this zone, the South Koreans will come in a massive way, because the Koreans like to live and invest in a clustered way.

title: JSD (Rab) calls 48-hr hartal in Ramgati
body: NOAKHALI, Jan 16: JSD (Rab) has called for a 48-hour hartal in Ramgati thana from 6 am tomorrow demanding immediate release of its workers, reports UNB. Police in a midnight drive on November 11, arrested 25 activists, including Chargazi UP chairman Mir Akhtar Hossin Bachhu, along with 300 arms and ammunition. They were arrested while preparing for taking possession of a char, police said. Local JSD leaders said they were implicated in a 'false case'. Their leader ASM Abdur Rab is a member of the cabinet holding the charge of the ministry of Fisheries and Livestock.

title: Rapid disposal of pending cases directed
body: Inspector General of Police (IGP) M Ismail Hossain yesterday asked the police officials to behave soberly when people come to police stations, reports UNB. He also directed the DMP officials to take necessary steps for rapid disposal of the pending cases, warrants and conviction warrants. The IGP was addressing a meeting with senior police officials of the Dhaka Metropolitan Police to review the law and order situation of the city. He also gave directives to take appropriate action to prevent snatching and pick-pocketing on the city streets and at market places during the month of Ramadan.
