The IGP instructed the DMP officials to deploy additional forces to ease traffic congestion in the capital, particularly at the places where the problem is more acute. Stressing the need for strengthening community policing and greater involvement of local people, he directed the police officials to take more effective steps to combat crimes. Additional IGPs of Finance, Headquarters, Special Branch and CID, DIG Headquarters, all Deputy Commissioners, Assistance Commissioners and Officers in Charge of different police stations of DMP were present at the meeting. The DCs, ACs and OCs informed the IGP about the law and order situation in their respective areas and the residential and transport problems of the police stations, according to a PID handout.

title: No lazybones in Tigers’ dressing room
body: Bangladesh cricket team’s strength and conditioning coach Mario Villavarayan dismisses the notion that the players are indolent when it comes to fitness and appreciates their commitment to look after themselves, especially when he is not around. When Mario became a part of the coaching staff last year, he was under the impression that the Bangladeshi cricketers were lazy and not too keen on fitness. In a matter of months, Tigers’ strength and conditioning coach found out how committed the players were even in the most taxing of circumstances. "When I was coming here I was given this impression that guys are not that keen on fitness. The biggest thing that hit me was that last year in July during Ramadan, we were doing running sessions at 3.30 pm in the afternoon.” Mario Villavarayan said. "These boys were fasting but they were running and pushing themselves. Those first few weeks proved I was given a wrong impression about the boys. From that point they have gone on well," he added. Although some of the players have suffered injuries, the bigger picture is still bright for Bangladesh says Mario. It takes time for the fitness levels of cricketers to improve markedly, and that also depends heavily on what they do when out of Mario’s supervision. The professionalism shown by Bangladeshi cricketers in this regard has impressed the strength and conditioning coach during his tenure. "I look after them here. When they go home, they have to look after themselves. That is what I have seen improved. They get into good habits and they are doing it at home. It is the main thing. This is the professionalism coming in,” Mario explained. “If they are not going to do it when I am not around, they are not going to help themselves," he said. Mario now has to look after the Bangladesh players as the grueling season continues with South Africa due to play 2 T20Is, 3 ODIs and 2 Test matches in July. The post-World Cup phase included the BCL one-day tournament, Pakistan’s tour and the India series in quick succession. Fortunately for Tigers, Mario believes the players are well prepared for the workload being fitter than before.

title: Chauhan, Dharmasena chuck?
body: NEW DELHI, Jan 3: Off-spinners Rajesh Chauhan of India and Kumara Dharmasena of Sri Lanka can't play international cricket until they rectified their suspect bowling actions, a top official of the International Cricket Council said Saturday, reports AP. The ICC technical committee recently watched the video footage of their bowling actions and ruled that Chauhan and Dharmasena threw the ball, Press Trust of India news agency quoted ICC chief Jagmohan Dalmiya as saying. The ICC acted on a complaint by Bob Simpson of Australia who was the match referee for the recent three-Test series between India and Sri Lanka. The ICC will provide a specialist to help Chauhan and Dharmasena correct their bowling actions and resume playing for their countries, Dalmiya said. Dharmasena is the second Sri Lankan player to be involved in such a controversy. In 1996, Sri Lanka's off-spinner Muthiah Muralitharan was no-balled several times by an Australian umpire for suspect bowling action. But he was later cleared to play international cricket. Cricket selectors on Saturday dropped a spin bowler from the Indian cricket team because of his faulty bowling action, Press Trust of India news agency said. The decision followed a ruling by the technical committee of the International Cricket Council that off-spinner Rajesh Chauhan threw the ball, said J Y Lele, secretary of Indian cricket control board. ICC had communicated the finding of its sub-committee to BCCI and the selectors, on the basis of that letter, omitted Chauhan from the 14-man squad for the January 10-18 Bangladesh silver jubilee independence cup tournament as they did not want the bowler to be no-balled there for his action, Lele said. Lele said the ICC match referee for the India-Sri Lanka Test series, Australia's Bob Simpson, had reported to the world body about his and several umpires' concern over the legitimacy of the bowling action of Chauhan. The ICC letter would have gone everywhere and Chauhan could have been called by an umpire at Dhaka, Lele said while adding that BCCI would support the bowler in correcting his action.

title: Rangpur Div I cricket
body: After a gap of five years the Rangpur Premier Division Cricket League was inaugurated at the city's Cricket Garden yesterday morning. Shorfuddin Ahmed Jhauntu, mayor of Rangpur City Corporation (RCC) was the chief guest of the event. In the league's first match, Oikko Sommeloni Krira Chakra (OSKC) beat Pouro Protirokkha Club (PPC) by nine wickets. Batting first PPC were bundled out for just 115 in 45 overs. OSKC chased the target comfortably in 31.3 overs. OSKC's Pappu top-scored with 62. Ten teams are participating in the tournament.

title: Former President Biswas says
body: Former President Abdur Rahman Biswas yesterday said that during his presidency, his speeches in the Parliament were endorsed by the Prime Minister and her office. Talking to UNB in the wake of a controversy kicked up by the opposition over the issue, he said, his presidential speeches used to contain two parts - objective and subjective. The objective part, mainly containing accounts of various development programmes and achievements of the government, was prepared by different ministries, while the subjective one, on matters like one Liberation War, contribution of national leaders to democracy and independence, was drafted by the President's Office. "However, finally the entire speech of the President used to be seen and cleared by the Prime Minister and her office," said Biswas, who was president from 1991-96 and was elected as a BNP nominee. The former president said he found nothing wrong in the cabinet, headed by the Prime Minister, endorsing the draft speech. Biswas, however, said that any additions or omissions from the draft speech were done on the basis of understanding between the head of state and the head of government. Biswas declined to make any comment on the opposition boycott of his successor's speech, delivered in Parliament yesterday, on objection that it was endorsed by the cabinet eulogising the government's programmes and performances. Praising President Shahabuddin Ahmed as a neutral and respected man, Biswas said Shahabuddin was accepted by all. "Even BNP gladly accepted him although he was nominated by Awami League." Asked to comment on whether a president could make his personal comments aside the scripted address to the Parliament, Biswas said as a matter of fact the President has nothing to say in addition to the prepared speech cleared by the Prime Minister and the cabinet. As per the present Constitution, the President is to act on advice of the Prime Minister, excepting imitating the leader of the majority party in forming government and giving appointment to the Chief Justice and to other constitutional posts. Biswas, however, recalled that while addressing the first session of the 6th Parliament, elected through a controversial election on February 15, 1996, as President he made certain comments which were little critical of BNP. And those comments earned protests from the BNP government as well. "BNP had raised objection to certain parts of that speech, but I insisted that those points should be there," said the former President. About the opposition boycott of municipal elections, Biswas refrained from making comment since he is no longer in active politics. "It is difficult on my part to comment since I was associated with a political party," Biswas said on the opposition boycott of President Shahabuddin Ahmed's speech in the first Parliament session of this year. He, however, suggested that both the ruling and opposition parties should close the gap and settle all differences through discussion. "Otherwise, parliamentary democracy would fail," he forewarned. "I love to call a spade a spade. Had I been in active politics, I would have suggested that both the government and opposition should thrash out the differences because democracy means discussion and settling all differences." The former President added: "It would not be good to push the country towards a stalemate."

title: Pak army takes control of nuclear-capable missile
body: Pakistan's army has taken possession of a nuclear-capable ballistic missile, a spokesman said Thursday, a first in the history of the country's nuclear program. The intermediate-range surface-to-surface Hatf-V missile, known as Ghauri, was presented to President Pervez Musharraf in his capacity as army chief during a formal ceremony at a nuclear research plant on the outskirts of Islamabad on Wednesday. General Musharraf said it was "a proud day for him to be accepting the Ghauri system on behalf of the Army's Strategic Force Command," military spokesman Major General Rashid Qureshi quoted him as saying. The Ghauri's induction into the army "would radiate the necessary effects of deterrence," Musharraf said. With a range of up to 1,500 kilometers (930 miles), the missile is capable of carrying a nuclear warhead deep into Indian territory. It was handed over by the directors of A.Q. Khan Research Laboratory (KRL), named after Abdul Qadeer Khan, the scientist who developed Pakistan's first nuclear weapon. "It is the first time a nuclear-capable ballistic missile has been inducted into the army," political observer Mohammad Afzal Niazi told AFP. The Ghauri was first tested in April 1998, one month before Pakistan and India conducted tit-for-tat underground nuclear tests. It was test-fired again in April 1999 and as tensions between Pakistan and India peaked in May last year. The missile is named after a Muslim warrior who defeated Indian ruler Prithvi Chauhan in the late 12th century. The induction ceremony, closed to the media, was attended by top generals, nuclear scientists and engineers. The Ghauri, painted in camouflage khaki and grey colours, was wheeled out of a workshop mounted on a truck and driven past Musharraf and other top brass, military-issued photographs showed. The KRL laboratory is involved in enrichment of weapons-grade uranium, used to build nuclear weapons, and missile development. The Dawn newspaper on Wednesday reported that US officials believe Khan initiated contact with North Korea in 1992 to obtain a dozen medium-range Nodong ballistic missiles. Observers say the Ghauri is based on the Nodong.

title: Boy stabbed in Bogra
body: An SSC examinee was stabbed by another boy at Goshaibari High School under Dhunat upazila on Tuesday afternoon. The deceased was Abu Sun, 16, son of Shahidul Islam of Paikartoli village under Shariakandi upazila. Locals said Abu was stabbed over a trifling matter when he went to enjoy a cultural function at the school. The accused was Shohag, 16, son of Tota Mia of Chithulia village under Dhunat upazila. He went into hiding after the incident.

title: Israeli army dynamites Palestinian home
body: The Israeli army dynamited Friday the house of a Palestinian woman who was killed last February in a suicide attack against a military checkpoint near the West Bank city of Nablus, Palestinian witnesses said. Troops blew up the house of Darin Abu Aysheh in the village of Beit Wazan after evacuating seven members of her family, the witnesses said. After her February 27 attack she left a videotape saying she carried out her operation for the Al-Aqsa Martyrs Brigades, an offshoot of Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement. She was a 21-year-old student from Nablus' Al-Najah University. The Israeli army has destroyed more than 120 houses in the West Bank since August, when it launched its policy of demolitions. The army says it is a deterrent to anti-Israeli attacks, while rights groups say it amounts to "collective punishment." In another pre-dawn operation Friday, Israeli troops arrested three Palestinians suspected of involvement in anti-Israeli attacks, two near the southern city of Hebron and one in the northern Jenin area, the army said. Meanwhile, the Israeli army closed three Israeli-Palestinian security liaison offices in the northern West Bank, on the grounds they no longer serve any purpose, the two sides said. The military on Thursday ordered Palestinian police to leave the offices in Tulkarem, Qalqiliya and Nablus and confiscated their arms, Palestinian security sources said. An army spokesman confirmed the closures saying "the presence of armed Palestinian policemen had become a liability for Israel."

title: Teacher 'tortured to death'
body: A schoolteacher was tortured to death allegedly by her husband at Mongtu Karbaripara under Matiranga upazila of the district on Saturday evening. The victim, Krayori Marma, 40, wife of Labrachi Marma, was the headmaster of Harun Headmanpara Government Primary School in the upazila. Police quoted neighbours and family members as saying that Labrachi, a driver of UNDP Matiranga office, picked up a quarrel with Krayori on Friday night as she protested his extra-marital affair. At one stage, Labrachi beat up Krayori, leaving her critically injured, they added. She was taken to Matiranga Upazila Health Complex Saturday morning, but the doctors of the hospital referred her to Chittagong Medical College Hospital (CMCH) as her condition was critical. She died at around 7:00pm. Residential Medical Officer of Matiranga Upazila Health Complex Dr Sabyasachi Nath told this correspondent that Krayori sustained serious injuries in her lower stomach. Labrachi fled CMCH soon after Krayori's death and his mobile phone was switched off yesterday. Contacted, OC Yousuf Mia of Matiranga Police Station said they will take legal action after getting the autopsy report.

title: Pakistan urges Egypt to help end Syria violence
body: Egyptian President Mohamed Morsi is conferred honorary doctor of philosophy by Pakistan's Prime Minister Raja Pervez Ashraf during his visit to the National University of Science and Technology in Islamabad yesterday. Morsi arrived in Pakistan on a South Asian tour that will also take him to India as he works to promote trade and investment in his nation's troubled economy. Photo: AFP Pakistani President Asif Ali Zardari yesterday urged his Egyptian counterpart Mohamed Morsi to help efforts to end the "bloodshed" in Syria and find a solution to the crisis. Zardari made the remarks during talks with Morsi who arrived in Pakistan as part of a South Asian tour that will also take him to India as he works to promote trade and investment in Egypt's troubled economy. Morsi's one-day trip to Pakistan is the first bilateral visit by an Egyptian leader since Gamal Abdel Nasser in the 1960s, Pakistan's foreign ministry said. Zardari "urged for working together to end the bloodshed in Syria and to find a peaceful solution to the crisis," presidential spokesman Farhatullah Babar said in a statement after the talks. Zardari also stressed that "the drive for peace in Syria must be led and owned by the Syrian people and offered Pakistan's readiness to play its role," Babar said. The conflict in Syria has killed about 70,000 people and forced millions from their homes according to UN figures. Pakistani state television showed live footage of a ceremony at the presidential palace in Islamabad where Morsi was greeted with a military guard of honour.

title: President, PM greet Myanmar leader
body: President Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed and Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina have greeted General Than Shwe, the Chairman of the State Peace and Development Council of Myanmar, on the occasion of his country's Independence Day, reports UNB. In his message, President Shahabuddin expressed the confidence that the existing friendly relations between the two neighbouring countries would further be strengthened in the years to come. He wished him good health and happiness, and continued progress and prosperity of the friendly people of Myanmar. Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina in her message hoped that the close bonds of friendship, mutual understanding and fruitful cooperation between the two neighbouring countries would acquire greater depth and dimension in the year ahead.

title: TV, Betar to broadcast Lie
body: Bangladesh Television and Bangladesh Betar will broadcast live the main function of the three-nation business summit reports UNB. The decision was taken at a meeting on media coverage of the summit. Tuesday with Foreign Minister Abdus Samad Azad in the chair.

title: HC says police should test DNA of suspects
body: The High Court yesterday observed that police should get tested the DNA of five detained North South University (NSU) students and the samples of evidence in connection with the murder of blogger Ahmed Rajib Haidar. “Why should the police wait for the DNA test in this case? They must have the DNA profiles of the accused people and the samples of evidences tested for fair investigation and evidential purpose,” it said. The bench of Justice AHM Shamsuddin Choudhury Manik and Justice Mahmudul Hoque came up with the observation on a suo moto move so that law enforcers can be sure whether the five detained NSU students are involved in the murder. Justice Manik said if police wait for DNA test in this sensational case, the process of investigation will be delayed as analysing DNA is a time consuming matter. The judge made the observation in response to a reported statement of Deputy Commissioner of Dhaka Metropolitan Police Mollah Nazrul Islam that they (police) will have the DNA of five detained NSU students tested if necessary. Mollah's statement was published on the daily Prothom Alo yesterday. The court asked Assistant Attorney General Mia Sirajul Islam to convey the observation to the police authorities.

title: Clinton's 'New Age' Diplomacy
body: Moral precepts are absolute and make no allowance for historical evolution. When thwarted, they allow no fall-back. But foreign policy must deal with nuances and processes rather than terminal points. Public relations myths - or worse, self-delusion - cannot serve as a substitute. New Age diplomacy has not abolished the need to strike a balance between a society's ideals and the necessities of its place in the world. The end of the millennium coincides with the moment when America's pre-eminence turned into predominance. Never before has a single country achieved a comparable ascendancy on a global basis and in so many fields of endeavour, from weaponry to entrepreneurship, from technology to popular culture. The American ascendancy finds the United States acting as the bulwark of stability, mediating the key trouble spots and stationing troops around the world in peacekeeping missions that shade into near permanent occupation duties. America dominates the international financial system by providing the most attractive haven for investment capital as well as the largest single pool of it. Yet America's dominance has expressed itself less as a strategic design than as a series of seemingly unrelated decisions taken largely in response to specific crises and driven less by an overarching concept than by responses to domestic pressure groups. It came about in an administration preoccupied with domestic politics, the views of many of whose leading members were shaped by the protests of the early 1970s deprecating the role of power and seeking to replace it with "New Age" issues like the environment and humanitarianism. Ironically - and perhaps because of this ambivalence -- the Clinton Administration has found itself drawn to a more frequent use of military power than any other post-war administration. In the heyday of their pre-eminence, the Roman and British empires managed to transform their power into consensus and their governing principles into widely accepted norms. The United States has not yet achieved such a position. Its decisions shape international events to an unprecedented degree but they have often appeared, especially to non-Americans, as either arbitrary or random responses to domestic constituencies. One result has been to spur groupings of nations at least in part designed to reclaim a greater freedom for regional or national decisions. To some extent, this is an inevitable reaction to our dominant position. Yet, while regional groupings may turn out to be the building blocks of a new international order, it makes a great deal of difference whether they seek their identity in cooperation with America or in opposition to it. The problem goes beyond the biases of the Clinton Administration. A society that has never known a permanent threat has been tempted by the end of the cold war to impose its preferences unilaterally, without calculating the reactions of other peoples or the long-range costs of such a course. A vigorous and highly competitive media has compounded the tendency for foreign policy to become a subdivision of domestic politics. In part as a reaction to this unilateralism, the European Union has emerged from the successful Kosovo war with a determination to forge an independent defence capability, calls for an Asian bloc have multiplied, and even Mercosur in Latin America is veering toward a more confrontational rationale. A dominant power unable to define a general concept fails in its principal potential contribution to world order. Administration diplomacy has been most successful where the challenge was most comparable to domestic politics, as in the Arab-Israeli negotiations. It has not managed to integrate either Russia or China into a workable international order. And it has failed to develop a strategy for the two most fundamental issues of global order: how to deal with rogue states and how to translate our moral values into an operational diplomacy. Iraq has been a test case for America's policy toward rogue states. But we have been in retreat since December 1998. Then British and American planes attacked Iraqi military installations in retaliation to flagrant Iraqi violations of the UN inspections system, imposed by the Bush Administration as the price for permitting Saddam to extricate his army and his rule from defeat in the Gulf war of 1991. Coupled with tough sanctions, the inspections system was supposed to eliminate Saddam's ability to pose a military threat to Iraq's neighbours and to stability in the Gulf. The Clinton Administration codified this into a containment strategy designed, in the words of Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, to "put Saddam in a box." Implemented in the style of the "New Age" diplomacy, it alternated the rhetoric of conciliation with ineffective spasms of military confrontation. For his part, Saddam moved tenaciously to wriggle out of international restraints. In 1996 he moved his army into the Kurdish autonomous zone heretofore, at least tacitly, under American protection. By 1998 he felt strong enough to challenge the UN inspections system frontally. Nevertheless, on Nov. 15, 1998, President Clinton still spoke of giving Saddam an opportunity "to become honourably reconciled by simply observing UN resolutions." Predictably, Saddam accelerated the pursuit of the three objectives that have guided his policy: 1) to shift the world's attention away from Iraq's flouting of UN obligations and to the alleged harm being done by UN sanctions to Iraq's population; 2) to magnify and force into the open the latent disagreements among the permanent members of the Security Council over Iraq, and 3) to involve the Secretary General of the UN as a mediator, thereby placing Saddam's grievances on the same level as his adversaries. President Clinton reacted to Saddam's defiance by ordering airstrikes. But the Administration's ambivalence with respect to the use of power for strategic or political objectives turned that enterprise into a cover for abandoning the inspections system rather than for enforcing it. Unrelated to any specific political demand, such as the restoration of an adequate inspections system, the bombing lasted but three nights (there was no daylight bombing), earning us opprobrium without political benefit. Clearly, these events have left Saddam far closer to his objectives than the United States is to its own goals. The UN inspectors evicted by Saddam have not returned. And UN diplomacy has focused on the removal of sanctions, so that their end, supported by three of the five permanent members of the Security Council - Russia, France and China - or their emasculation seems only a question of time. As a result, the victory of the Gulf war is in danger of unravelling. None of the Gulf states believes in the possibility of reconciliation with Iraq. The Islamic Republic of Iran watches amid its own domestic debate over the relative merits of moderation and intransigence. When Tehran's hard-line leaders see how a defeated neighbour succeeds in defying a multilateral coalition ostensibly headed by the United States, their incentive for moderation will surely diminish. A political vacuum is emerging in which an ambivalent United States will be obliged - without significant allies - to defend the weak Gulf states against the two strongest states in the region - hardly an ideal example for deterring rogue states globally. The strategic and political paralysis in dealing with the rogue challenge in the Gulf has been overshadowed by the most dramatic use of NATO military power since World War II - the 78-day bombing campaign over Kosovo. Nothing could show more clearly the emotional priorities of the Clinton Administration than the fact that it devoted 78 days to destroying the infrastructure of Serbia, a country representing no strategic threat, and only three nights to overcoming Saddam's eviction of the UN inspections system, heretofore considered the key to stability in the vital Gulf. For weeks during and after the Kosovo crisis, both Washington and London trumpeted their humanitarian foreign policy as the progressive alternative to traditional diplomacy based on equilibrium. But life has been far more complicated. Multiethnicity in the Balkans has proved far more difficult than "progressive" exhortations to that effect.Nor has the Kosovo intervention solved the political problem that gave rise to it. NATO occupation of Kosovo is based on a UN resolution that explicitly describes Kosovo as an autonomous part of Yugoslavia (Article 5) and reaffirms the territorial integrity and sovereignty of all of Yugoslavia (Article 8). There is even a provision for a token number of Serb administrators. To underline the UN commitment to a multiethnic state, the KLA (the armed forces of the Albanian resistance) was supposed to be disarmed by NATO. None of these provisions has been implemented or has a prospect of being implemented. The KLA has not been truly disarmed; the opposite of a multiethnic society is coming into being; Yugoslav sovereignty can only be exercised at the price of a bloody Serb intervention. In the name of a humanitarian foreign policy, NATO has manoeuvred itself into a position where it is condemned either to the permanent occupation of Kosovo or to seeking to find a different UN rationale - a change Russia would probably veto - to permit the emergence of an independent Kosovo. But an independent Kosovo is precisely what all NATO states have sought to avoid. They have evaded their own principle of self-determination because they know that an independent Kosovo would evoke claims for a similar status for Albanians in Macedonia, adjoining Kosovo. Yet a break-up of Macedonia could unleash another Balkan war and lead to another NATO protectorate, continuing a process whereby either NATO becomes the heir of the old Turkish and Austrian empires or the Balkans continue in a state of permanent crisis. America and its allies were right in resisting Serbian ethnic cleansing. But their means were inappropriate to the objective. The NATO demand at Rambouillet for unlimited right to move its forces across Yugoslav territory and occupy a province of a sovereign country - before ethnic cleansing had started on a large scale - guaranteed the most bloody outcome. Not even a reasonable Yugoslav government could accept such terms. Less emphasis on domestic politics and more thoughtful understanding of history would have produced a better balance between the humanitarian and political challenges, saved more lives and created better conditions for a long-term political evolution. And it would have avoided the uneasiness caused in many parts of the world by NATO's drift from defensive to offensive missions. The same tendency to seek immediate solution to an historic problem has also exacerbated the situation in East Timor. The West pressed an interim unelected Indonesian government that had already granted full autonomy to East Timor to move toward independence - in the midst of Indonesia's first democratic election. This perversely reduced that government's ability to restrain its dissident military. And the lack of sensitivity to Indonesia's concern with the precarious unity of its state and of the religious issue involved has mortgaged not only the fledgling democracy but Indonesia's historic partnership with the West. Six months after the proclaimed triumph over Kosovo, the West's reaction to Russian repression of Chechnya showed that Kosovo had established far from a general principle. Russia, as Serbia, is trying to impose its rule on a dissident province; as in Kosovo, the conflict between the Orthodox Christianity of the rulers and the Islamic faith of the rebels is religious in origin; and, as in the Balkans, the rulers seek to break the will of their subjects by making their lives in their home province unendurable, generating mass migration. What differs is the reaction of the Western allies. The apostles of the so-called ethical policy can bring themselves to utter criticisms of Russia only in a shamefaced form designed to placate critics at home rather than affect decisions in Moscow. Both in official statements and in the media, the "freedom fighters" of Kosovo have been transmuted by tacit abdication into the "rebels," or "militants," of Chechnya. Moscow is criticized, if at all, for inflicting excessive casualties, not for the purpose of the operation - which, in fact, President Clinton endorsed as protecting the integrity of Russia's borders and fighting terrorism. The reluctance to jeopardize relations with a potentially powerful Russia is understandable. But just as, in Kosovo, the absence of historical perspective caused us to veer too far in the direction of moral crusades, we have now erred by adopting too narrow a definition of the national interest. Even granting that blocking Russian intervention was impossible, it nevertheless was important to discourage Russia from future attempts to rely on force in regulating its relations with its many neighbours - already fearful about being forced back into a new Russian empire. And this required a less timid response. Moral precepts are absolute and make no allowance for historical evolution. When thwarted, they allow no fall-back. But foreign policy must deal with nuances and processes rather than terminal points. Public relations myths - or worse, self-delusion - cannot serve as a substitute. New Age diplomacy has not abolished the need to strike a balance between a society's ideals and the necessities of its place in the world. Oscillation between over-commitment and abdication will vitiate our power and our capacity to shape a stable international order. This article first appeared in The Dawn of Pakistan.

title: Independence Cup notebook
body: NO COMMENT NOW Record breaking batsman and former India captain Sunil Gavaskar arrived in the city on Saturday to witness the ongoing Coca-Cola Independence Cup as one of Bangladesh Cricket Board's special guests. First man to reach 10,000-run mark and the scorer of most centuries in Test cricket , the legendary opening batsman however will not be a mere guest and perform another role during his stay. Recently in the centre of controversy for his remark about present Indian captain Azharuddin, 'Sunny' as he is known in the cricketing fraternity, refused to make any comment on Azhar's superlative batting effort yesterday saying he is under a contract with a vernacular daily to write a column regularly through the Independence Cup. It was during the 23rd over of the Pakistan innings when this reporter came across this batting colossus near the WorldTel commentary box. When asked about the match Gavaskar who apparently was not at first aware of the questioner's journalistic connection reacted quickly, " Good match. I think it is going to be a pretty close contest." What does he have to say about Azharuddin's century ? " No comment now" by now the maestro had found out the identity of the person he was talking to though rather curiously but the caution was obvious , " No, I can not make any comment because I am under a contract. I will write that in my column." PAKISTAN CAPTAIN The newly appointed Pakistan captain Rashid Latif is likely to lead his country until the 1999 World Cup, a Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) official revealed. Tariq Aziz, a Karachi-based Pakistan Cricket Board coordinator who is now covering the ongoing Coca-Cola Independence Cup as a commentator of Radio Pakistan , yesterday told The Daily Star that Rashid Latif enjoys the reputation of being the most honest and disciplined cricketer in Pakistan. "There prevails a notion that Rashid only concentrates on cricket. The main consideration behind his appointment as the captain was his honesty and simplicity which are in short supply in Paskistan cricket these days," said Tariq . SHAME! An unknown girl in the gallery raised a placard during yesterday's match reading "Shahid Afridi, please marry me". This shameless exhibition of marital inclination caught the public eye when the TV camera dwelt on the ladies' gallery in the course of the live coverage of the India Pakistan match. State Minister for Information Abu Sayeed gave commentators of Bangladesh Television a piece of his mind yesterday. The otiose professor paid a surprise visit to the roof top box of the BTV 'bunglers'. The State minister was reportedly annoyed with the standard of commentary in course of the opening match of the Independence Cup between India and Bangladesh on Saturday. He instructed them not to 'air' things they were not properly informed of. CHEER GIRLS Four beautiful girls were seen as cheer leaders bearing the name of an international bevarage company during yesterday's India-Pakistan match at the Dhaka Stadium. It was learnt that the girls, who are professional models, have been brought from the Indian city of Bangalore for promotional reasons. P-O-M Rafiqul Alam, one of the five national selectors who was the adjudicator for yesterday's player-of-the-match award, came under fire from cricket lovers and experts for choosing Indian captain Mohammad Azharuddin ahead of Sachin Tendulkar, whose all round excellence was the source of everybody's admiration yesterday. Many felt Sachin who scored a swashbuckling 67 off just 44 balls to give India a perfect start and then took four brilliant catches including that of dangerman Imzamamul Haq whom he caught off his own bowling should have been named the player-of-the-day.

title: Worker dies from electrocution
body: A day labour died after being electrocuted in Boiragipara area of Rangpur city on Sunday night. The deceased is Biplob Mohanta, 19, son of Bishu Mohanta, of the same area. Witnesses said Biplob died on the spot as he came into contact with a live electric wire while working at a house in the area. An unnatural death case was filed with Rangpur Kotwali Police Station in this connection, said Md Shahabuddin Khalifa, officer-in-charge of the police station.

title: 3 'human traffickers' held, woman rescued in Khulna
body: Police arrested three alleged human traffickers and rescued a woman at Kashipur in Khulna city on Tuesday night. Following information from neighbours, police arrested Adbus Sattar, 45, of Narail district, his wife Khaleda, 28, and his sister-in-law Rafiza Akter, 22. Police said Sattar confined the woman, 20, to his house, promising her a good job abroad.

title: AL meets today to discuss strategy
body: Ruling Awami League will hold a series of meetings today to discuss strategy to face opposition movement and upcoming local government polls. According to party sources, Ganobhavan, the official residence of the Prime Minister and AL supremo Sheikh Hasina has been chosen as the venue for holding three meetings in quick succession starting at 10 this morning. Meetings of the AL National Committee, Central Working Committee (CWC) and also an extended meeting of the National Committee would be held today in the wake of movement threats from major opposition parties - BNP, Jatiya Party and Jamaat. The opposition had already put forward a four-point charter of demands giving a 30-day ultimatum ending on February 5 and also given a nation-wide hartal call on January 26 coinciding with the date of submission of nominations for pourashava polls. Many of the presidents and general secretaries of 70 organisational districts of AL already reached Dhaka yesterday while others are expected to reach today to join the 156-member National Committee meeting. Party sources told The Daily Star that upcoming elections to four city corporations and 143 pourashavas would be on top of the agenda at today's meetings as the major opposition parties had already rejected the schedules of the polls. Sheikh Hasina is scheduled to preside over the meetings. Beginning at 10 in the morning the National Committee meeting is likely to continue till lunch break. Then an extended meeting of the National Committee would be held in the afternoon. AL Central Working Committee would sit at the end of the day to summarise the essence of the earlier meetings and then decide next course of actions in coming days, sources said.

title: Africa's nations renew rivalry
body: JOHANNESBURG, Feb 3: The African Nations' Cup comes of age this week in Burkina Faso with the 21st edition of the biennial 16-country showpiece, reports AFP. Apart from Olympic champions Nigeria, suspended for refusing to defend the title in South Africa, the giants are present, including World Cup qualifiers Cameroon, Mrocco, South Africa and Tunisia. Morocco are the popular choice to lift the trophy because they can field a settled side, employ an experienced coach in Frenchman Henri Michel, and have been ranked No 1 in Africa since last May. But the 41-year history of the competition is littered with upsets and the lions of the atlas could face formidable challenges from holders South Africa, Cameroon, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Tunisia and Zambia. The four previous tournaments staged in west Africa were won by countries from the region and footballers used to first-class accommodation and facilities may struggle here. While the organisers have spared no effort to host a memorable 22-day event, Burkina Faso is one of the poorest nations in the world and cannot hope to match the glitz of South Africa two years ago. Ouagadougou, the capital city in the heart of the landlocked country, and the south-western town of Bobo-Dioulasso play host to teams from the north, west, centre and south of the continent. The Chinese-built, 40,000-seat August 4 Stadium stages the opening ceremony, they first game between Burkina Faso and Cameroon Saturday, and the final on February 28. Matches in Ouagadougou are divided between the National Stadium and the smaller Municipal Stadium while Bobo-Dioulasso boasts the new, French-built Omnisport Stadium. Crowds at games not involving Burkina Faso are expected to be much larger than in South Africa, where only fixtures featuring 'bafana bafana' (the boys) drew big attendances. Expectations are high that the finals could match those of 1984 in Ivory Coast, where the 'indomitable lions' of Cameroon won what is widely regarded to be the most exciting of the 20 tournaments. If the presence of stars guarantees success then Burkina Faso can hardly fail as veterans, established internationals and young hopefuls strive to capture the attention of spectators and a worldwide television audience. The 'old guard' includes Abedi Pele of Ghana, who collected a winners' medal in Libya 16 years ago, and fellow-midielder Kalusha Bwalya from Zambia, the strongest team never to have finished first. Noureddine Naybet of Morocco and Hani Ramzy of Egypt in defence, Moussa Saib of Algeria and Zoubeir Beya of Tunisia in midfield, and 'Paulao' of Angola and Patrick Mboma of Cameroon in attack are proven performers. No continent encourages youth more than Africa and much is expected of strikers Benni McCarthy of South Africa, 'Akwa' of Angola and Ibrahim Babayoko of Ivory Coast. Only Group B, where four-time champions Ghana and 1996 runners-up Tunisia should have the measure of the ill-prepared Democratic Republic of Congo (formerly Zaire) and limited Togo, appears clearcut. A dramatic improvement by Burkina Faso since the arrival of French coach Philippe Troussier could spell problems for Cameroon and Algeria in Group A with Guinea the outsiders. Ivory Coast borders Burkina Faso and the 1992 champions can expect huge support in Group C against South Africa, without a win in seven matches, potential giantkillers Angola and dark horses Namibia. Every tournament has a group of death and a pool containing Morocco, Zambia and Egypt certainly fits the bill with Mozambique completing the Group D line-up. Each team plays its three opponents once on a league system with three points for a win and one for a draw and group winners and runners-up advance to the quarterfinals.

title: Chittagong trade fair to continue till April 5
body: The authority of Chittagong International Trade Fair-2013 scheduled to end on March 31 has decided to continue the expo till April 5. The decision was taken on requests from the participant businesses, as the fair saw huge turnout in the last couple of days, said the event's organising committee. Local and foreign entrepreneurs built around 239 stalls and 12 pavilions at the 21st edition of the show.

title: School cricket Islamia High champs
body: Islamia High School clinched the Standard Chartered 21st National School Cricket Championship (Gaibandha region) beating Gaibandha Government Boys High School by four wickets in the final at Gaibandha Govt Boys High School ground yesterday. Winning in the toss, Gaibandha Govt Boys batted first and scored 139 runs all out in 28 overs. In reply, Islamia made 142 runs for six wickets in 26.2 overs. Johnny of Islamia was declared man-of-the-match.

title: Banks reject BFFEA proposal for cash incentives
body: The central bank and the commercial banks have rejected the frozen food industry's proposal for cash incentive and blanket transfer of 40 per cent of all its arrears into the "blocked account," says UNB. To keep the frozen food export uninterrupted, the banks, however, have decided to give some "special facilities" temporarily only to those food-processing units which are still in production. At a recent meeting, chaired by Bangladesh Bank deputy governor Khondker Ibrahim Khalid, the bank executive also assured Bangladesh Frozen Food Exporters' Association (BFFEA) of giving "packing credit" on the basis of "case-to-case" study of the status of individual unit. Frozen food export accounts for 10 per cent of the country's total export earnings and contributes 5 per cent to the GDP. The bankers endorsed the Association's concern about the staggering situation of the frozen food industry, hard hit by the abrupt fall of price in international market. But they categorically said the proposal for giving any cash financial assistance on export was beyond their jurisdiction and felt that the government might take necessary steps regarding the issue. Fall of price, import restriction by the EU, currency devaluation by the competing exporter countries have altogether made the Bangladesh's frozen food export very tough and competitive, resulting in huge stockpile of frozen food and shortage of fund for loan repayment. Failure in repaying overdue loans led many exporters to face fund shortage as they are not getting fresh loans, thus leading to closure of many food processing units and stoppage of export from many others, the meeting observed. The units, which exported frozen foods in last few months, and have export orders in had will be fit to be chosen for special consideration. But no defaulted unit will get any consideration. Fifteen per cent of the real stock price of the chosen frozen food exporters may be kept as "blocked account" for three years. Concerned banks will realise the amount directly from export bills within the stipulated timeframe. As an alternative, packing credit may be granted but a unit cannot avail of both the opportunities at a time. The frozen food exporters and processors will have to pay 9 per cent interest on blocked account while the banker-customer relationship will decide about the guarantee. Earlier, Bangladesh Frozen Food Exporters Association (BFFEA) president Golam Mostafa made two proposals to help the frozen food industry recover from the present crisis, caused by factors beyond its control The two proposals were: Transferring 40 per cent of the actual loan into interest-free blocked account and realising it at 1 per cent rate on export bills after a three-year moratorium; and giging 15 per cent alternative partial cash incentive. Golam Mostafa gave the meeting a detailed picture how crisis engulfed the frozen food industry, despite its bright prospects. Prices of frozen shrimp dropped by 40 per cent in international market during July 1997 to December 1998 period, he said, leading many exporters to lose their running capital. Besides, the EU clamped a ban on export of frozen food from Bangladesh in July 1997 on the plea of quality control, compelling many processing units to invest Tk 1.5 crore to 2 crore for overhauling and to suspend production for seven to eight months. As a result, the industry developed a huge backlog of frozen food and was forced to sell those below the usual rate. The 1998 flood gave another blow to the industry, inundating many shrimp plants. On the other hand, several frozen foodexporting countries, including India, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia and Pakistan, devalued their currency against the dollar to boost their exports. Country's export target of frozen food during the current fiscal year has been fixed at Tk 1500 crore, which is Tk 217 crore higher then the export in 1995-96. Some 1.2 million people are directly involved with the industry while another 12 million indirectly. If a proper policy is adopted and implemented, the frozen food export can be raised to 1.5 billion US dollar in four years, Golam Mostafa hoped.

title: MOU signed between BCSIR, UNI-LAB
body: A memorandum of understanding (MOU) has been signed between the Institute of Fuel Research and Development, BCSIR, Dhaka and UNI-LAB for estimation of Aromatic Hydrocarbon in jute bags at a meeting held in BCSIR recently, says a press release. Under the agreement, Institute of Fuel Research and Development will test 'lignum' a hydrocarbon free jute processing lubricant based on vegetable oil developed by UNI-LAB for using in jute industries in place of harmful jute batching oil (mineral oil). IFRD will also test mineral oil content of jute bags supplied by UNI-LAB. It is mentioned that jute batching oil is composed of 20 to 30 per cent aromatic hydrocarbons which are carcinogenic and responsible for food contamination. If 'lignum' can be used in place of JBO then jute bags will be hydrocarbon free. Then it will be used in food packaging. UNI-LAB is engaged in export of jute goods for foodgrain packaging. Professor Mosihuzzaman, chairman, Bangladesh Council of Scientific and Industrial Research (BCSIR) and Shaheed Ahmed, Managing Partner of UNI-LAB signed the MOU on behalf of their respective organisations. The MOU will remain valid for three years till December 2000.

title: India set for big win
body: Cheteshwar Pujara struck his second Test double century to ensure a huge first-innings lead as hosts India took a stranglehold of the second Test against a hapless Australia on Monday. Pujara's masterly knock of 204 and his record 370-run partnership with Murali Vijay (167) helped India pile up a commanding 503, giving the hosts a lead of 266 runs on the third day at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium. Such was the impact of the Pujara-Vijay effort that India managed to cross the 500-run mark despite losing their last nine wickets for only 116 runs. With a huge cushion under their belt, off-spinner Ravichandran Ashwin came out all guns blazing, dismissing David Warner (26) and Phillip Hughes (0) in quick succession as Australia finished the day at a shaky 74 for two in their second innings. Both Warner and Hughes were guilty of trying to sweep Ashwin deliveries, which pitched on the leg-stump before disturbing their stumps. Cheteshwar Pujara raises his bat after reaching his double hundred on the 3rd day of the 2nd Test against Australia in Hyderabad yesterday. PHOTO: INTERNET At the close of play, Australia required another 192 runs to avoid an innings defeat, and Mahendra Singh Dhoni and Co going 2-0 up in the four-match series seemed inevitable. With still two more days to go, the question now is not how but when will India wrap up the match. While the second day totally belonged to Vijay and Pujara, the duo did its bit on the third day as they frustrated a lacklustre Australian attack which looked clueless and waiting for the batsmen to make mistakes. While Vijay hit 23 boundaries and two sixes in his 361-ball knock, Team India's newest 'run-machine', Pujara's magnificent knock, spanning 341 balls, was laced with 30 boundaries and a six.

title: EC envoy calls on Faezul
body: Ambassador of European Commission (EC) to Bangladesh Antonio de Souza Menezes called on State Minister for Jute A K Faezul Huq at his Secretariat office yesterday and discussed matters relating to mutual interest, reports UNB. They also discussed the ways and means to strengthen the activities of the International Jute organisation (IJO). Among others, First Counsellor of the European Commission Jorg Volker Ketelsen was also present, said an official handout.

title: Glimmers of hope for troubled US newspapers
body: A news vendor is seen at Manhattan's Cooper Square, New York City. The US newspaper industry sees some positive signs after being battered for years. Photo: AFP The US newspaper industry is seeing some glimmers of hope after being battered for years, a prominent study concluded Monday. While the industry is about half the size it once was, there are some positive signs, including new revenue streams from digital paywalls and a general economic improvement which is aiding newspapers, the study found. "For the first time since the deep recession that began in 2007, newspaper organizations have grounds for a modicum of optimism," said the authors of the study by the Pew Research Center's Project for Excellence in Journalism. The 2013 State of the News Media report said newspapers "have started to experiment in a big way with a variety of new revenue streams and major organizational changes." Some of these, such as using social media to help advertisers, are too new to be measured, but are part of a trend which suggests stabilizing revenue, the researchers said. Among other positive signs, the report said: - Digital pay plans have been adopted at 450 of the 1,380 dailies US and "appear to be working not just at The New York Times but also at small and mid-sized papers." These are helping add new revenues and reduce dependence on advertising. - Publicly traded newspaper companies saw their share prices rise in 2012, albeit from a reduced base, with several up 30 percent or more. - Newspapers coming onto the market are finding buyers. Among the notable investors are Warren Buffett, whose Berkshire Hathaway bought a group of 63 newspapers and several others. - The modest improvement in the economy has eased pressures on the industry, with auto advertising reviving and real estate and employment ads recovering in some markets as well. Nonetheless, the authors say these positives "are, for the time being, mostly promise rather than performance" and that the basic indicators remain grim. Print advertising fell for a sixth consecutive year in 2012 -- by a significant 7.3 percent or $1.5 billion. National advertising is especially weak, suggesting that corporations are shifting to other platforms. The Pew research shows digital advertising now represents 15 percent of total newspaper ad revenue, but has grown anemically the past two years and does not come close to covering print ad losses. The study indicates newsrooms are still being slashed and that readership from mobile platforms is failing to generate significant revenues. "Though the great majority of newspaper organizations are profitable on an operating basis, many companies continue to struggle with debt and pension obligations assumed in better times," the report said. "In a symbolic indicator of decline, newspapers are abandoning the grand headquarters buildings that used to help anchor downtowns in favor of smaller, less expensive offices. Those that stay are starting to rent excess space to other businesses." Some dailies have cut print frequency to three times a week, which has sparked a heated debate in the industry. The most prominent of these was the New Orleans Times-Picayune and its parent Advance Publications. In Pew interviews with executives at 13 major newspaper companies, the most common prediction was that more papers would soon adopt the three-day-a-week publication schedule. The report said newspapers continue to slash staff, making it harder to cover news in the way readers have expected. "This adds up to a news industry that is more undermanned and unprepared to uncover stories, dig deep into emerging ones or to question information put into its hands," the report said. And a public opinion survey released in the report showed that 31 percent had "deserted a news outlet because it no longer provides the news and information they had grown accustomed to," Pew said. Overall, Pew said media organizations -- including newspapers, broadcasters and cable news operators -- were shrinking further, driving consumers to seek information elsewhere. "There are all sorts of contributors in the evolving landscape of news and, in many ways, more opportunities for citizens to access information," said Amy Mitchell, acting director of the Pew Center's Project for Excellence in Journalism. "But there are more signs than ever that the reduced reporting power in the news industry is having an effect and may weaken both the industry's capacity to produce in-depth journalism and its credibility with the public at the same time that others are gaining more voice." Pew said that Google has become a dominant force in digital news, impacting traditional media groups. "News organizations are increasingly dependent on Google and a handful of other powerful tech firms for the tools and platforms needed to reach their audience," the Pew report said. "They also are increasingly vulnerable to the changes the tech firms are introducing. The shift to mobile, for example, is making news an ever-more expensive arena in which to operate, but it is not yet producing the kind of new revenues to back up news organizations that will allow them to support those expenses."

title: Sporadic violence across country
body: Police trying to disperse the pickets when they block a local road by burning tyres in Rajshahi city during opposition 18-party alliance enforced 36-hour shutdown Wednesday. Photo: STAR The 36-hour hartal enforced by the BNP-led 18-party alliance is going on across the country on Wednesday amid stray incidents of violence. Four vehicles were torched in Chittagong while seven others were vandalised in Narayanganj. Law enforcers rounded up 31 pro-hartal activists in Rajshahi and Chandpur. 26 people were injured in clashes during hartal hours in Rajshahi, Chandpur, Jhenidah and Bogra. At least 12 homemade bombs exploded in Chittagong, Narayanganj and Bogra. The 18-party combine called the shutdown as part of its strategy to make April a turning point in their agitation to oust the government. Pickets torched two trucks and a covered-van at Sitakunda upazila in Chittagong around 5:30am, reports our correspondent quoting Samiul Alam, officer-in-charge of Sitakunda Police Station. Activists of Swechchhasebak Dal torched a rickshaw at Kazir Dewri area in the city in the morning, said Mirza Saiem Mahmud, assistant commissioner of Chittagong Metropolitan Police (Kotwali zone). Islami Chhatra Shibir activists brought out a procession and put barricade by burning tyres on a road in Rahmatganj area around 7:30am. BNP activists hurled four homemade bombs on police while law enforcers resisted their procession at Alangkar intersection in Pahartoli area of the city around 11:15am, witnesses said. Pickets also exploded three cocktails in Ispahani, Kazir Dewri and Askar Dighirpar area in the city around 2:30pm. Five people were injured as the activists of BNP clashed with police at Puratan Court area in the city around 6:00am. The clash took place when police resisted some BNP activists who were trying to block a road and vandalised a truck in the area, witnesses said. In face of police resistance, BNP men hurled brick chips and exploded at least three cocktails forcing the law enforcers to charge batons and open fire, said Munzur Kader, officer-in-charge (OC) of Narayanganj Sadar Police Station. Pickets also vandalised a bus on Narayanganj-Adamzi road at Haziganj while another was damaged on Dhaka-Narayanganj road at Kutubpur area. In another development, police detained city unit BNP joint secretary Anwar Mahmud around 8:30am, the OC said. A police constable was injured as Shibir activists clashed with police near Loknath High School in Hetemkha area in the city. The clash ensued when police tried to disperse a Shibir procession in the area around 7:30am, reported our Rajshahi correspondent. Being resisted by police, the Shibir men hurled brick chips at police and blocked a road at the area by burning tyres leaving the police constable injured, said Ziaur Rahman, OC of Boalia Police Station. Police had to fire over 100 rounds of rubber bullets and six rounds of teargas shells to take the situation under control, the OC said. Injured Anwar Hossain, constable of Boalia Police Station, was given primary treatment at a local clinic in the city, he added. Meanwhile, law enforcers picked up 22 pro-hartal activists including city unit BNP vice president Ansar Ali from Dharampur area on suspicion of carrying out subversive activities during the hartal, said Alamgir Hossain, officer-in-charge of Detective Branch of Police. Police also foiled a procession when the city BNP leaders and activists led by Mizanur Rahman Mizan, joint secretary general of BNP, tried to bring out the procession from the city’s Malopara BNP office around 6:30am. At least five people were injured when Awami League activists swooped on a BNP procession at Faridganj upazila of the district around 11:00am, said Nazmul Haque, OC of Faridganj Police Station. Pickets blockaded Chandpur-Comilla road and Chandpur-Matlob road in the town by burning tyres and felling trees in the morning, reports our Chandpur correspondent quoting the OC. They also vandalised several vehicles in the town while BNP activists brought out several processions in different areas of the town. Police picked up nine people while they were picketing at different areas of the district, said Md Amir Zafar, superintendent of police in Chandpur. At least 10 leaders and activists of the Jatiyatabadi Mohila Dal district unit were injured as Bangladesh Chhatra League and Jubo League men attacked the former at Paira Chattar in the town. The injured including the district unit Mohila Dal general secretary, Ayesha Khatun, and its Sadar upazila unit convener Tohura Khatun. They were admitted to Jhenidah Sadar Hospital, reported our Jhenidah correspondent. Ten people were injured when the driver of a mini truck lost his control over the steering and hit a roadside tree after pickets hurled brick chips towards the vehicle on Bogra-Naogaon road in Arulia of the town around 6:00am. Most of the injured were day labourer but details of the injured could not be known immediately, reports our Bogra correspondent quoting Syed Shahid Uddin, OC of Bogra Sadar Police Station. Three of the injured including the truck driver were admitted to a local hospital with severe injuries, the OC said. Meanwhile, two cocktails were blasted in Kathaltola area just after a procession of the district BNP unit around 11:00am, the OC said.

title: 'US should dump Islamabad'
body: Washington and Islamabad should give up the fiction of being allies and acknowledge that their interests simply do not converge enough to make them strong partners, Pakistan's recent envoy to the US, who is now a hunted man in his home country, has advised. Instead, says Hussain Haqqani, till recently Pakistan's ambassador to the US, Washington should leave Pakistan to its own devices so that it can discover for itself how weak it is without American aid and support, eventually enabling it to return to the mainstream suitably chastened about its limitations. "By coming to terms with this reality, Washington would be freer to explore new ways of pressuring Pakistan and achieving its own goals in the region. Islamabad, meanwhile, could finally pursue its regional ambitions, which would either succeed once and for all or, more likely, teach Pakistani officials the limitations of their country's power," Haqqani writes about the broken relationship in the latest issue of Foreign Affairs journal. "Once Pakistan's national security elites recognize the limits of their power, the country might eventually seek a renewed partnership with the United States -- but this time with greater humility and an awareness of what it can and cannot get," says Haqqani .

title: Minimum standard of edn a must for MPO: Farruk
body: Education Minister Dr. Osman Farruk yesterday said Monthly Pay Order (MPO) and government grants to educational institutions must not be a "permanent settlement". "The educational institutions that will fail to register a minimum performance should not have the right to claim government grants and facilities," he said while inaugurating as chief guest the national-level programme of the 'National Education Week-2003'. Held at the Osmani Memorial Hall under the auspices of the education ministry, the function was also addressed by State Minister for Education ANM Ehsanul Haque Milon and Deputy Minister Mohammad Abdus Salam Pinto as special guests. Presided over by Education Secretary Mohammad Shahidul Alam, the inaugural function was also addressed, among others, by Director General of Secondary and Higher Secondary Education Directorate Abdur Rashid and Joint Secretary of the ministry Sheikh AK Motahar Hossain. Dr. Osman Farruk said the education administration had become weak and full of irregularities and the managing committees almost "non-functioning" because of "personal" and "coterie" interests. "Our government does not believe in politicisation of school and college managing committees," he said adding that to improve the prevailing situation, both responsibility and accountability of the governing bodies had to be enhanced. The education minister said the responsibility to improve the standard of education must be carried out jointly by its stakeholders -- teachers, students, guardians, civil society members and the government. The education minister said the curriculum as well as syllabus of the text books must be "life-oriented" and realistic so that real nation-building architects come out from the country's 107,000 educational institutions. The main work to attain this goal has to be carried out by 750,000 teachers employed in these institutions, he said. Turning to the quality education, the minister said "We do not want to engage police to remove note books from the market, nor do we want to close down the private coaching centres right now." "We have to go to the root of the problem and ask ourselves why students have become dependent on note books and coaching centres," he said, adding that teachers must perform their sacred jobs of imparting education and wisdom to their pupils in the class room for the full period of their contract hours before heading for coaching centres. "We have to recast our education system so that the new generation can be injected with human and moral values and are well-educated," he said. He stressed the need for introducing an education system that is capable of achieving the basic objectives of education, like enlightening the learners, making them wise, knowledgeable and good citizens and capable of innovating new skills and strategies for nation-building purposes. Making a departure from his written speech, the education minister raised some important issues like adopting unfair means in examinations, misuse of funds and facilities, sufferings of the teachers in the corridors of education directorate and national university to get their problems addressed. At the same time, the minister hinted at some important measures his ministry is going to take to streamline this very important sector of national life. He said the education directorate and the national university would be further decentralised so that the teachers and others concerned could get their services without undergoing much hazard and inconvenience. The inaugural session was followed by National Education Conference entitled "Education for Attaining Self-reliance".

title: LTTE pounds police passing out parade
body: COLOMBO, Jan 20: Four civilians and a constable were killed today when Tamil rebels fired mortar bombs at police recruits holding a passing out parade in eastern Sri Lanka while 11 more died elsewhere, officials said, reports AFP. The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) guerrillas pounded the ceremony at Morawewa village, officials said, adding that the four civilians victims were relatives of recruits. In another attack on a civilian gasoline tanker, Tiger rebels shot dead the driver and wounded three others Thursday in the easatern district of Batticaloa, the defence ministry said. In other clashes, government troops killed nine members of the LTTE in gun battles in the northern peninsula of Jaffna on Wednesday, the ministry said adding that a rival rebel also died in an accidental shooting.

title: Agri Credit and Fate of Cultivator
body: The objective of establishing Agriculture Bank in the country is to assist the cultivators and boost agricultural production. From the then Pakistani period up till now huge amount of money has been disbursed among the cultivators and the credit programme is still running in the country. The agriculture credit is essential to help the farmers during or after damage of crops by natural calamities like flood, drought etc. There are different types of credit being disbursed among the farmers like short term, medium term, long term, crop loan, fishery loan, loan for purchasing agricultural tools, machinery, inputs etc. All types of small, medium and large farmers are entitled to take loan from the bank after fulfilling the necessary formalities. Sometimes, taking loan from the banks becomes difficult. The uneducated farmers are cheated by some corrupt bank officials and middlemen who take illegal gratification from the farmers. As a result the farmers are compelled to go to the private money lenders bracing exorbitant interest. Monitoring: Is there any monitoring or follow up system on the utilisation of the credit taken for a specific purpose? Nothing effective. In many cases it has been observed that the farmers do not use the credit in productive purposes rather they use the money in social purposes like, payment of dowry or to meet up the expenses of son's/daughter's marriage or sometimes even in household consumption. If the loan is not used for productive purposes it may be really difficult to repay it in time. Repayment: The repayment of agricultural loan is mainly dependent on the production of crops. If the farmers do not have a good harvest, normally they are not interested or in a position to pay back the money. Even they do not walk near the bank and try to evade meeting the bank personnel. Due to non-payment of loan in time, the amount becomes bigger by addition of interest in compound rate. In the process, after some years, it becomes really difficult to repay the loan by the poor farmers. Moreover, in rural Bangladesh there prevails a belief government may rebate all the loans some day considering the borrower's incapability. Due to wait-and-see perception of the farmers and increase of loan amount with addition of compound interest, the farmers become eventually discouraged to repay. But on the other hand, loan taken from private source can not be kept unpaid for long time due to pressure from the lenders and in fear of losing property as well as social status in society. Repayment is made or has to be made quickly. The realisation rate in private sector is always higher than in public sector. Dealing with Defaulters: According to reports in the daily newspapers, "banks are hostage to 87 defaulters" in the country. These defaulters are very rich. They have borrowed heavily from the banks and just did not pay back the money. Whereas in the rural areas, many certificate cases have been filed against the farmers for non-payment of bank loans. The poor farmers are willing to repay but they do not have any capacity to pay back the amount. It may be mentioned that in rural areas of the country many farmers have taken crop loan, fishery loan some 15-20 years back, but are yet to repay those. Several notices have been given from the banks but the collection rate is not satisfactory and the progress that has been made through recovery system is not always socially encouraging. It may be mentioned that some of the bank-mortgaged lands have been sold out and the previous owners of those land have either migrated to the city or to other countries. Considering the number of defaulters and amount of outstanding credit, there must be a huge number of mortgaged plots in the whole country. To whom these will be sold or how, or will it be a wise decision? How to solve this problem? This is a vital question of the social/political leaders and reputed economists of the country. Moreover, what action will be taken in case of those famous 87 defaulters who do not have any intention to repay the bank loans? Are they out of the law of the land? Do they provide special privilege to the government or do they have two votes per person? The citizens of the Republic want to see every citizen is treated equally in the eye of law of the land and dealt with accordingly. To deal with the defaulter farmers it may be suggested that the interest of all outstanding agricultural loans up to Tk 10,000.00 per farmer should be rebated fully and only the capital amount realised in instalments, by which, both the farms and farmers will be saved. In near future interest-free agricultural credit programme should be initiated experimentally with the sanction of Tk 15,000.00 to each interested farmer. Only service charge at the rate of 3 per cent to 5 per cent on the capital amount can be charged. Through this programme, the marginal and medium class farmers are expected to benefit largely.

title: 'No normalization of ties with Pakistan'
body: On the eve of Pakistan Prime Minister Raja Parvez Ashraf's visit, India yesterday said there cannot be normalization of ties with it unless the terror machine still active there was brought under control. Prime Minister Manmohan Singh said India has made sincere efforts to normalize its relations with Pakistan and had achieved some progress. "People to people contacts have gone up, trade relations have shown improvement," Singh said in the Rajya Sabha replying to a debate on Motion of Thanks to President's address. "But there cannot be normalisation of relations between our two countries unless and until the terror machine which is still active in Pakistan is brought under control," he said. Singh said this has been his government's policy for the past nine years and would continue in the coming times. The Prime Minister's remarks come ahead of the his Pakistan counterpart's visit to India tomorrow. Ashraf, during a day-long visit, is scheduled to offer prayers at the famous dargah of sufi saint Moinuddin Chisti at Ajmer. External Affairs Minister Salman Khurshid will host a lunch in his honour at Jaipur, but no "substantive talks" are expected to take place. Ashraf's visit comes at a time when there is a chill in bilateral ties over the ceasefire violations at the Line of Control in Kashmir. An Indian soldier was beheaded by Pakistani troops while the mutilated body of another was found in January.

title: Jamaat calls hartal in Ctg for Monday
body: The Jamaat-e-Islami called a dawn-to-dusk shutdown in Chittagong division for Monday protesting the death of an Islami Chhatra Shibir activist during a police raid at the house of former Jamaat lawmaker on March 13. Mainul Hossain Munna, 26, a nephew of former Jamaat lawmaker Shahjahan Chowdhury, who sustained injuries during the raid, died at Chittagong Medical College Hospital around 11:00pm Friday, reports our Chittagong correspondent. ANM Shamsul Islam, lawmaker of Jamaat of Satkania constituency, announced the hartal around 3:35pm Saturday while attending the namaz-e-janaza of Mainul. Failing to nab Shahjahan, the law enforcers pushed Mainul off the rooftop of the house on March 13, Shahjahan claimed. Police raided the house of Shahjahan on the night of March 13 to arrest the Jamaat leader on charges of creating anarchy in Satkania upazila on February 28, said Md Iltutmish, additional superintendent of police (ASP) of Chittagong South zone. Anticipating detention, Mainul ran towards the rooftop of the four storey building and fell down, the ASP said. He was rushed to the Chittagong Medical College Hospital where he succumbed to his injuries Friday night, Iltutmish added. On February 28, Jamaat-Shibir men vandalised at least 60 vehicles on Chittagong-Cox's Bazar highway in Satkania upazila soon after Jamaat leader Delawar Hossain Sayedee was sentenced to death for his wartime offences. Several cocktails were also blasted in front of Chittagong College during the incident.

title: Oil dips as hopes for output cutback extension dwindles
body: LONDON, Jan 29: Oil prices fell back this week amid profit-taking of recent sharp gains, as hopes dwindled of an extension to producer output cutbacks, says AFP. The Brent North Sea reference crude fell to 25.70 dollars a barrel for March delivery on the International Petroleum Exchange in London from 26.76 dollars last week for February. On the New York Mercantile Exchange (NYMEX), light sweet crude for February delivery fell to 27.62 dollars from 29.66 dollars last week. Prices peaked at new nine-year high points early in the week as a US cold snap increased demand, eating into already low stock levels. But prices fell after Norway and Saudi Arabia both said that crucial output cutbacks should remain in place until the end of March as planned, but said nothing about an extension to the cuts. A pact last March to rein in global supply by 2.1 million barrels a day, including 1.7 million from the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Counties, helped oil prices more than double, but now the market is looking for indications of what will happen once the agreement expires in March. OPEC will take a final decision on the production quotas in Vienna in March. Rubber: Bounce. Rubber prices gained ground this week in a calm market. The arrival of winter in some Asian producer regions could limit supply, helping prices in coming weeks, one London dealer said. The London rubber index jumped to 482 pounds per tonne (for February delivery) from 455 last week. Meanwhile, in Kuala Lumpur, the RSS1 index rose to 2.64 ringgit per kilo from 2.46 ringgit, while the SMR20 index for material used in tire-manufacturing rose to 2.85 ringgit from 2.74. Tea: Weak. Demand fell away in the Mombasa auction houses but picked up in Colombo. Top-grade BP1 (Broken Pekoe) leaves managed to claw back last week's losses by gaining up to 13 cents, but PDust, which is used mainly to make tea bags, fell up to 25 cents. Vegetable oils: Warm. US soya prices gained further ground this week amid predictions of dry weather over South American producer regions. On the Chicago Board of Trade (CBoT), a bushel of soya gained 22 cents to 5.27 dollars (for March delivery). Dry weather has reigned over Argentinean and southern Brazilian crops, but wetter weather has been forecast for the coming days. Cotton: Fine. US cotton prices picked up this week in calm trading with few new market-moving factors. In New York, May contracts rose to 58.82 cents a pound from 58.76 cents. Cash prices covered by the Cotton Outlook index rose to 50.10 cents a pound from 47.20 cents.

title: Rony was drunk while shooting
body: A counsel for Bakhtiar Alam Rony, son of ruling Awami League lawmaker Pinu Khan, yesterday told a Dhaka court that his client was drunk when he shot dead two people in the capital on April 14. His client had no intention to kill any people, claimed advocate Kazi Nazibullah Hiru, adding that Rony committed the offence when he was drunk. So, he should not be placed on remand. Moreover, his client is sick, and he should be given proper treatment in jail custody. The lawyer said this while moving a petition seeking bail and cancellation of the seven-day fresh remand prayer by detectives. But the prosecution opposed it, saying Rony committed the offence with his full knowledge because he knew that if he shot a man, he would be killed. So, the accused should be remanded. Rejecting defence pleas, Metropolitan Magistrate Mahbubur Rahman put Rony on a four-day fresh remand for gleaning more information about the double murder in the city's New Eskaton. The jail authorities yesterday produced Rony before the court. In the remand prayer, Dipak Kumar Das, a sub-inspector of Detective Branch (DB) of police and also the investigating officer of the case, said he had earlier quizzed Rony intensively for four days and got vital clues about the killings. On June 13, Rony was sent to jail on expiry of his remand.
