He said eleven railway projects have already been undertaken at a cost of US$630 million out of the US$736 million allocated for 14 projects under the one billion dollar Indian LC. Following the decision of the joint communiqué signed on January 10, 2010 between Bangladesh and India during Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina's visit to New Delhi, Indian Prime Minister Dr Manmohan Singh announced the one billion dollar Indian LC for Bangladesh that included railway infrastructure and procurement of broad gauge and meter gauge rolling stock. The loan agreement was signed on August 7, 2010 between Bangladesh government and EXIM Bank of India in the presence of the then Indian finance minister and currently the president, Pranab Mukherjee.

title: 12 rifles looted from jute mills in Jessore
body: KHULNA, Jan 22: Unidentified miscreants looted 12 rifles and 155 bullets early Wednesday morning from Ansars on duty at the security room of the Akij Jute Mills at Noapara under Abhoynagar thana in Jessore, 30 kilometres off Khulna city. The Ansars deployed there to guard the mills were reportedly dozing, keeping the rifles on the floor and the door of the security room open. But the FIR at the Abhoynagar thana states that an organised group of 15 masked young men stormed into the security room firing shots at the Ansars at about 3-30 am. They confined the Ansars in another room at gun point and looted the rifles and bullets and then escaped raising slogans in favour of an outlawed organisation. They also exploded hand bombs and fired several blank shots. Ansar Bishnupada Saha was injured as the miscreants fired shots while entering into the security room of the jute mills, the second biggest in the Jessore industrial belt, the FIR said. Police rushed to the spot and took all the Ansars into custody for interrogation. A young man identified as Iqbal Kabir was arrested this morning from Ikhtarpur village under Abhoynagar PS.

title: Hosts take on India in opener today
body: Cricket lovers in the country will wake up to a week-long cricket carnival today when hosts Bangladesh take on giants India in the opening tie of the Coca-Cola Independence Cup tournament at the Dhaka Stadium. But a blanket of thick fog which has been prevailing over the country for the last few days threatens to disrupt a smooth progress of the tri-nation tourney that also includes Pakistan. According to a Met Office forecast, the foggy weather is likely to prevail. If the condition does not improve today, the match is likely to have a delayed start. But Mike Denness, the match referee and former England captain, is still hopeful of a full 50-over-a-side affair. Foreign Minister Abdus Samad Azad will formally inaugurate the tournament and the match is scheduled to start at 9 am. Both the state-run electronic media - Bangladesh Television and Betar - will provide the ball-by-ball commentary of the match from the big bowl. The stage is all set to take the heat of the big time cricket. Bangladesh Cricket Board (BCB), organisers of the tourney to celebrate the country's Silver Jubilee of Independence, has completed all the necessary preparations to make the gala event a success. However, Bangladesh skipper Akram Khan and his Indian counterpart Mohammad Azharuddin opted to wait till the morning before finalising the playing eleven. But an expected full-house crowd at the 35,000-capacity Dhaka Stadium will keep their finger crossed for a shiny day to enjoy the game of glorious uncertainties. The country is in the grip of cricket fever with the fans still having a busy time to collect a ticket of whatever match. Tickets of the six matches including the mandatory three finals are almost sold out. But touts are seen engaged in brisk selling of tickets around the stadium. This is for the fifth time Bangladesh will face India in an official limited-over match since their first meeting in October 1988. Bangladesh lost all their previous four engagements against their more colourful neighbours by an identical nine-wicket margin. "This is for the first time we have included a bunch of new faces in our side and I hope they will perform up to their potential," said Bangladesh skipper Akram Khan in a crowded press briefing at a local hotel last night. Tournament coordinator Syed Ashraful Haque, match referee Mike Denness and all the captains and managers of the participating teams attended the briefing. "The whole nation is expecting a good performance from us after two embarrassing tours of Kenya and New Zealand. As far as standard is concerned, there is a gulf of difference between them and us, but we will try our best to put up a good fight," said a soft-spoken Akram. When Akram was hoping for a better outcome, his Indian counterpart Mohammad Azharuddin, who regained the captaincy a week ago replacing Sachin Tendulkar, expressed his concern over the prevailing weather. "The wicket looked a bit damp in the morning when we had our practice at the venue. I don't know how it is going to be tomorrow. I think, no one can make any prediction until the match starts," said Azhar. "However, we have come here to play and we are taking every match seriously. Bangladesh is an emerging nation, but there is no scope of underestimating them," said the Hydrabad-born most successful Indian captain. At official briefing, Syed Ashraful Haque, a vice-president of the Bangladesh Cricket Board, declined to disclose the financial dealings of the tournament. " I am not authorised to say anything other than introducing the officials of the three teams," he said in reply to a volley of questions from the newsmen, who were eager to know the deal between the Board and America-based WorldTel. Ashraful, however, assured that the board would disclose all the details about the deal in a month. The WorldTel will provide live coverage of the tournament to 20 countries across the globe. Doug Cowie of New Zealand and Russell Tiffin of Zimbabwe will officiate today's match while Rudi Koertzen of South Africa will act as the third umpire.

title: Maradona hospitalised
body: PUNTA DEL ES-TE, Uruguay, Jan 5: Argentine foot-ball legend Diego Maradona was in intensive care in hospital here Wednesday after being admitted with heart problems, reports AFP. Maradona was receiving treatment at the Cantegrill Clinic after "suffering from a hypertension attack with ventricular arrhythmia, complicated by the fact he already had high blood pressure," said Dr Frank Torres. Maradona's manager Guill-ermo Coppola denied reports that his condition had been brought on by drug addiction or an overdose. "Everyone knows that Mara-dona has hypertension," Coppo-la, who was acquitted last year of cocaine possession, told the Radio Mitre radio station. "It's already happened to him more than once -- in Chile during a television programme and then when playing football in Buenos Aires, but there were no indications that drugs had anything to do with it," he added. "There was no ambulance, there was no coma, there were no police," he said," blasting what he called sensational press reports of Maradona's ailment. Torres said the 39-year-old Maradona was admitted to the clinic's intensive care unit on Tuesday afternoon. Maradona, who all but singlehandedly won the 1986 World Cup for Argentina over Germany and then led them to the 1990 final where the Germans gained revenge, was accompanied to the hospital by his wife Claudia Villafane and Coppola with whom he had been on holiday. "He is under observation and no complications are expected meaning he should only have a short stay in the clinic," Torres added. When asked if the problems were brought about by a drug overdose, Torres refused to confirm or deny, answering only: "The hypertension problems could have many different causes." Maradona has had repeated drug problems and has had rehabilitation several times. He was even thrown out of the 1994 World Cup for failing a drugs test and had a drugs ban while playing for Napoli in Italy. He had been on holiday at the expensive holiday resort of Punte del Este where he spent the New Year. Maradona, who courted controversy throughout a tempestuous career with Boca Juniors, before European stardom with Barcelona and Napoli, was recently voted Argentine spor-tsman of the 20th century. He retired from football in 1997. Argentine President Fernando de la Rua said he hoped Maradona would make a speedy recovery. "He has given so much happiness to everyone," he said. Among those to visit Maradona in the clinic were former president Carlos Menem and Uruguayan international Enzo Francescoli. "I feel reassured because Diego is perfectly all right," Menem said.

title: For An Enlightened Theatre in The New Millennium
body: LIKE every other morning, life of Kana and her husband Asheque begins in a peaceful manner at their apartment. Kana, daughter of a rich father, bears an extremely feminist ideology and is absolutely against any kind of dowry. One of the major reasons she loves and respects her husband very much is that her husband refused to take any sort of dowry from her father at the time of their marriage. Asheque, an established engineer, also loves his wife the same way and the couple was set for a perfect happy conjugal life until that morning. Their technician Ratan comes up with the news of suicide of Soroma, a neighbor who lives in another apartment of the same building. The news comes to Kana as a shock as it is gradually revealed that Soroma committed suicide under the irresistible pressure for dowry by her husband and in-laws. Things become more unbearable for her when Aheque goes forward to help Ronen, the husband of Soroma. But still Kana was ready to carry on unless she finds some of his father's letter written to her husband where to her greatest surprise, she discovers that Asheque have been regularly taking dowry from her father without her slightest knowledge. Kana thinks of Soroma and realizes the sheer helplessness that led Soroma to commit suicide but Kana resolves not to follow her. She faces her husband boldly, reveals everything and resolves to go forward, against the whole society. This is how the play 'Soroma' ends. The play was staged at the opening ceremony of the three-day long millennium drama festival by Nagarik Nattyangan on December 31 at the Guide House Auditorium. The play is written by Dipak Sen and directed by Lucky Enam. This is the thirtieth show of the play. Lucky Enam played the role of Kana and the roles of Asheque, Ronen and Ratan were played by Mahmudul Islam Selim, Nurul Hasnat Zilan and Imran Humayun Khan respectively. Gias Babu played the character of Ajay, the brother of Soroma. Mahmudul Islam Selim did a good job in the stage direction while costume designed by Tahmina Sharif Naz was suitable to the story. Nagarik Nattyangan is celebrating its fifth founding anniversary. The celebration began with a colourful rally at 3pm. The rally ended at the millennium tower built by the Nagarik Nattyangan at the Guide House premises. An Iftar party was thrown on the occasion. The inauguration ceremony took place at 6.30pm. Industry minister Tofael Ahmed was present as the chief guest. The president of Sammilito Sanskritik Jote Ramendu Majumder and general secretary of Bangladesh Group Theatre Federation Liakat Ali Lucky were present as special guests. Liakat Ali Lucky, in his speech, expressed deep gratitude to all the audience and persons related with Bangladesh theatre movement and he wished the best for Nagarik Nattyangan. Ramendu Majumder said, 'At the eve of this new millennium, it is high time that we can hope for a bright and luminous future for the theatre of our country.' Golam Haider, the general secretary of Nagarik Nattyangan, said that every drama of the group tries to send a message to its audience. Tofael Ahmed said that the group theatres of the country are working hard since our liberation, to uphold the glorious image of our country. The presider of the discussion meeting, Enamul Huq, expressed his firm resolution to carry on with the Nagarik Nattyangan and hoped to be pledge-bound under the common resolution to work for the development of the theatre movement of Bangladesh in the new millennium. The play 'Soroma' was staged after the inauguration and later a seminar on drama and a cultural programme took place, which continued till midnight with all the members of Nagarik Nattyangan welcoming the new millennium. Nagarik Nattyangan was founded on January 1, 1995 and since then the group has concentrated on production of drama close to life. With its first production 'Kholosh', an adaptation by Lucky Enam from the original of J.B.Priestly and directed by Enamul Huq, Nagarik Nattyangan entered the theatre arena on April 29, 1995. The second show of the play 'Grihabasi', the tenth and last production of the group was staged yesterday on the occasion of its founding anniversary. The play is written by Enamul Huq and directed by Lucky Enam. Nagarik Nattyangan has performed in Assam and Tripura. In the previous Nagarik Nattyotsovs, Nagarik Nattyangan organized Moitri Utsav where the other leading group theatres from Bangladesh and other countries were invited to perform. Bahurupee and Sundaram, the two Indian theatres performed in the previous founding anniversary festivals. The festival will conclude today with the staging of the play 'Janatar Rangashala', the fifth production of Nagarik Nattyangan. 'Janatar Rangashala' is an adaptation by Mojibur Rahman Dilu from the original play 'The Three Penny Opera' by Bertolt Brecht. Jamaluddin has directed the play in the first phase and Enamul Huq in the second.

title: Agora's raffle draw held
body: The New Year raffle draw of chain superstore Agora was held at Gulshan in the city on Wednesday, says a press release. Agora, a concern of Rahimafrooz Group, arranged the promotional campaign, which ran from December 21, 2002 to January 7, 2003, for its customers. The customers who purchased goods worth over Tk 700 from any of the Agora stores at Gulshan or Dhanmondi received raffle coupons. The raffle draw function was presided over by Rahimafrooz Superstores Ltd Managing Director Niaz Rahim. The raffle draw prizes include Dhaka-Cox's Bazar-Dhaka air ticket, electric oven, VCD player and cordless phone set.

title: Police to probe movie moghul
body: Aziz Mohammad Bhai, an industrialist and film producer has been placed on a two-day remand for interrogation, reports UNB. As defence counsel prayed for bail when he was produced before the CMM's court yesterday afternoon, the Court Inspector stood in opposition bringing the serious charges against the accused. "There are allegations that Aziz Mohammad Bhai is involved in film actor Sohel Chowdhury murder, using beautiful women in smuggling and supply of secret government information and documents abroad," Inspector Nakib Zaman said. Police prayed for a 10-day remand, but the magistrate granted two days. Aziz Bhai was arrested Wednesday evening from Gulshan area by Special Branch of police. He was taken to the court at about 3.45 pm. At one stage, he shook hands with his lawyer Barrister K S Nabi who opposed the remand prayer saying that all the allegations brought against his client are 'fictitious.' K S Nabi, the former Attorney-General, submitted that there were no specific charges against Aziz Bhai and no provision of police remand in the CrPC. "Police sought remand only to harass him," he said. Meanwhile, a 120-day detention order against Bhai will come into effect after the remand is over.

title: FM urges BNP chief to shun destructive politics
body: Foreign Minister Abdus Samad Azad yesterday called upon BNP Chief Khaleda Zia to act like a leader of responsible opposition party by shunning the path of destructive politics, reports BSS. "The opposition should play a vital role in the development of the country as it is a guiding force for strengthening of democracy," he said while speaking as the chief guest at a reception accorded to the newly appointed three cabinet ministers. Jatiya Sramik League organised the function at the historic Paltan maidan to accord reception to Food Minister Amir Hossain Amu, Commerce Minister Abdul Jalil and Health and Family Welfare Minister Sheikh Fazlul Karim Selim. The foreign minister said Begum Zia has made an unholy alliance with the anti-liberation and autocratic forces to destabilise peace in the country aimed at grabbing power by any means. "There is no alternative to coming to power without election. So you have to come to power by taking people's mandate," he said adding that people is the only force who would choose a party to rule the country by casting their vote in the next general election. Referring to the comments of Khaleda Zia in the businessmen's conference, he said the announcement of Khaleda Zia, that if necessary BNP would call hartal everyday, it was like a declaration of war against the nation and humanity. Azad also said that Begum Zia has not shown interest to sit for dialogue with Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina despite repeated attempts in this regard. "The BNP chief, who is surrounded by anti-liberation and autocratic forces, does not want to settle the issues through talks. On the other hand she wants to fish in the troubled waters," he added. The minister said the ill motives of Khaleda to destabilise peace by ignoring the Prime Minister's invitation for talks has been clear to the people of the country. Food Minister Amir Hossain Amu urged the members of Sramik League and other progressive people to build a strong resistance unitedly against the alliance of opposition political party. "The autocrats, Razakars and vote thieves have been united against the democratic, progressive and non-communal forces in the country," he said adding that it was the proper time to give a befitting reply to the anti-people alliance.

title: Feed industry rebounds as bird flu ebbs
body: The feed industry is recovering on the back of rising poultry farming in recent months, industry people said yesterday. "The situation is much better now. The winter has ended so the feed demand is starting to pick up," said Ihtesham Shahjahan, president of Feed Industries Association Bangladesh. Last year, the feed market shrank 26 percent to 20-22 lakh tonnes from a year ago, according to some operators, as thousands suspended farming due to outbreaks of avian influenza. This year, however, the attacks have petered out, which encouraged many to resume farming, said Shahjahan, also managing director of Quality Feeds Ltd. "The marginal farmers are returning after many days," said Fazle Rahim Khan, managing director of Aftab Bahumukhi Farms Ltd, which also makes feed. He said the price of day-old chicks needed for farming had been low last year, while market price for chicken and eggs were relatively better. "As a result, many existing farmers made substantial profits in quick bursts. Plus, it encouraged many small farmers to come back." Khan said feed sales started regaining from the middle of January, with Aftab registering 15-20 percent sales growth in February year-on-year. "The number of farmers has substantially increased in January and February. The feed demand in aquaculture farming has increased as well. It appears that everyone in the industry is happy.” Shahjahan said the whole feed industry might regain 50 percent of its lost sales this year. MM Khan, secretary general of Bangladesh Poultry Industries Association, had earlier told The Daily Star that some 5,000 farms came back to production in the last several months. Amid demands from poultry industry operators, the government earlier provided bird flu vaccinations in Gazipur and Kishoreganj districts. “Farmers are more courageous now because of the introduction of vaccination," Khan said, while predicting a good year for the poultry and feed sector.

title: Motor vehicle deal: CPD stresses need for multimodal strategy
body: Potential benefits of the motor vehicle agreement signed among the four South Asian nations can be maximised through developing a national multimodal comprehensive connectivity strategy, Centre for Policy Dialogue (CPD) said today. The civil society think-tank also called upon the government to build strong coordination among different ministries to materialise the gain to be arisen from an integrated sub-region. The CPD told this at a seminar on "Trade facilitation in South Asia through transport connectivity" at the Brac Inn in Dhaka with Prof Rehman Sobhan in the chair. Bangladesh, Bhutan, India and Nepal signed the deal on June 15 that would allow seamless movement of people, cargo and personal vehicles across the countries within the next few years.

title: Young man stabbed to death in city
body: A young man was stabbed to death by a gang of assailants near the Sayedabad bus terminal in the city Saturday night. The victim was identified as Ali Hossain Bhuiyan, 26, son of Sadek Ali, a resident of Sayedabad area, police and hospital sources said. According to Demra police, Ali, an alleged phensidyl trader, was murdered by the members of his rival group following a dispute over phensidyl trading in the area. Meanwhile, our hospital sources quoting relatives of the victim said, Ali was a roadside gasoline seller. Police later arrested two persons, Sohag and Kalam yesterday. They were accused in the murder case lodged by the father of the victim with Demra thana.

title: Shell extends Sangu drilling plan
body: Shell Bangladesh Exploration has extended its drilling programme in the Sangu gas field in the Bay of Bengal under Block 16. A Shell press release yesterday said that during the drilling of an appraisal well, "South Sangu-1" Shell discovered gas-bearing sandstone at a depth below 3300 meters. "Preliminary analysis of intermediate wireline log data indicate that South Sangu-1 intersected 34 gross metres of gas-bearing sandstone. The drilling of the well continues seeking deeper objectives," stated the release. Shell and its partners Cairn Energy and HBR Energy have undertaken the joint drilling programme under a Production Sharing Contract with Petrobangla. Petrobangla sources said that Shell faced difficulty during the drilling of the appraisal well due to some unforeseen geological formations. The British company Cairn struck the Sangu gas field in early 96 and developed it in a record time of 18 months. Last year, Cairn struck a deal with Shell Oil under which it transferred the operatorship of Block 15 and 16 to Shell.

title: Yeltsin goes
body: President Boris Yeltsin announced on national television today that he had resigned and presidential elections will be held within 90 days to replace him, reports AP. The announcement caught Russia by total surprise, and is likely to launch the country into yet another political crisis as parties scramble for unexpected presidential elections. Prime Minister Vladmir Putin, the country's most popular politician, immediately took control of the government and will serve as acting president until the elections. Looking pale and grim in a speech on national television, the 68-year-old Yeltsin said it was time for him to go. He asked Russians to forgive him for his mistakes and failing to realise their dreams after the fall of the Soviet Union. "Today, on the last day of the outgoing century, I resign," said Yeltsin, speaking in front of a gaily-decorated New Year's tree and a blue, red and white Russian flag with a golden Russian eagle. "I am stepping down ahead of term. I understand that I must do it and Russia must enter the new millennium with new politicians, with new faces, with new intelligent, strong, energetic people, and we who have been in power for many years must go," Yeltsin said. It was yet another unexpected move by Yeltsin, who has presided over Russia through eight tumultuous, often chaotic years. His attempts to build a market economy were deeply flawed by corruption and incompetence, and he became widely disliked by most Russians. Looking emotional, Yeltsin asked several times for forgiveness for not solving Russia's problems. "I beg your forgiveness for having failed to jump in one leap from the gray, stagnant, totalitarian past to the clear, rich and civilized future," he said. "I am leaving. I've done what I could," he added. The Russian stock market jumped to a 15-month high on the news, with dealers saying the hopes of strong new leadership after Yeltsin would boost the economy. Yeltsin turned over to Putin the nuclear suitcase, which contains the codes to launch nuclear weapons. Yeltsin also gave Putin medals symbolizing his presidential status and his presidential pen, while Russia's Orthodox Patriarch Alexy II looked on. Yeltsin then left for his country residence outside Moscow, and Putin convened an emergency Cabinet session. The Kremlin said, Yeltsin still plans to travel to Bethlehem next month for Orthodox Christmas celebrations. "The Yeltsin party of power has fallen," said Communist leader Gennady Zyuganov, who came in second in 1996 presidential elections. He called on his supporters to rally for a Communist presidential candidate. Under the Russian constitution, presidential elections must be held within 90 days of the president's resignation. The ITAR-Tass news agency said the presidential elections would be held around March 27. Putin, with effective control of the government, including state media, has a huge advantage in the race to succeed Yeltsin. Yeltsin, who has been hit by corruption allegations in recent months, reportedly had been looking for assurances for the safety of himself and his family when he steps down. Putin as president would be able to give Yeltsin the immunity he reportedly wants. Plagued for years by heart and other health problems, Yeltsin was often ill and out of sight during his second term. He spent many weeks sidelined at his country residence and was largely seen as a caretaker president. But Yeltsin continued to dominate Russian politics, despite his ill health. He easily defeated a Communist-led effort in May to impeach him and had dismissed four prime ministers in the last two years.

title: CCCI rally today
body: The Chittagong Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCCI) will hold a jubilant rally and take out a colourful procession in the port city today to celebrate the declaration of Chittagong as the commercial capital and allotment of land for CCCI-proposed World Trade Centre (WTC). The local businessmen and people from all walks of life will take part in the celebrations to be held at the Chittagong outer stadium at 10.30am. Earlier, a preparatory committee was formed with former CCCI vice-president MA Latif as its convenor and Faruq-e-Azam, Bir Protik, and C&F Association President AKM Akter Hossain as joint convenors to make the programme a success. At a press conference yesterday, the CCCI leaders said that thirty arches have been erected in the city on the occasion. CCCI president Amir Humayun Mahmud Chowdhury spoke of the need to develop infrastructural and other facilities to turn Chittagong into commercial capital. The CCCI president said that while the cabinet approved the proposal for commercial capital on January 6, Prime Minister Khaleda Zia directed the ministries concerned to implement 15 development projects that would be required for the commercial capital on an urgent basis. About the construction of WTC, the CCCI president said the process had already started and the physical work would start as soon as railway hands over the land. He further disclosed that air freight unit would start functioning at Chittagong port soon and it is likely to be inaugurated formally on January 18. CCCI senior vice-president Ershad Ullah, vice-president Monjur Ul Amin Chowdhury, the directors of CCCI and a number of businessmen attended the press conference.

title: President’s condition improving
body: The condition of President Zillur Rahman, who had been undergoing treatment at a Singapore hospital, had improved, family sources said yesterday. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina urged people to pray at all mosques and other religious institutions for the early recovery of the president. Zillur Rahman was flown to Singapore Sunday night and admitted to Mount Elizabeth Hospital yesterday morning. All necessary medical examinations and treatment of the president are going on under intensive observation of specialised physicians of the hospital. Zillur's son Nazmul Hassan Papan, a ruling Awami League lawmaker, who is attending to the president, told BSS by phone that Zillur was suffering from severe lung infection and that doctors began removing water from his lungs as his condition stabilized a little. Before being taken to Singapore, Zillur was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit of the Combined Military Hospital (CMH) in Dhaka Saturday night with respiratory problems. Bangabhaban official sources said the 83-year-old president was on respiratory support while boarding the aircraft. Zillur had been suffering from fever since Saturday morning and taken to CMH after he had developed breathing problems.

title: Magnitude 6.1 quake shakes Taiwan
body: An earthquake with a magnitude of at least 6.1 shook Taiwan on Wednesday, official agencies said, but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage. The US Geological Survey registered the quake with a magnitude of 6.3. The epicenter of the quake was near central Taiwan at a depth of about 15 km (9 miles), said Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau, which uses the Richter scale. Earthquakes occur frequently in Taiwan, which lies on a seismically active stretch of the Pacific basin. In September 1999, a 7.6 quake killed more than 2,400 people and destroyed or damaged 50,000 buildings.

title: The technology that could 'revolutionise' how people light the world
body: Kick-started by the invention of the light bulb, the way we illuminate our homes and our lives is ever-changing - particularly in a world where the challenge is to light more, but to consume less energy. But Mark Major, one of the world's leading lighting designers, believes we're at the early stages of a lighting revolution. "Changing technology makes me feel very clearly that this is as much of a revolution going on now as perhaps when gas went out and electric lighting came in," he says. But what is it that makes something beautifully lit, and what role does technological innovation play in illuminating both our buildings and our state of well-being? Major's work - along with his late partner Jonathan Speirs - is award-winning, credited with enhancing the atmosphere of already iconic structures. It is arguably Speirs + Major's most distinctive work, unmissable to Londoners, that displays this like none other: St. Paul's Cathedral. "It was a great privilege to work on that project," he says. "Probably one of the toughest assignments we've ever had. It took about five years in its execution to design and have the lighting fully delivered." The result is a building swathed in soft light - giving the building a sense of serenity in the hustle and bustle of Britain's capital city. Inside, it was an even bigger task. "When you're dealing with not just a heritage building, but a heritage building of that nature, you realise it was never really designed to be seen under artificial light in quite that way - it would have been seen in candlelight. "You're placing, in a way, a new interpretation on the building and its architecture after dark, and you have to be very careful how you do that." As well as tremendous buildings - Speirs + Major also work with more practical locations such as offices or restaurants, and even our streets. "On a very basic level," Major says, "Well-designed lighting in the streets of cities doesn't just keep you safe and secure, but also can really help to create a pleasant and interesting atmosphere. "It can bring out the colour and texture of the landscape, it can sort of direct you to places, it can play a number of different roles in the city that are more than simply enabling us to see - good lighting makes our cities more legible. "And I hope, as a result, more enjoyable." He envisions a future where streets light up as you walk down them, but get dimmer when no-one's around, saving energy. Not only this, but the light can be used to change the very mood of the street depending on the occasion - a delicate skill. "We all know the difference between a romantic candlelit supper for two, with that soft, warm, glowing light focal that makes your partner look wonderful, and sitting in a fast food restaurant under fluorescent lighting and what a grim experience that can be." This type of flexibility would not be possible with traditional filament bulbs. Advancements in light emitting diode (LED) technology means lighting specialists are able to come up with far more complex arrangements. "We've moved a long way from candles and gaslights," Major says. "LEDs are going to fundamentally revolutionise the way we work with light. "It's smaller, it's cooler, and the quality of LED lighting has improved so much. Warmer light, broader spectrum, better skin tones, better reproduction of colour - just the overall quality." But there are downsides with this revolution, he argues. "The more light we bring into the world, the greater some of the challenges become. "Research is beginning to rapidly prove that you can have too much of a good thing - we all know about light pollution." And it's not just human beings who would be affected, Major says. "Many creatures are adapted to the night - so by bringing along a lot of light we can really impact on their feeding habits, on their breeding patterns and all sorts of things. "So we can enrich our lives, but we have to be quite careful how we work with this industrial material."

title: Human chain at DU protesting assault on woman at TSC
body: The Dhaka University students formed a human chain on the campus yesterday protesting assault on a woman during New Year's celebration at TSC and sexual harassment on women throughout the country. The students under the banner of 'Students of Dhaka University Against Sexual Harassment' formed the chain at Aparajeo Bangla at around 11 am. Some teachers of the university expressed solidarity with the initiative. Different organisations also expressed solidarity with the students and joined the human chain. The organisations include Bangladesh Mahila Parishad, Bangladesh Chhatra Union, Bangladesh Chhatra Moitry, Sexual Harassment Resistance Stage, Suchana, Garments Sramik Oikya Forum, Anushandhan and Anneshan Pathchakra. The protesting students also announced that they would submit a memorandum to the vice-chancellor of the university tomorrow.

title: SECOND LEAST LIVEABLE BUT...
body: One can list a multitude of reasons to not visit Bangladesh -- never ending traffic jam, incessant power cuts, air heavy with dust and pollution and thousands upon thousands of people thronging the streets every single day! Dhaka was ranked the second least liveable city among the world's 140 cities in this year's Global Liveability Index released by the Economist Intelligence Unit. Now let's be clear, it cannot be denied that there are more charming spots on earth than Dhaka -- what with the chaotic traffic system where cars, buses, rickshaws, bikes, people, donkeys and chickens share public space. The public infrastructure and health system are not very inviting either -- as people die in hospital elevators due to long power cuts. Many other reasons are there why European visitors should stay away from Dhaka, but there are at least 10 reasons why one should visit the second least liveable city in the world. Women are all over the city. Females are much more visible than they were 10 years ago. The young generation, in particular, is seen flocking to universities and going abroad to earn international degrees from reputed universities. Women lead businesses, earn money, are interested in politics and want to be independent. Females will be an even greater force in the years to come. If you want to see and feel women's motivation, Dhaka is the place to go. 2. NEVER ALONE, NEVER BORING Are you lonely once in a while? Is your boss not talking to you? Do your friends never have time for you? If you feel like you want a bit more attention, Dhaka is your city. Hundreds of rickshaw-pullers are eager to take you on board. If you decide to grab tea in a local tea-stall, you can be sure to get involved in discussions. So if you feel neglected, just take a walk through Dhaka. The city offers you thousands of faces; Bangladesh as a whole has about 1,000 people per square kilometre. That is four to five times more than what we experience in Switzerland, for example. So if you want to live the real "density-stress", here you go! Dhaka is never boring, I promise. 3. YOUNG PEOPLE Are you sick of the senile western cities, where more money is spent on elderly institutions than on anything else? Where demographics dominate every discussion? If yes, then Dhaka will be a refreshing change. Here, the young outnumber the old by miles. If you walk down the road and look at all the young faces -- which smile at you and are not looking into some digital device like back home -- you are reminded of your own youth, memories come flooding back. In the midst of young people, you feel young again. And unlike young people in Europe, young Bangladeshis are always up for a chat. 4. YES, WE CAN! The city is currently being rebuilt. Around every corner crumbling old buildings are taken down and replaced by surprisingly good architecture and modern designs. Even the sidewalks are being improved. Life in the city gets dangerous sometimes. The footpaths, which resemble Swiss cheese rather than sidewalks, can be a nightmare at times. Given that change is brewing, you can be there to see it. 5. OLD DHAKA The old part of the city is the craziest mix between modern life and medieval age you have ever seen. Chickens are slaughtered on the footpath next to a man repairing an iPhone 5. The roads in Old Dhaka are so narrow and intertwined and the centre so densely populated, you are sure to lose your way. So do take a native with you if you go there or you will have to stay there forever. But Old Dhaka is the ultimate place to go if you want to experience the chaotic yet oh so beautiful Dhaka. 6. DAY IS NIGHT AND NIGHT IS DAY Aren't you often frustrated if you can't find a warm dish after 10:00pm in European cities? In my home country, Switzerland, it is difficult to even find a cold dish after midnight. But in Dhaka, you will find warm food round-the-clock. Bangladeshis make no big difference between night and day. Little lights and fire sparkling along the streets are with you all night long and indicate where you are most likely to find a bite to eat -- at any time. And whereas in our world the roads after 10:00pm are often as dead as a cemetery, life in Dhaka goes on all night long. 7. FORKS AND KNIVES Compared to 10 years ago, many things in the city have changed already. Not only many more people wear western clothes (less lunghi), couples walk hand-in-hand through parks (not quite what you would expect in a Muslim country), and rickshaw-pullers communicate with their customers through mobile phones. One does not only find a cosy atmosphere and excellent food, the plate also comes automatically with forks and knives for visitors. 8. REAL VEGETABLES AND FRUITS Let's stay with food for a second longer. We in the West suffer from tasteless bananas, unripe mangos, and watery tomatoes. They are harvested too early in order to be shipped to us. That is why you will fall in love with Dhaka immediately if you like vegetables and fruits. At every corner of the city you'll find people displaying fruits and vegetables of the best quality. Just to look at the colourful display is a pleasure. Tasting them every morning for breakfast is like heaven. 9. BETTER THAN A BURNOUT CLINIC Are you stressed and feel like you would like to run on a lower gear for a while? People in the West are flocking to so called burnout clinics to get relief from their workload and stress. A stay in Dhaka would provide the same cure and would be much more fun than a clinic, and most probably even cheaper. Because whatever you plan to do in Dhaka, pressure of time does not exist as traffic in the city dictates your programme. You will probably hang around most of the time waiting for traffic jams to dissolve. So running on a high gear most of the time is impossible, giving you all the free time for reading, socialising and doing nothing as you always wished. Your blood pressure will most certainly decrease and there is no need for the expensive tranquiliser your doctor back home prescribed you to. You will be amazed at how much patience you can develop. 10. AN ORGANISED CHAOS Last but not least the organised chaos in the least liveable city of the world has a charming side to it. The honking horns, bells of rickshaws, the chatter and laughter of people, the cook-a-doodle-doo around the corner, and the colours in the bazaar all add to its charm. It is a world of mysteries and secrets to us who come from a frantically over-organised life where every minute of our day is scheduled and every train, which is a minute late, causes grim remarks. And surprisingly enough: most things you plan to do in Dhaka work out -- usually just a little later than you had planned. Yes -- Dhaka in many ways is a horrible place to live. And surprisingly enough: most things you plan to do in Dhaka work out -- usually just a little later than you had planned. Yes -- Dhaka in many ways is a horrible place to live. But nevertheless there are enough reasons to visit this unique metropolis. So hurry up and book a flight to Dhaka as long as the city is still the second least liveable city on earth. Because be assured: times change. Don't be late!

title: Call to protect parliamentary democracy
body: Political Adviser to the Prime Minister Dr S A Malek urged all, especially the intellectuals, yesterday to come forward to protect parliamentary democracy in the country, reports BSS. "Parliamentary democracy is now at stake after the leader of the opposition shut down her door to talks to resolve political stalemate", he said while addressing a discussion on "Role of the Opposition in Parliamentary Democracy". He said: "It is very unfortunate that the opposition leader has categorically rejected Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina's offer to resolve the political standoff through dialogue, leaving no option for the government to explore." Dr Malek said there had been the possibility of enshrining parliamentary democracy in the country when Awami League led by Sheikh Hasina assumed office after winning people's mandate in free and fair general elections on June 12, 1996. "But a certain quarter became active to foil parliamentary democracy as soon as Sheikh Hasina took office," he said, adding, "Begum Zia threatened to oust the present government just 90 days after it assumed power." Dr Malek called upon the intellectuals not to hesitate to protect democracy at a time when opposition political parties are mapping out a sinister blueprint to destroy it. The discussion was also addressed by Chairman of Public Administration Reform Commission (PARC) A T M Shamsul Huq, General Secretary of Sangsadia Ganotantra Parishad Dr Harun-ur-Rashid, Vice-Chancellor of Dhaka University Dr A K Azad Chowdhury, Pro-Vice Chancellor Mohammad Shahadat Ali, Dr Shamsul Huda Harun, Prof Ali Asgar, Prof Imamul Huq, Prof Mejbauddin Ahmed, Chairman of Bangladesh Muktijodda Central Command Council Principal Ahad Chowdhury, and President of Bangladesh Federal Union of Journalist (BFUJ) Abul Kalam Azad. Justice K M Sobhan presided over the function. He said: 'The Opposition is the alternative government in a parliamentary democracy. If the government fails to run the state, the opposition takes power as an alternative government in the parliamentary system of government." He said the opposition was not following the parliamentary norms and practices. "It is not clear to many of us on which grounds the opposition staged walkout within five minutes on the first day's sitting of parliament," he added. Criticising opposition leader Begum Khaleda Zia for her declaration that hartal will be used to create a deadlock, Justice Sobhan said the people will pay eventually for such actions. He also questioned the logic of the anti-government movement of the opposition. Dr Shamsul Huda Harun said, "No government would be able to run the country, if the opposition does not play its due role in a parliamentary democracy."

title: Nat'l Social Service Day observed
body: The National Social Service Day was observed for the first time across the country in a befitting manner yesterday, reports BSS. Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina last year announced that henceforth January 2 every year would be observed as National Social Service Day to carry forward the social welfare activities. The theme of this year is "service to all and development." Inaugurating the day's programme at the newly constructed Social Service Directorate building at Agargaon in the city, Political Advisor to the Prime Minister Dr S A Malek said Father of the Nation Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman had tried to develop society through undertaking various social service oriented activities. Listing various social service programmes taken by the government, Dr Malek said Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina has been working relentlessly to finish the unfinished tasks of the Bangabandhu for the greater benefit of the poor. Dr Malek said 'Ashrayan' project, old age allowance and 'Shanti Nibash' are some social service oriented programmes of the government that would help assuage the sufferings of the teeming millions.

title: JUTA polls Feb 9
body: Election of a 15-member executive body of Jahangirnagar University Teachers' Association (JUTA) will be held on February 9. The election commission will publish the voters' list on January 31. The last date for submitting nomination papers is February 3 when the commission will also scrutinise those. The last date for withdrawal of nomination papers is February 5. The election commission will publish the final list of the candidates on the same day. The election will be held at the University Teachers-Officers' Club from 9:00 am to 1:00 pm. Some 250 teachers are likely to cast their votes in the upcoming JUTA election to elect a president, a vice-president, a treasurer, a general secretary, a joint-secretary and 10 general members.

title: 2 held with Yaba in Gopalganj
body: Two drug peddlers were held with 150 Yaba tablets in Gopalganj on Thursday night. The arrestees are Palash Khan, 28 and Mihir Chandra Dey, 22. Both of them are resident of Kashiani sadar upazila in the district. Acting on a tip-off, a team of Detective Branch of police arrested the people from Gopinathpur area. A case filed in this connection.

title: Activists fight back
body: The truth is many shades of grey. There are thousands of young people who are filling the ranks of new organisations like Not In Our Name, United For Peace, Drum (Deshis Rising Up in Movement), SAPBR (South Asians against Police Brutality & Racism) and International ANSWER (Act Now to Stop War & End Racism). But you wouldn't know all this from watching CNN! The mainstream press is working overtime to hide these facts. But behind the scenes, on the streets, through the Internet and in alternative media outlets, a resistance movement is growing. WHEN bad times come, there can also be a positive side effect. It wakes many of us from lethargy and apathy. That is what is happening in an America changed by September 11. As civil liberties and immigrant rights are attacked, and the Pentagon beats the war-drums, the activist community is waking up and mobilizing in unprecedented numbers. They are taking their dissent to the streets, to the college campuses, and to the internet. During the 1960's Vietnam protests, the slogan was "Hell No, We Won't Go". In 2003, the slogan is "Not In Our Name." I arrived here for college thirteen years ago. For the first few years, many of our activist projects in the US were involved with Bangladesh. As recent arrivals from Bangladesh, we were still intimately connected with issues "back home". Fundraising for floods, campus events, letters to the editor -- the usual things. The earliest petition we wrote was in the early '90s, urging ISNA (Islamic Society of North America) to rescind a conference invitation to war criminal Ghulam Azam. That petition did not succeed in convincing ISNA. Instead, I got a hostile call from one of their officers. The man on the phone called me "brother" (which always make me suspicious) and asked me to amend my ways -- as if speaking out against a 1971 war criminal was blasphemy. We had the wind briefly taken out of our sails by that failure, but the activism continued. Over the years, many more Bangladesh petitions were written. The Shobak. Org website's back pages are littered with petitions for Badruddin Omar (the banned 21st February article), Farhad Mazhar (arrest after "Ansar rebellion" article), Rahnuma Ahmed (JU campus sexual harassment cases), and others. After a few years of living here, our activism shifted to take on more of our immediate surroundings. We started becoming involved in "American issues." The first Gulf War came along, our main project became anti-war protests. A South Asian identity became less important, this was a larger struggle against imperialist adventures. "No Blood For Oil" t-shirts were everywhere. With the end of that war, the peace movement ran out of steam. Domestic crises engaged us. A doctor was shot dead outside an abortion clinic. People formed human chains to protect the clinics. Affirmative Action was under attack in colleges, and we marched with Black students to protest. Genetically Modified foods became a hot topic, and neighborhoods petitioned supermarkets to start carrying organic food. The Globalization movement started forming, culminating in the watershed protests at Seattle. Then came the xenophobia tide led by California's Proposition 187 and Peter Brimelow's book "ALIEN NATION". Although Brimelow was a British immigrant, he spoke out against the "wrong type of immigrants" (smelly brown ones). The first attack on the World Trade Centre happened (everything in our present day is like a sequel to an old film)... Immigrants were suddenly in the spotlight. But the Oklahoma bombing helped push things in the other direction. When Timothy McVeigh was arrested, Connie Chung and other TV reporters who had immediately blamed Arabs were on the defensive. White extremists were a problem for those who wanted to pin all terrorism on the "dark hordes". During this phase of the struggle, we found new allies among the country's huge Latino population. Returning home one night, I saw a convoy of police cars near my Hell's Kitchen apartment. "Must be an accident," I thought. The next morning I learnt that Patrick Dorismond had been shot on that block, by a police officer who thought he was reaching for a gun. Investigations found that he was unarmed! Soon after that, Amadou Diallo was shot 41 times by the police -- he was only reaching for his wallet! New York city exploded with pent-up racial tension. A black man in Harlem ran in front of a TV camera, holding up his one-year old baby. "Shoot him now," he screamed, "You'll do it anyway. There ain't no place for a 'nigger' in this country." Even though Amadou was an immigrant, the struggle for him became a Black struggle. Although these were bad times, it was exhilarating to go to rallies in Harlem and see so many Asian faces along with Black faces. When one rally blocked Times Square, the plastic handcuffs came out and police started chasing the protesters and herding them into vans. As we ran away from the police, I found myself running next to a co-worker from my office. "What are you doing here?" she said. "Why shouldn't I be here?" I replied. Both of us had worked at a corporate television network for two years without being aware of each other's politics -- we had kept our secrets well. Protestors started calling New York a "police state". People were constantly protesting the NYPD's tactics. The police were getting used to meeting protesters who would hold up a wallet and chant, "Police Training 101/It's a wallet not a gun" and "It doesn't take 41/To kill a man without a gun". The Community board started putting up pacification posters that read, "New York needs CPR= Community, Police, Respect." People would deface or rip down those posters. Like an army under siege, the police responded by getting more aggressive. Transportation Alternatives arranged monthly bicycle rides where we bikers would take over city streets and bike down to the World Trade Centre -- to show support for car-free streets. These events were very innocuous; we had never had any trouble. That year, I watched horrified as our bike convoy got stopped, again at Times Square, and police started grabbing the leaders and shoving them into vans. Arrested for riding a bike, no one got believe it! Infuriated riders started head butting the police, inflaming the crowd further. Shouts of "Shame, Shame" filled the air. Everything was volatile in New York. Mayor Giuliani managed to infuriate people no matter what he did. The Brooklyn Museum showed England's "Sensation" art exhibit. Giuliani tried to block the show, claiming it was anti-church. People lined up around the block to get in, their way of giving the middle finger to "Herr Giuliani". When more cases of police brutality happened, the Mayor tried to talk about falling crime rates (which, to give the devil his due, were true)-- but no one was listening. Then came September 11. Overnight, the whole city changed. The once-hated NYPD police became heroes (deservedly), as did the Fire Department. With a huge death toll, they earned our respect. Young kids, who were once so hostile to the police, now nodded in grudging respect. Mayor Giuliani garnered many positive reviews by speaking out against attacks on immigrants, and putting convoys of police in front of Arab stores in Brooklyn. TIME magazine put him on the cover as "Man Of The Year" and even my activist friends did not complain. These were different times now. But after September 11 came the new anti-immigrant backlash. Not so much Muslim-phobia, as it was phobia of the new and different. In America's recent past, the Irish, Italian, Spanish, Jews, Blacks and East Asians were being called "Mick", "Wop", "Spic", "Kike", "Nigger" and "Chink". I once saw a restaurant sign from the 1930s that read "No Irish, No Blacks, No Dogs". Arabs and Muslims were just the newest group to receive the baton of hatred that had been passed down through generations. But there are some bright spots as well. The average American is not as xenophobic as 10 years ago; there are many more open-minded people. Some of the strongest voices for immigrant rights come from white Americans who have lived here for generations. The Jewish community, which was refused permission to immigrate during the Holocaust, has come out against INS Registrations. The Japanese-American community, remembering their own forced internments in 1940, has organized their own rallies. The ACLU (American Civil Liberties Union) is a strong voice for civil liberties, and their membership has jumped since 9/11. But there is also a deadly combination of a powerful White House, and a Republican-controlled Senate, Congress, and Supreme Court. What is to be feared are the draconian immigration and surveillance laws that they will pass in these moments. The activist fight is now against passage of those laws. To quote the over-used Dickens line: "It was the best of times, it was the worst of times." The unprecedented attack on civil liberties, the immigration crackdown and the impending war on Iraq have mobilised many thousands of activists. At the October 26th Washington DC rally, 200,000 people showed up. I was stunned at the sheer size of the rally and the enthusiasm of the crowd. A friend and I started doing a Bengali chant "Mani Na, Manbo Na." Three teenagers came over and asked us what it meant. Then they tried to imitate us, mangling the words in their mid-western accents. Finally giving up, one of them gave me a "high five" and ran off to join a large group of high school students. There they resumed their previous chant: "Hell no we won't go/We won't kill for Texaco!" I stared at them amazed -- they were not even old enough to go to war, and here they were, protesting with gusto! Don't believe the hype about lazy, video game playing, apathetic teenagers. The truth is many shades of grey. There are thousands of young people who are filling the ranks of new organisations like Not In Our Name, United For Peace, Drum (Deshis Rising Up in Movement), SAPBR (South Asians against Police Brutality & Racism) and International ANSWER (Act Now to Stop War & End Racism). But you wouldn't know all this from watching CNN! The mainstream press is working overtime to hide these facts. But behind the scenes, on the streets, through the Internet and in alternative media outlets, a resistance movement is growing. January 18th is the next big anti-war rally in Washington DC. Thousands make their voices heard again. They are taking the "Pledge Of Resistance" and saying: "Not in our name will you wage endless war Not by our mouths Will we let fear silence us Another world is possible and we pledge to make it real." Naeem Mohaiemen runs Shobak.Org, a website for "Outsider Asian Voices".

title: Don't Force People to Lose Faith in Polls
body: THANKS to the hardened position of both the ruling and the opposition parties, the country's electoral process itself stands largely redefined at present. Boycott, widespread violence and distressingly poor voter turnout have marked all the elections held in recent times, the Chittagong City Corporation polls being the latest on the list. Gunshots and bomb blasts throughout the day turned the port city into a veritable battle-ground. While the opposition activists engaged in a day-long brawl with the law enforcers, majority of the electorate preferred staying indoors to exercising their right to franchise. The net result has been yet another election under the present government that can be called anything but participatory. While the opposition's the boycott of process told upon the credibility of the elections, poor voter turnout essentially decimated the representative character of the local government bodies. Similar has been the case with the recent by-elections to Tangail-8, Serajganj-7, Rajshahi-1 and Kishoreganj-1 constituencies late last year. Rationality of the opposition resolution to boycott any election under the incumbent chief election commissioner and government is indeed disputable and, in fact, this paper has vehemently criticised such a hardened position editorially on several occasion. Appallingly, in the midst of intense debate over the political position of the 'combatants', we have failed to appreciate the erosion the stand-off is causing to the country's democratic institutions. Already, the parliament has become a casualty of the prevailing deadlock. By pushing such unilateral and violence-prone elections the government is actually taxing the electorate's patience which is manifestly running out. The poor turnout in successive polls is a proof of that. It could easily have worked on ways to woo the opposition into the electoral fray through negotiations. Towards that end, the first step should have been deferment of the polls. In fact, the Election Commission had reportedly advised the government likewise. But the latter didn't budge and the one-sided elections and hartal were forced upon the Chittagonians. We are afraid that if the trend continues it will eventually leave the country with an electorate indifferent to the electoral process itself. The question is: whether the politicians are aware of that.

title: Madhu Mela begins today
body: JESSORE, Jan 24: Madhu Mela-2000, a week-long festival marking the 176th birth anniversary of Poet Michael Madhusudan Dutta begins at village Sagardari under Keshabpur thana tomorrow. Education Minister ASHK Sadique will inaugurate the festival at 10.30 am. State Minister for Power, Energy and Mineral Resources Prof Rafiqul Islam, Tabibur Rahman Sardar, Khan Tipu Sultan, Ali Reza, and Shah Hadiuzzaman, among others, will attend the inaugural function. Secretary of the Cultural Affairs Ministry Syed Abdur Rob will preside.

title: Shops, godown gutted at Barisal
body: BARISAL, Jan 24: Some hardware shops and a godown were gutted in a fire in the early hours of today in Hatkhola area of the town, reports BSS. The fire originated from a store and soon engulfed the adjacent shops and the godown at around 5-30 am, fire brigade sources said. Critically injured Sajal, 35, and an unidentified businessman were admitted to Sher-e-Bangla Medical College Hospital for treatment. Firefighters from Barisal and Jhalakati rushed to the spot and extinguished the blaze after an hour. Chief Whip Abul Hasanat Abdullah, State Minister for Jute and Textiles AK Faizul Huq, Divisional Commissioner M Yahia Mollah, deputy commissioner and police super visited the place this morning. They assured the businessmen of necessary help.

title: Buet closed amid fear of unrest
body: The Buet has been closed for an indefinite period after some unruly students vandalised its academic buildings, demanding postponement of term final exams. All resident students were instructed to vacate halls by 5:00pm yesterday, according to a notice published by the Bangladesh University of Engineering and Technology (Buet). The authorities claimed that a group of "unruly" students confined the vice-chancellor (VC), registrar and students' welfare director to the VC's office on Tuesday, demanding postponement of the exams. On Wednesday night, they besieged the teachers' residential area and vandalised some academic buildings. "Because of this, the overall law and order in the university has deteriorated," said the notice, signed by Registrar AKM Masud. Under these circumstances, all academic activities will remain suspended until the security of teachers, students and staffs is ensured, and the congenial environment for education is restored, it added. The students said they demanded holding the exams after the Eid-ul-Fitr vacation instead of the scheduled date of June 27. They could not prepare themselves for the exams due to some unscheduled closure of the university in recent times, they claimed. "But the sudden closure of the university has created an uncertain situation on academic activities," said one of the students, wishing not to be named. Buet VC Khaleda Ekram, now staying abroad, would take necessary steps on the issue after her return, said the university sources. Despite repeated attempts, Student Welfare Director Delwar Hossain could not be reached for his comments.

title: Div III soccer
body: Lalbagh Sporting Club recorded a 2-0 victory over Rayerbazar Athletics Club in one of the two Third Division Football Super league matches played at the ground adjacent to Dhaka Stadium yesterday. In a one-sided affair, Shameem and Monir struck one goal each in the first half to guide their side to their third victory of the league. With the win, Lalbagh finished fourth in the eight-team league having raised their point-tally to nine. On the other hand, it was the fourth defeat for Rayerbazar which kept them second from the bottom with their previous collection of five points. In the day's other match, Matuail Udayan Sangha and Deepali Jubo Sangha shared points with a 3-3 draw. In a see-saw affair, Ripon struck twice while Rana added the other for Matuail while Wahid, Rafique and Nizam scored one apiece for Deepali. The draw, Matuail rolled up their campaign with nine points from seven matches while Deepali finished at the last having collected two point.

title: 2-2 draw for BD girls
body: After two consecutive defeats, Bangladesh played out a 2-2 draw against their Tajikistan counterparts in the AFC (Asian Football Confederation) U-14 Girl's Regional Championship in Sri Lanka yesterday. Bangladesh, who lost to Iran 0-5 and India 1-5, went ahead against Tajikistan with a six-minute strike from Krishna Rani before Safarova levelled the margin for Tajikistan in the 35th minute. Bangladesh restored the lead three minutes later with a strike from Marzia but Safarova again rescued Tajikistan in the 69th minute to share points with Bangladesh. Bangladesh will play their fourth match against Bhutan on Saturday.

title: Boy killed in Jhalakati road accident
body: A little boy was killed in a road accident in Ichhaneel area of the town Sunday. The victim was identified as Shohag, 9, son of Hossain Hawlader of village Taruli in Sadar upazila. Shohag was wounded critically when he was knocked down by a bus in the area at about 10am and died at Jhalakati Sadar Hospital shortly after admission. Meanwhile, an elderly man was injured seriously in another road accident in Protap area on Jhalakati-Barisal road on the day.

title: Sarbahara leader dies during army interrogation
body: A leader of the outlawed Sarbahara Party, who was arrested by members of the joint forces, died of 'heart attack' during interrogation at Ataikola, Pabna. Nasir Uddin, 35, was arrested by a team of the joint forces at Ataikola for suspected involvement in criminal activities. Our Pabna correspondent reports that the joint forces arrested Nasir from a wedding party at a village in Sathyia Monday evening. He was later taken to Ataikola to identify the body of a slaughtered young man. Nasir identified the dead as Nayan of Salgari of Pabna town. He also said Nayan, a member of his gang, was killed as per his instruction. Nasir collapsed after making the confessional statement, according to the local witnesses. Police and army men rushed him to the Pabna Sadar Hospital where the on-duty doctors declared him dead. Police said he was a heart patient and they found medicine for heart ailments in his pocket. The postmortem report said there were no marks of injuries in his body. Our correspondent also adds that the joint forces arrested two listed criminals from different parts of the district during the drive. In Tangail, the joint forces arrested one person and seized a revolver, a pipe gun and bullets from Pankata of Dhanbari upazila, our correspondent reports. Our Rajbari correspondent reports that the joint forces arrested three criminals from different parts of the district. They are Afzal, a gang leader, and two of his accomplices, Reazul Karim and Sunny. They also arrested Budy from his village Horindanga in Pangsha upazila with one pistol and some bullets. In Kushtia, the joint forces arrested three people and recovered a firearm from different parts of the district, our correspondent reports. A team of the joint forces raided the residence of Sihab at Taragunia, arrested him and his associate Liton, and recovered a pipe gun from his possession. Later, the joint forces arrested a Jubo League leader, Masud Rana alias Pinu from the same area. Our Barisal correspondent reports that the joint forces arrested two people from different parts of the district. A team of the joint forces arrested Babul Talukder, a BNP leader from Awaliapur of Bakerganj upazila and recovered a pipe gun along with bullets and crackers. In another raid, they arrested a notorious criminal from Barguna district town. The joint forces arrested 79 people, including 16 listed criminals, from different parts of the country in the 24 hours ending at 8:00am yesterday. They also seized 17 firearms including one pistol, six guns, three pipe guns, six shotguns and a G-3 rifle along with 10 bullets during the period, according to a home ministry press release. The latest spate of arrests pushed the number of people rounded up since the start of the anti-crime crackdown on October 17 to 11,119, including 2,443 listed criminals. The joint forces have so far seized 2,011 firearms and 29,745 rounds of ammunition. The police headquarters in a press release yesterday said they rounded up 1,237 people, including 12 identified criminals from different parts of the country in the 24 hours ending at 6:00am yesterday. During the drive, police also recovered four firearms, one other weapon and two bombs, the press release added. The Dhaka Metropolitan Police in a press release yesterday said they arrested 211 people, including 32 accused in different cases during a special drive in the city.

title: Bangabhaban bid to broker deal fails
body: A presidential attempt to forge a negotiation between the country's two conflicting political camps was nipped in the bud yesterday as opposition rejected his proposition. An hour before the Jatiya Sangsad went into session at 4:05 pm yesterday, President Justice Shahabuddin Ahmed requested the BNP secretary general over telephone to join the parliament session and call off the 18-hour hartal beginning this morning, sources in the BNP said. If the opposition agreed to the proposal, the President assured the BNP leader that he would use his good office so that the governing party deferred the already announced schedule for the municipal elections to a date acceptable to the opposition, the sources added. When BNP secretary general Abdul Mannan Bhuiyan pointed out to the President that the resignation of Chief Election Commissioner was very important to the opposition, the President said that it was not possible 'right at the moment', according to the sources. Bhuiyan, however, communicated the presidential proposal to BNP chairperson Khaleda Zia, who eventually found the proposition to be unacceptable, a top ranking BNP leader told The Daily Star. While talking with her party secretary general on the issue, Khaleda Zia also told him that the opposition did not have any room for compromise over the CEC's resignation. Besides, she wanted to know whether the ruling party had contacted any BNP leader. On a negative reply from Bhuiyan, she told him that it was useless to consider the question of attending the inaugural session or calling off the countrywide hartal. Later, Bhuiyan regretted the President's proposal, and then the President entered the House at 6:00 pm to deliver his address with most opposition benches empty. Meanwhile, Telecommunication Minister Mohammad Nasim told The Daily Star that the ruling party had so far made no communication with the opposition for a dialogue. He was rather optimistic that the opposition would join the session when it resumes on January 31. "I see no reason for the opposition to stay away from parliament. Besides, the opposition only said that it would boycott presidential speech - not the entire session."

title: To tackle or not to tackle?
body: MILAN, Feb 3 (AFP): "Who wants to end up like Ciro Ferrara, with a broken leg and no chance of the World Cup finals?" That's the question which Italian club coaches are hoping their players won't be asking themselves too often in the coming weeks after the Juventus and international defender ruled himself out of France '98 on Sunday. The next few months are crucial for Serie A sides, who are vying for the league title, the Italian Cup and all three European Cup competitions. Their coaches, some of whose jobs could be at stake, will be expecting them to risk everything in the headlong rush towards a trophy. However, a great many players here in the Serie A, whether they're European, South American or African, are also expecting to play in the World Cup finals soon after the season ends. Ferrara's total commitment to the Juventus cause, seen in the 50-50 ball he lunged for on Sunday against Lecce, means that he is now certain to watch the finals at home on television. How many will now want to follow his example? Who really wants to rip a thigh muscle two weeks before flying to France? The fear of missing the tournament of a lifetime in a single tackle is very real. However, players and coaches claimed this week that there were even greater fears for the players - failure to get picked in the first place, or the risk of an even more serious injury by holding themselves back. Pierluigi Casiraghi, who will lead Italy's attack at France '98, said: "I'm sorry for Ferrara, but no player who's line for a place at the World Cup finals should be influenced by incidents like that. "In this game, injuries can happen at any time, even in training. A footballer should just concentrate on playing football. End of story."And he added: "The moment you start being frightened of getting hurt, that's just when you can really get seriously injured."Juventus coach Marcello Lippi, whose team is packed with internationals and is on course for the league title, the European Cup and the Italian Cup, also hopes there will be no Ferrara-effect on his teammates. "All the Serie A players are true professionals, and are used to the fast and physically demanding football that's being played today," Lippi said. "They know the risks. I don't think that what happened to Ferrara is going to make people start taking things easier, or make them reluctant to throw themselves at a loose ball. Fear always increases the risks of getting hurt."Inter Milan's latest hero, Uruguayan striker Alvaro Recoba, also believes that players will still give everything in the months ahead. But he also reckons the injury issue may yet re-surface, this time as an excuse. "In Italy, even friendlies are played at 100 per cent," said the 21-year-old, whose country failed to qualify for France '98. "So I don't think the World Cup finals will influence the way people play. I've got the example here from my teammates - Ronaldo, Youri Djorkaeff and Ivan Zamorano will be among the stars of the tournament. They never hold anything back. They're just like Ferrara. "They may play well, or they might not play well in some matches, but I've never seen them back off from the ball.""I think this talk about the World Cup influencing players might often be used as an excuse, as a way of covering things up."

title: US takes hard line on Saddam's latest ultimatums
body: WASHINGTON, Jan 19: Responding to Saddam Hussein's latest ultimatums, US officials stressed Sunday that Iraq not only must allow weapons inspections but must show a commitment to peace before crippling trade sanctions can end, reports AP. Republican leaders went further. They said it's time for the United States to issue its own ultimatum that the Iraqi president must either cooperate or face US military retaliation. "The burden of proof is on Saddam Hussein," Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said on NBC television. "The bottom line here is, has Saddam isolated himself by not fulfilling the obligations that have been laid on him by the Security Council."Saddam, in a speech Saturday marking the seventh anniversary of the Gulf War, threatened to bar future UN weapons inspections if sanctions against Iraq are not lifted. Widespread military training of Iraqis was ordered. Saddam's speech also came on the eve of a visit to Baghdad by chief UN arms inspector Richard Butler. He said he will state plainly to the Iraqis that the inspection teams must have total freedom of movement, including access to presidential palaces that the Iraqis have declared off limits. "There can be no such sanctuary," Butler said on CNN. "That's what I will be putting before (Iraqi Deputy Prime Minister) Tariq Aziz."Administration officials insisted the policy of applying diplomatic pressure through the United Nations is working. "There are no prospects of sanctions being lifted," said Bill Richardson, America's UN ambassador. Saddam has "got the (UN) Security Council against him and we have once again a state of desperation on his part," Richardson said on ABC television. "I don't want to saber-rattle," he said, but "What Ambassador Butler's trip brings back will be a very important threshold."White House National Security Adviser Sandy Berger repeated on CBS television that the United States is prepared to use unilateral military force against Iraq if that becomes necessary. But Republican Sen John McCain told CBS that the time has come for an ultimatum. He said military action now appears inevitable. And unlike the limited military strikes of the past that did little damage to Saddam, McCain said, this time the attacks should be crushing. He said there should be sustained air operations against Saddam's Republican Guard and his facilities, including his palaces. "It's time that he understood that we're serious about complying with the agreements signed," McCain said. Republican Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott also urged a more forceful US policy against Iraq. "We cannot tolerate or allow him to do what he is threatening to do," he said on CNN. Iraq's ambassador to the United Nations, Nizar Hamdoon, appearing on Fox and NBC, said Saddam had no choice but to set a deadline for an end to the inspections. They are unfair, Hamdoon said, and US policy has been to continue sanctions even if Iraq proves it no longer has weapons of mass destruction. He strongly denied recent reports that Iraq has used human subjects to test its chemical weapons. Meanwhile, as Iraq steps up preparation for a possible military confrontation over UN arms inspections, the chief international inspector is travelling to Baghdad for talks with Iraqi leaders. Richard Butler's visit today comes at a time of renewed tensions between Iraq and the United States, the chief proponent of the inspections. Iraqi officials, fearing an American military strike, urged residents Sunday to volunteer for weapons training. Vice President Taha Yassin Ramadan accused the United States of "increasing its aggressive stands" to prolong UN economic sanctions. Reuter adds: Iraq declared holy war on UN sanctions today, calling for a one-million volunteer force to push for an end to the seven-year-old embargo it says has caused widespread starvation and death. "We are determined to carry out a great Jihad to lift sanctions," Vice-President Taha Yassin Ramadan said. "There is no alternative to this after seven years of patience and cooperation with the United Nations and its committees."However, Washington immediately rejected Baghdad's ultimatum and insisted that Iraq must first comply with all UN resolutions for sanctions to be lifted. "It is not upto Saddam Hussein to be offering this kind of ultimatum ... sanctions will stay on until he carries out his obligations, which is to come clean on the weapons of mass destruction," Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said in Washington. Official Iraqi News Agency (INA) quoted Ramadan as saying one million people, men and women, would be given weapons training in a volunteer force from the start of next month. Iraq called on people early today to register for the training by next month. "The Defence Ministry calls on all Iraqi men and women ... to enlist in popular training which will take place in all governorates of the country from the first of February," the agency said.

title: Int'l tourism fair begins in capital
body: A three-day international tourism fair began in the capital yesterday. Mahbubul Alam, former adviser to a caretaker government and editor of English daily The Independent, inaugurated the fair styled Monitor-United Airways Dhaka Travel Mart-2013 (DTM 2013) at Pan Pacific Sonargaon Hotel.
