The Bangladesh Monitor, a travel and tourism based magazine, organised the fair sponsored by private airliner United Airways, said a press release. Eastern Bank Ltd is the banking partner of the fair, while Biman Bangladesh Airlines is its airline partner and Bangladesh Tourism Board partner, it said. The fair will remain open from 10:00am to 8:00pm for visitors. The entry fee for each visitor is Tk 20. Participating organisations will offer special discounts in air fares, tour packages and many other attractive offers to the visitors. About 50 organisations including tour operators, hotels, resorts, travel trade bodies from six countries -- Malaysia, Thailand, Singapore, Turkey, Nepal and Bangladesh -- will take part in the fair. A raffle draw on the entry coupons will be held on the concluding day of the fair. Winners can avail various prizes including airline tickets to various destinations and other exciting tour packages. Bangladesh Monitor Editor Kazi Wahidul Alam, Bangladesh Tourism Board CEO Akhteruz Zaman Khan Kabir, United Airways Director (Sales and Marketing) Khawja Jonaid, Eastern Bank Head (Brand and Communication) Ziaul Karim, Biman Bangladesh Airlines General Manager (Marketing and Sales) Abdullah Al Hasan also spoke on the occasion.

title: Today's 18-party's rally rescheduled for tomorrow
body: BNP-led 18-party alliance rescheduled today's protest rally in the capital and all districts and metropolitan headquarters for tomorrow. The rally is scheduled to be held in front of the BNP central office at Naya Paltan in Dhaka at 3:00pm to protest “the killing and oppression by the government law enforcer's and ruling party men in different parts of the country”, BNP Joint Secretary General Rizvi Ahmed said at a press conference yesterday. Sources in BNP said the opposition alliance might announce fresh hartal in this week if the government “creates any obstacle in holding the rallies”. Jamaat insiders said they have a plan to stage a big showdown by ensuring their huge presence in tomorrow's rally in the capital. On March 6, the 18-party alliance in a meeting decided to launch a one-point oust-government movement. A day after, the BNP standing committee in a meeting decided to “go tough” against the government to materialize the alliance's one-point movement.

title: HK visa clampdown on Bangladeshis, Indians, Pakis 'not racist'
body: HONG KONG, Jan 26: Hong Kong's immigration director today denied a visa clampdown on nationals of India, Pakistan and Bangladesh was racist, reports AFP. "The reason why we reviewed the visa-free period in respect of these three nationals is purely on immigration control reasons (SIC)," Ambrose Lee told reporters. He cited "significant immigration problems with South Asian visitors. "Namely people overstaying in Hong Kong, people taking up illegal jobs in Hong Kong, and many visitors from these three countries have abused our hospitality", Lee said. The department said last week the three-month visa-free stay allowed to South Asians had been cut to 14 days because of problems including 'illegal employment and seeking of residence in Hong Kong under false pretenses'. Under the new rules, spouses and other dependents of foreigners resident in Hong Kong are no longer able to sponsor relatives unless they themselves work or have right of abode here. A main reason for the chance was reportedly the problem of South Asian dependents of Hong Kong residents bringing over their relatives. The Indian consulate said last week it had not come across any widespread fluting of the previous visa rules, but would study the changes to see their impact on Hong Kong's large Indian business community. Indian anti-racism campaigner Ravi Gidumal said the Immigration Department needed to explain fully its decision to restrict visa access for South Asians to avert suspicions of discrimination.

title: I will try to root out corruption, terrorism
body: KHULNA, Jan 9: Awami League candidate in the mayor election S M A Rob says he is "hundred per cent confident" about his victory. "By all calculation I am sanguine about winning the upcoming election," he said in an interview with The Daily Star on Wednesday. Rob left Jatiya Party and joined the ruling party in September last year. "I do politics for the commonman and they love me from the core of their heart because they get me in their need. If elected, I will try heart and soul to fulfil my commitments", Rob said. Asked about his election commitments he said, "My first duty will be to remove corruption from the KCC administration to build the city into a modern one at any cost". Rob said he will remove terrorism from the city and not politicise the KCC administration. "I do not underestimate BNP candidate Shaikh Tayebur Rahman. He is a tough candidate and there is no doubt about it. Tayeb Bhai has been discharging the responsibilities of a Mayor for the last few years", he said. "I am on good terms with him. Yet, I must tell you that he could not do any good work only because of the corrupt administration in the city corporation," the AL candidate said. Asked to explain, Rob claimed that Tayebur Rahman miserably failed to eradicate mosquito, rehabilitate the evicted hawkers and present a planned development of the city. Blaming the BNP Mayoral candidate for politicising the city corporation, the AL candidate alleged that the corporation was used for his party politics. Rab said he wants the election to be held in a free and fair manner. "If it is held so, you take it for granted that Tayebur Rahman will suffer a crushing defeat." "Why will people vote for BNP candidate? He bluffed the city dweller by wasting Taka 190 crore through corrupt engineers and dishonest contractors during his long tenure." He alleged that Mayor Tayebur Rahman was solely responsible for playing of about 20,000 unlicensed rickshaws in the metropolitan area. "I have parted with Ershad for his wrong political decisions. Awami League has a glorious background and I want to dedicate rest of my life to serve the people under its banner, showing respect to the Father of the Nation Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibar Rahman, Rob said.

title: Fuel price hike protested
body: Leaders of different political, social and workers' organisations have strongly protested the fuel price hike terming it an anti-people decision of the government. They urged the government to withdraw the decision immediately. The fuel price hike would multiply the sufferings of the people as it would lead to rise in transport fare and price of essentials, they said. The fuel price hike would also have a negative impact on the agriculture output, they observed. At a protest rally in the city yesterday, the leaders of Dhaka City Awami League said the fuel price hike would push the people to a miserable condition. City AL president and former mayor Mohammad Hanif, AL organising secretary Abdul Mannan, Abdus Shahid, Jahangir Kabir Nanak and Miza Azam MP spoke at the rally in front of the Awami League office at Bangabandhu Avenue. It also took out a procession in the city yesterday protesting the government's decision. Chairman of Jatiya Party Anwar Hossain Monju and general secretary Sheikh Shahidul Islam in a joint statement said the government raised the fuel price in an 'undemocratic' way. It increased the fuel price through an executive order without discussing the issue in the Jatiya Sangsad, they added. The government has raised the price bypassing the Jatiya Sangsad, although it always calls for making the parliament effective, the Jatiya Party leaders said. They urged the government to make necessary reforms in the energy sector and check system loss. The Bangladesh Sanjukta Sramik Federation (BSSF) leaders observed that the fuel price hike would multiply the sufferings of the low-income group and create anarchy in the transport sector. In a joint statement, BSSF President Mokhlesur Rahman and general secretary Mokaddem Hossain said the government increased the price without considering the living standard of general people. High price in international market do not justify the fuel price hike as the living standard of general people in Bangladesh do not match with the international standard, they said. Expressing concern over the government decision, Bangladesh Krishak League President Hazi Rashed Mosharraf and general secretary Harun or-Rashid Hawladar said it would bring disaster to the country's agriculture sector. Four left-leaning political parties - Jatiya Gono Front, Biplobi Oikya Front, Gonotantrik Mojdur Party and Gonsonghati Andolon - termed the step anti-people and urged the government to withdraw the decision immediately. They called upon the people to build up resistance against such anti-people steps. The other oranisations which gave statement protesting the decision include The Gontantrik Biplobi Jote, Bangladesh Truck Chalok Sramik Federation, Jatiya Samajtantrik Dal and Bangladesh Samyabadi Dal also protested the fuel price hike.

title: Hartal observed in Pabna, BNP blames ruling AL
body: The daylong shutdown enforced by the district BNP protesting the murder of its Sadar upazila unit leader Ibrahim Ali Mridha passed off peacefully in the district yesterday. The body of Ibrahim, vice-president of the upazila unit and chairman of Goyeshpur Union Parishad under the upazila, was found near Lalon Shah Bridge area in Bheramara upazila of Kushtia at around 8:00am on Sunday. Being informed by locals, police recovered the body and sent it to Kushtia Hospital for autopsy. According to the autopsy report, Ibrahim was strangled. Family sources said Ibrahim was in the capital for a physical check-up for the last two weeks. He went missing from Saturday night. In separate statements on Sunday, BNP central and Pabna district units held the ruling Awami League responsible for his death. The district unit of Bangladesh Jamaat-e-Islami, a key partner in the BNP-led 18-party alliance, gave support to the hartal. Educational institutions and shops and business establishments were closed while vehicles, except a handful of rickshaws, went off the roads during hartal hours in the district yesterday. Additional police and Rapid Action Battalion (Rab) members remained deployed at the strategic points in the town to avert any untoward incidents. The first Janaza for BNP leader Ibrahim was held on the Pabna Town Hall premise on Sunday night. Shamsur Rahman Simul Bishwas, personal assistant to BNP chairperson Khaleda Zia, and district BNP leaders and activists attended the janaza. After second janaza held at Pushpopara BB Pilot High School at about 9:00am yesterday, the slain BNP leader was buried at his family graveyard in Goyeshpur-Monoharpur village in Sadar upazila of the district. Ibrahim's son filed a murder case with Bheramara Police Station in Kushtia on Sunday. No one was arrested in connection with the murder as of filing of this report at 5:00pm yesterday.

title: Sheraton voted Best Business Hotel in Bangladesh
body: AsiaMoney voted Dhaka Sheraton the "Best Business Hotel" in Bangladesh for 1997, says a press release. This award was given on the basis of a survey conducted by Asia Money's 1997 Business Travel Poll, where business travellers visiting Dhaka voted the hotel the Best Business Hotel in Bangladesh. AsiaMoney is a publication of EuroMoney, a leading institution that holds financial and business meetings worldwide.

title: Language Movement heroes' reunion Friday
body: A number of Language Movement veterans of 1952 are set to join a reunion in the capital on Friday under the joint auspices of a weekly and a research group, organisers said yesterday. They said Weekly Somodhara and Bhasha Andolon Gobeshona Kendra jointly organised the reunion of the living Language Movement veterans when 52 of them would be conferred with special honour for their historic role 61 years ago paving the way for the emergence of independent Bangladesh in 1971. The veterans, who will be conferred with the honour, included Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman and his aides like Syed Nazrul Islam and Tajuddin Ahmed.

title: 499 polling centres in Bagerhat vulnerable
body: A total of 499 polling centres, out of 671, in the district have been identified as vulnerable in the upcoming union parishad (UP) election. Of these, 307 are most vulnerable and special security measures will be taken to hold free, fair and peaceful election in these centres, local Election Commission office sources said. The centres are 29 in Sadar, 18 in Kuchua, 31 in Chitolmari, 49 in Fakirhat, 44 in Mollahat, 32 in Rampal, 17 in Mongla, 16 in Shoronkhola and 71 in Morelganj upazilas. Police said they will hold meeting soon to take pre-cautionary measures in the most vulnerable centres. Meanwhile, two chairman candidates and six members have been contesting in the UP election here from jail. They were arrested during different drives of joint forces. Meanwhile, another report from Munshiganj says: A total of three union parishad (UP) chairmen candidates and 44 member candidates have been unofficially elected unopposed in the district in the ensuing union parisad elections. Of them, present chairmen of Bajrojogini and Konkosar UPs Tota Miah and Abu Bakar Dhali have been elected unopposed as their possible rival candidates withdrew their nominations. Another elected chairman was Abul Kalam Dhali of Moddhyapara union. Of the rest unopposed-elected candidates, 16 women have become members for the reserved seats and 28 members for the general member posts. The Election Commission office sources said elections to two union parishads would not be held due to non-completion of their tenure.

title: Deadly mosque attack kills 49 in Damascus
body: Syrian President Bashar al-Assad vowed to "cleanse" his country of extremism yesterday, a day after a suicide bomber killed more than 45 people including a key pro-regime Sunni cleric in a mosque. The attack was also condemned by the opposition, who raised the possibility that the regime was behind the deadly blast at the Iman Mosque in Damascus on Thursday night. State news agency SANA said that 49 people had been killed, including Mohamed Saeed al-Bouti, the most prominent Sunni cleric to back Assad's regime against a Sunni-led uprising. The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights put the death toll at 46, saying that around 15 of the wounded were in critical condition and the toll was likely to rise. The attack came as heavy fighting raged across Syria, and UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon said the United Nations would investigate whether chemical weapons have been used in the conflict. Bouti's death is a blow to Assad's regime, which has been fighting an insurgency that flared when his forces launched a bloody crackdown on Arab Spring-inspired democracy protests that erupted in March 2011. The relentless violence has killed more than 70,000 people, according to UN figures, and caused more than one million to flee their homes as refugees. In a statement issued by the presidency, Assad condemned the attack and mourned Bouti's death, vowing to eradicate "extremism and ignorance" in Syria. "I swear to the Syrian people that your blood, and that of your grandson and all the martyrs of the homeland, will not be spilled in vain because we will be faithful to your ideas by destroying their extremism and ignorance until we have cleansed the country," he said.

title: Chinese ships in disputed waters: Japan
body: Two Chinese government ships were spotted in the territorial waters of disputed islands yesterday, Japan's coastguard said. They were plying waters around the Tokyo-controlled Senkakus, which Beijing calls the Diaoyus and says it owns, shortly after 11:00am, the coastguard said. Three other Chinese surveillance ships were navigating in and out of the contiguous zone outside the 12-nautical-mile territorial waters, it added. Chinese government ships have frequently spent time around the disputed island chain since Tokyo nationalised three of the isles last September.

title: BIRTH OF A NATION
body: 'This country belongs to people of the hills and plains, Muslims, Hindus, Buddhists and Christians' Tarique Rahman returns home after 17 years in exile A psychological reset for BNP, a moment of political recalibration for Bangladesh Zubaida, daughter Zaima reach Gulshan residence হাদি হত্যার ন্যায়বিচার নিশ্চিতে যা যা করা হয়েছে, উপদেষ্টাদের শাহবাগে এসে তার ব্যাখ্যা দেওয়ার দাবি জানিয়েছে ইনকিলাব মঞ্চ।

title: Hasina speaks of Asian energy grid
body: "India, Pakistan and Bangladesh are located at the cross-roads between West and Central Asia on the one hand and East and South East Asia on the other. Our meeting today reflects our shared commitment to join hands in working for a better future for the 1.2 billion people in our three countries. Our three countries share a common history and a common heritage. India and Pakistan are celebrating 50 years of independence. We share your sense of joy and optimism about the future. We too recently celebrated the Silver Jubilee of our independence. Each of our countries values and cherishes our independence and sovereignty. Indians, Pakistanis and Bangalees are nationalists to the core. We take great pride in the many achievements of our respective countries. But we are also hardheaded realists. The world has indeed undergone a dramatic transformation during the past decades. Globalisation and liberalisation today dominate the world economic agenda. We are aware that our three countries today constitute the largest single concentration of poverty in the world. We can overcome our poverty and bring prosperity to our region if we can forge strong economic links among ourselves. We must work together to realise our full potential. Our enormous market, our untapped natural resources and above all, our vast human resources can convert our region into one of the most prosperous in the world. Indeed the forecast for 1998 is that South Asia's growth will be at least six per cent, the highest for any region in the world. We had an excellent SAARC summit in Male this year. Regional cooperation in South Asia has taken firm root. Our achievements in the field of poverty alleviation and reduction of tariffs are quite commendable. But we need to do much more to catch up with the rest of the world, particularly to match the high rates of growth achieved by some of our fellow Asian countries in the recent past. * The identification of "regional best practices" as followed by the European Union (EU) and North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) regional blocs, where the best practices for a particular economic reform by one country is adopted by all others on a reciprocal basis. * We may set up a task force made up of senior officials from the three governments as well as representatives of the private sector, to look into improved road, rail and air links between our countries. * An Asian energy grid could be of enormous benefit to all of our countries. Such a grid system could extend eventually all the way from Turkmenistan to Singapore. * I would urge His Excellency Mr. Gujral to urgently consider Bangladesh's proposal for giving zero tariff access to exports from the four South Asian LDCs into India. At the same time I would request His Excellency Mr. Nawaz Sharif to examine the possibility of extending this facility. In the meantime, I would urge you to at least remove the duty on Bangladesh tea, so that we can re-establish our market in Pakistan. * In order to follow up on our deliberations in this summit, I would like to propose that the Finance and Commerce Ministers of our three countries should meet by the middle of this year. Prior to their meeting, a task force made up of senior officials and representatives of the private sector would put forward some specific recommendations for their consideration, including the possible setting up of some trilateral joint venture industries. Within SAARC itself, we need to increasingly cooperate on specific projects. We need to improve the environment for business and investment. Our infrastructure must match that of the more advanced countries - our ports, railways, telecommunications, civil aviation, roads and highways must be of the highest standard. We must ensure an abundance of electricity at competitive rates. Our bureaucracies must show a high level of efficiency. In this effort to accelerate the rate of growth and create a healthy environment for business and investment our three countries must take the lead. In Mr. Gujral and Mr. Nawaz Sharif, we are fortunate to have two men with a clear vision for their own people and also for South Asia. Mr. Gujral's firm commitment to improving relations with India's neighbours has already shown some very positive results. He, above all, realises that any meaningful regional cooperation must take into account the size of India as well as the political sensitivities of its neighbours. Mr. Nawaz Sharif's resounding electoral victory has given him a golden opportunity to take some bold policy initiatives. His own invaluable experience as a successful entrepreneur has been a major asset for Pakistan. These two visionary men have shown a sense of determination to put India-Pakistan relations on a better footing. We, in Bangladesh, pray that their noble efforts are crowned with success. Peaceful co-existence between India and Pakistan is of great importance in ensuring peace, stability and economic development in South Asia. When I became Prime Minister in June 1996, I realised that to achieve this goal I would have to follow an innovative approach towards accelerating economic development in the country. It was essential to reach development to the villages, focus on human development and improve infrastructure within the country. Moreover, our foreign policy would have to be energised. In particular, it was necessary to strengthen relations with all our neighbours in South Asia and intensify our work to make regional cooperation a reality. We have to create conditions to attract foreign direct investment and intensify the economic interaction among ourselves. This would require forging an effective partnership between government and the private sector. Each of us may be doing this already in our respective countries but it is essential that we, the three largest economies come together to chalk out a plan of action. I am grateful to both Mr. Nawaz Sharif and Mr. Gujral that when I put forward the proposal for a business summit to them last year, they readily accepted my proposal with great enthusiasm. This summit, the first of its kind, must send a clear and powerful signal to the rest of the world: Firstly, that we in South Asia provide excellent investment opportunities for foreign investors. Secondly, that we are collectively committed to create a congenial environment for business. Thirdly, that our governments will work closely with the investors and with each other in putting the required infrastructure in place to facilitate business and investment. Fourthly, that we would encourage our own private sectors to interact more closely with each other, to expand trade and set up joint ventures. Let me now put forward some specific proposals on the form and substance of the cooperation that may take place among us: 1) The summit should set directions for close interaction between the private sectors and government representatives of the three countries. This would enhance mutual understanding of the view points and challenges faced by each country, as the region tries to integrate in a number of different sectors. Such interaction will set the stage for future dialogue between the private and public sectors of the three countries. 2) Specific issues pertaining to private sector initiatives in certain areas and regulatory changes in others could be discussed thereby providing tangible inputs to future negotiations at the inter-governmental level. 3) In the course of economic liberalisation, Bangladesh, India and Pakistan would have enacted substantive and meaningful changes in their foreign investment and import and export trade laws. Cooperation of these initiatives among the three countries could lead to a uniform economic regime supported by a common regulatory framework. This would provide the three countries with many competitive advantages. 4) In order to enhance trade among the three countries, there is the imperative need for harmonisation of customs procedures, improvement of shipping and port facilities and simplification of visa procedures for businessmen and investors. 5) The identification of "regional best practices" as followed by the European Union (EU) and North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) regional blocs, where the best practices for a particular economic reform by one country is adopted by all others on a reciprocal basis. 6) We may set up a task force made up of senior officials from the three governments as well as representatives of the private sector, to look into improved road, rail and air links between our countries. The Asian highway and railway will pass through our three countries linking us on the one side to Central Asia and Europe, and on the other side to China and the ASEAN countries. Improved communications will also be of immense benefit to each of our countries, particularly, for our private sector. 7) The opportunities in the energy sector should be fully realised. An Asian energy grid could be of enormous benefit to all of our countries. Such a grid system could extend eventually all the way from Turkmenistan to Singapore. 8) We must work more closely together to create improved facilities for the training of our manpower. It is especially important that our private sector fully understand the implications of globalisation and the need for each of us to be more and more competitive. 9) I would urge His Excellency Mr. Gujral to urgently consider Bangladesh's proposal for giving zero tariff access to exports from the four South Asian LDCs into India. At the same time I would request His Excellency Mr. Nawaz Sharif to examine the possibility of extending this facility. In the meantime, I would urge you to at least remove the duty on Bangladesh tea, so that we can re-establish our market in Pakistan. 10) In order to follow up on our deliberations in this summit, I would like to propose that the Finance and Commerce Ministers of our three countries should meet by the middle of this year. Prior to their meeting, a task force made up of senior officials and representatives of the private sector would put forward some specific recommendations for their consideration, including the possible setting up of some trilateral joint venture industries. Before I conclude, I would like to stress once again that our summit in Dhaka offers us a unique opportunity to set the tone for a more meaningful cooperation in the fields of business and investment. We, three Prime Ministers, can commit ourselves to do everything possible to encourage our private sectors to play a more dynamic role in bringing new life and meaning to the process of regional cooperation in South Asia. I hope our meeting today will mark the beginning of a new period of mutual trust and confidence among us. Let us be inspired by a vision of a South Asian community, a community where fear and suspicion is replaced by a sense of well-being, a community free of poverty where each of our citizens can lead a life of dignity, free from hunger and illiteracy. (This is an abridged version of the speech the Bangladesh prime minister delivered at the opening ceremony of the three nation Business Summit yesterday)

title: French envoy calls on CCC Mayor
body: CHITTAGONG, Jan 16: French Ambassador to Bangladesh Allen Brown Brewtatit called on Chittagong City Corporation Mayor A B M Mohiuddin Chowdhury here today, reports BSS. During the meeting the mayor apprised the ambassador of various development and service projects of the city corporation including turning Chittagong city into a mega city and building up a 17-kilometre deep sea port from Patenga to Faujdarhat. They also discussed matters of mutual interests. The ambassador commended Mayor Mohiuddin Chowdhury for overall development of Chittagong City.

title: Security for minorities demanded
body: The government should take immediate steps to ban the “evil political forces” that are spreading religious extremism and threatening public security, said some citizen group members yesterday. They demanded exemplary punishment of those responsible for creating anarchy in the country and attacking minority communities. The speakers also demanded security of the minority communities. They made the demands at a press conference organised by Nagorik Protinidhi Dal (citizen representative group) in the capital following their visits to some areas of Satkhira where communal attacks and political violence occurred. Reading a statement, Jagannath University teacher Rajib Mir said along with the government's actions, social resistance, comprising people of all walks of life, must be built to combat communalism and fundamentalism. He alleged that the ruling Awami League had failed to build resistance against the attacks of Jamaat-e-Islami and Jamaat backed Islami Chhatra Shibir in Satkhira and the administration there played a "questionable" role in this matter. Claiming that there are familial relationships between local AL and Jamaat leaders in Satkhira, he said, “Local administration and ruling party leaders must shoulder the responsibility of the incidents that occurred in Satkhira.” Gono Oikkya Member Secretary SM Sabur, and veteran left politician Bimal Biswas also spoke.

title: Jewellery looted in Jessore, robbers held in Magura
body: Police arrested four alleged robbers in Magura yesterday, hours after they looted cash and gold ornaments from a jewellery shop in broad daylight in Jessore district town. During the drive, at least five people, including a policeman, were injured in a bomb attack by the robbers. Being informed, a team of police led by Mohammad Nuruzzaman, sub-inspector at Sadar police station in Magura, went to Bhitasayeer village to arrest the gang fleeing by a microbus. At one stage, the robbers hurled a bomb at the police, leaving the SI injured seriously at around 3:00pm, reports our correspondent. The law enforcers then chased the gang and arrested four of them in Ichhakhada area with the help of the villagers. However, the rest managed to flee, said Mohammad Zahangir Alam, officer in-charge of the PS. Of the arrestees, Khalilur Rahman, 42, of Barguna district, Shahjahan, 35, of Pirojpur and Milon, 33, of Madaripur, could be identified. Injured Nuruzzaman was admitted to Magura Sadar Hospital. The arrestees were also rushed to the hospital as they were injured in a mob beating at the time of arrest, said the OC. The law enforcers also seized the microbus, he said. Earlier, four robbers in a microbus swooped on Bani Jewellers, just 5/7 yards away from Kotwali PS, at Jessore Boro Bazar at around 1:30pm and looted cash and gold ornaments at gunpoint, reports our correspondent. Before fleeing the scene, they exploded three bombs, leaving four people injured. Of the injured, employees Porithosh Pal and Pabitra Adikari of the shop could be identified, said assistant superintendent of police Naimul Haque. However, the loss caused by the robbery could not be known immediately. Protesting the robbery, local traders in the area staged demonstration in front of the PS and vandalised five vehicles.

title: Islam fastest growing faith in US: Clinton
body: WASHINGTON, Jan 11: President Bill Clinton has said that Washington's policy of fighting terrorism is directed at actions of individuals and groups indulging in violence and not Islam, the fastest growing religion in the United States, reports PTI. "Our policies are guided by our profound respect for Islam. The Muslim religion is the fastest-growing faith in the United States (the number of Muslims in the US is put at 5 to 6 million)," Clinton said in a report to the US Congress on Sunday. "We recognise and honour Islam's role as a source of inspiration, instruction and moral guidance for hundreds of millions of people around the world. US policy in the (Mid East-South Asia) region is directed at the actions of governments and terrorist groups, not peoples or faiths." This year, not only the president but also the vice president issued an Eid Day message, in what analysts said was an indication of the importance the administration attaches to the growing popularity of Islam.

title: 'Missing' man found dead after 9 days
body: Police recovered the decomposed body of a man from Halsa Beel (water body) in Jhikargachha upazila of the district on Sunday evening, after nine days of his 'abduction'. The deceased was identified as Altaf Hossain Gazi, 43, son of late Afsar Ali Gazi of Bagdanga village of the upazila. Police, quoting the victim's family, said Altaf went out of the house to go to neighbouring Narangali village on February 23. Since then he remained 'missing' as some criminals kidnapped him from Narangali Babu Bazar on the same evening. Officer in-charge of Jhikargachha police station Humayan Kabir said, some farmers saw the body of Altaf in a wheat field at Halsa Beel. On information, the victim's family identified the body of Altaf and informed the police.

title: Man 'commits suicide' in Ctg
body: A man allegedly committed suicide by consuming poison in Chandgaon area of Chittagong city on Saturday night. Md Rafiq, 35, resided in the area. Deceased's father Shah Alam said Rafiq went out on Saturday night following an altercation between them. Later, locals found him in an unconscious state near their house. He was rushed to Chittagong Medical College Hospital where doctors declared that Rafiq died from poisoning. Chandgaon police said Rafiq committed suicide. An unnatural death case was filed with Chandgaon Police Station.

title: No liquidity crisis in banks
body: The banks in the country do not have any liquidity crisis, the Bangladesh Bank said yesterday, reports BSS. Refuting recent press reports, the central bank, in a press release yesterday, said "in fact, there is no liquidity crisis in the banks at the moment." It described as untrue the reports carried by a section of newspapers that the rise in interest rate in call money market is due to increased overdrawing by the government. The Bangladesh Bank attributed the rise in the interest rate to heavy withdrawal by the customers on the occasion of Eid. The hike in interest rate is a temporary phenomenon and it is not the sign of overall liquidity crisis in the banks, the press release added.

title: New committee of Ctg city BNP announced
body: A new executive committee of Chittagong city unit of BNP has been formed with Meer Nasiruddin and Dastogeer Choudhury as its president and general secretary respectively. The 158-member body was announced yesterday following a series of negotiations between the two conflicting groups of the city unit in the last couple of days, said a party press release late last night. Other members of the committee are Syed Wahidul Alam, MP - senior vice-president; Prof Arif Moinuddin, Md Salimullah, Ekramul Karim, Begum Rozy Kabir, A M Najimuddin, Shamsul Alam, Kazi Kamaluddin Choudhury and Saleh Ahmad Sowdagar - vice-presidents; F H Khan - organising secretary; M A Sabur, Ershadullah, Abdus Sattar, Shahadat Hossain Selim, Abu Sufian, Abdul Wahab Quashemi and M Najimuddin - joint secretaries; and AKM Khorshed Alam and Md Idris - assistant organising secretaries. The executive committee members are Abdullah Al Noman, M Morshed Khan, MP, Amir Khashru Mahmud Choudhury, MP, M Zahiruddin Khan, Dr AFM Yusuf, Sirajul Islam Choudhury and Shahjada Enayet Ullah Khan. The committee has been empowered to co-opt 11 more members.

title: First birds had 4 wings
body: Anchiornis huxley, a small, feathered, dinosaur, showing a second set of wings on its legs. Photo: Dailymail Researchers have uncovered new evidence that the first birds had four wings instead of two. A team from China say they flew rather like a biplane -- with wings on their legs providing a second boost. The team analysed 11 bird skeletons from between 150 and 100 million years ago, and believe they eventually shed the second set so they could use their legs more effectively. Led by Xiaoting Zheng of China's Linyi University, the authors of the new study analysed the bird skeletons donated by various collectors to the Shandong Tianyu Museum of Nature. The 11 birds come from five species and were relatively robust: larger than a crow but smaller than a turkey. Recently, several fossils have shown that some dinosaurs had large feathers on both fore limbs and hind limbs. But, until now, no examples of this four-winged body plan have been described in birds -- or even in their most recently extinct relatives. Zheng and colleagues studied fossils in China's Shandong Tianyu Museum of Nature and identified 11 primitive bird species with clear signs of feathered hind legs. Modern birds have two types of feathers: vaned feathers that cover the outside of the body, and the down feathers that grow underneath them. The Chinese team found that one type of vaned plumage, also known as pennaceous feathers, was neatly preserved in skeletal fossils of these specimens, along each creatures' hind limbs. These findings suggest that this four-winged condition preceded the two-winged body plan, and that birds have gradually lost the feathers on their hind limbs over evolutionary time. In a related news article also published in Science, Michael Balter compares the ancient birds to biplanes in the early 1900s, which were later phased out in favour of faster monoplanes. The study adds to existing theories that suggest the first birds flew with four wings.

title: More Positive Assurance Needed
body: With the setting up of government of BJP-led alliance at the centre in India its minority communities are apprehending their uncertain political and economic future because of inclusion of certain fundamentalist Hindu leaders such as L K Advani, M M Joshi and Arun Jaitley. The role of Advani in the destruction of Babri Mosque has already been revealed. The real motive behind Joshi's Hindutva cultural project "Bharatya culture" has been reflected in the district education programme "Sarva Shiksha Abhijan" that this programme aims at imposing Hindu culture throughout India. Arun Jaitley's wish has been gradually revealed in various mass media programmes. Apart from this, BJP extremists are trying to disturb the communal harmony in West Bengal, Bihar, Gujrat, Orissa and Uttar Pradesh. However, we wish that these Hindu fundamentalists cannot be effective in future because after the demolition of Babri Mosque BJP had to forsake its agenda to come to power and the present government is a coalition government which has to accommodate the wishes of the BJP allies. Though apparently Pakistan was created on a two-nation theory, it may not be too difficult to prove that Pakistan became a reality mainly because of (i) failure of Mohammad Ali Jinnah to fulfil his dream as a Congress leader; (ii) Jawaharlal Nehru's inadequate political foresight; and (iii) British government's wish to divide and rule to maintain economic control on the sub-continent (as long as possible). It was mainly exploitation of religious sentiment of the common people, majority of whom were poor and illiterate and as such incapable of understanding political strategies and intricacies. Ever since the creation of Pakistan its senior politicians and bureaucrats were apprehensive of pressure from the people of its eastern part for a fair share in employment and economic activities with the rise of literacy. Mohammad Ali Jinnah, who used to consider the eastern wing as an 'outpost' of Pakistan, advised them to make the western wing self-sufficient as quickly as possible so that west Pakistanis needed not to depend for anything on the eastern wing. As such all policies (at least the major ones) were formulated mainly for the benefit of west Pakistanis only. Subsequent developments, particularly during the so-called 'golden era' of Ayub Khan prove the point. The foundation of Pakistan was based more on sentiment and less on cool logic. A modern state can never flourish on the basis of religion alone. Other than religion east Pakistanis had nothing common with the west Pakistanis. Some twenty-five years back Clarence Maloney in his book Peoples of South Asia (Holt, Rinehart and Winston, Inc New York, 1974) rightly observed:' the disunity within Pakistan was apparent from the start. Religion proved inadequate to hold different peoples together in amity. The west Pakistani tended to look down on Bengali Muslims as second class Muslims, descendants of converts and do not in the same direct line of religious family as those who brought Islam to the country. The Punjabi Muslims see themselves as direct heirs to the ruling tradition of the Mughal territory. Thus there was deep seated cultural prejudice current at the birth of Pakistan." Bangladesh achieved its independence through a nine-month long liberation war in which more or less all the religious minorities contributed because they hoped that independent Bangladesh would be a secular democratic state where all its people would be free to lead a peaceful life with complete religious freedom and where all will be equal before law. After independence, however, things did not proceed as anticipated. Though the then AL government could adopt secularism as one of the state principles it did not get enough time to nullify the anti-Hindu Acts (such as Enemy Property Act) imposed by the then Pakistan. Far from redressing the problems of the Hindus Zia knocked out the principle of secularism. Both Zia and Ershad were interested in the Islamisation of the constitution and ignored the problems of the minorities. In fact Zia's ill-advised policy in regard to CHT increased the suffering of the tribals there. As CHT was a political problem it was beyond the capability of a military ruler like Ershad to solve it. Geographically Bangladesh is surrounded on three sides by India and Myanmar. India is a Hindu-majority country and Myanmar is Buddhist dominated. It may further be added that eastern part of India (bordering Bangladesh) is dominated by Buddhist Christians and tribals. It would, therefore, be most pragmatic for Bangladesh not only to tolerate these cultures but also to encourage development of their cultures so that political relations of Bangladesh with its neighbours are developed on a warmer and firmer footing. This will help her much to quicken the pace of development of trade and economic relations. It is indeed surprising that despite long experience of ruling the country for twenty years (11yrs by BNP and 9 yrs by JP) both BNP and JP are trying to raise the issue of religion in the name of so called "nationalist parties". For them it may be useful to raise the religious sentiment of the illiterate and simple voters through publicising that Awami League is a pro-Indian and secular party and as such not enough committed to protect Islam, the religion of the majority people of Bangladesh, but it would certainly be harmful for the country in the long run. Some may argue that while communal riots frequently occur in India (which is a secular state) why Bangladesh should try to be secular in letter and spirit. There may be good reasons as to why Bangladesh should not follow India in her policy toward the minorities. The following reasons may be identified: i) the constitution of Bangladesh is not based on two-nation theory; ii) the exodus of Hindus from Pakistan was because of anti-Hindu polices adopted by the then Pakistan governments; iii) it would be improper for Bangladesh to ignore the moral and material support she received from Hindu dominated India, Buddhist dominated Myanmar and Japan and Christian democracies of UK, France and Australia and communist countries like Russia and the then East Germany; iv) it would be in the interest of Bangladesh to develop better relations with the peoples of the neighbouring states; and v) it cannot be denied that except from the Mughal ruler Akbar Hindus did not receive proper treatment from the Muslim rulers. It may not be easy to establish absolutely amicable relationship among all the communities in South Asia because of the following constraints: (a) Kashmir conflict between India and Pakistan; (b) Tamil uprising in Sri Lanka; (c) BJP-led DNA rule in India; and (d) Islamic fundamentalist dominated military rule in Pakistan. As Bangladesh appears to be free from any such constraints as quoted above it may be appropriate for her to initiate a proposal before coming SAARC summit for adopting resolutions aiming at eliminating any existing discriminatory policy (if there be any) and not to adopt any policy discriminating the minorities in future to improve communal relationship in the region. Though we may not get immediate result from such resolutions adoption of such resolutions would increase the confidence of the minorities and will make the SAARC more meaningful and powerful. The writer is a retired Joint Secretary.

title: Grab and slip
body: There is a human propensity for things coveted. The wise advice "power lies in not using it", is ignored, to pay covert allowances (baksheesh) generously for miscellaneous services rendered quietly, efficiently, and unofficially (the more informal the safer it is). When the rulers do not ride the rules, the regulations derail and rot and only deserve floating reference. Statutes (and lips) lie sealed inside the small print in the books of law. But today's shady (or scintillating) entrepreneurs bask in the publicity of the dining hall; away from the murky processing in the kitchen, and the proceedings in the pantry. The proof of the pudding lies not in the eating, but in ignoring the make-believe. A show is a show, and there is a time for dropping the curtain. All the world is not a stage - if the appropriation come stage by stage. The auditors are well treated here, provided they return the compliment. The inspectors are rather stiff-necked, and look straight ahead, because gentlemen do not poke their noses everywhere. Let them have some peace, is the official posture; and let the peaceful in the society lose their peace of mind for a while, for the sake of the country. The internal revolution continues; the RPM depending on the lubrication. Public duty may not be publicly visible, in the same way the fixation of responsibility in the civil service is invisible. Civil servants work quietly and anonymously in the background, betoken as a gesture of humility. But these days silence has its price in this noisy world; and the gas contracts are designed to leak through the back door. The society condones the concept of being economical with the truth; and the loud mouths get it out of the system through the gift of the gab. It is not a spectator sport, but the gladiators do go round in the arena, and the spectators have learnt to take it stoically. The inner space is pregnant with possibilities, but the live births are not celebrated in countries with the bottomless baskets. Professionalism, an old science, is a new art in the developing world, hence passing through the teething stage. A tight and rigid stance is not possible in the Third World - there are two more worlds to go up. A doctor is supposed to doctor the medicine; or is it otherwise? In the under-developed countries, the scanty resources for survival have to be engineered with an ingenuity which is supposed to be encouraging the spirit of entrepreneurship. The auditors have to be rather philosophical at times. Frequently the spirit evaporates, and one is left high and dry. Efficiency comes in two models, dry and wet. The of the class, drenched in sweat, feed the dry, living higher up the mountain of labour. The leaders must be left undisturbed to think and plan. Defaulters also come in two models; one is the familiar bank-loan defaulter, and the other are those who default with the progress of the nation. The cerebral defaulters are entrusted to groom the country. The trust, however, is misplaced, and it causes instability on many fronts. Many rising nations are passing through this stage, and Bangladesh is no exception, except to note that the moral environment is deteriorating due to green envy. Grab, and slip away, with malice for none, and goodwill for all. This phase of the national itch is now in focus in the public fora. The battle for survival (for good and evil) is on. It is a classical battle of human choice. The average output can be predicted; provided the reserve price can be announced before the auction.

title: Road connecting Bangabandhu Bridge to be widened
body: Communications Minister Anwar Hossain Manju yesterday told the Jatiya Sangsad that feeder road connecting Bangabandhu Bridge would be widened and improved as a part of national highway project, reports BSS. Making a statement on a call attention notice by Mohammad Wajiuddin Khan (Pabna-3), the minister said that as part of the project financed by the World Bank, a road link between Pabna and the bridge via Tebunia, Atgharia, Handia and Hatikamrul would be completed by year 2002. He said work of the proposed road would start in December this year. The minister also observed that opening of Bangabandhu Bridge is considered as a milestone in national economic pursuit. He said all future road networks have been designed to connect the bridge.

title: WB earns flak for AJM closure
body: Speakers at a dialogue yesterday came down heavily on the World Bank saying Adamjee Jute Mills was closed in line with a prescription of the bank. They said the Bank had earlier suggested halving annual production, which resulted in pushing up production cost. "It was the World Bank that recommended to reduce the production to 50,000 tons annually from 99,000 tons which pushed the cost of Adamjee up," said Shahidullah Chowdhury, a trade union leader. The dialogue on 'Closure of the Adamjee Jute Mills and Future of Industrialisation in Bangladesh' was organised by the Centre for Studies in Social Transformation (CSST) at the Planning Academy in the city. Professor Sirajul Islam Chowdhury, president of CSST, chaired the session while Professor Abul Barkat of the Department of Economics of Dhaka University presented the keynote paper. Speaking at the dialogue, Professor Muzaffor Ahmed of the Institute of Business Administration noted wage issue did not link to the productivity for which industries in Bangladesh faced different problems. "Bangladesh could not take the benefit of product diversification in the jute sector but some other countries are expanding their market by doing so," Prof Ahmed told the dialogue. Dr Kazi Kholiquzzaman Ahmad, president of Bangladesh Economic Association, said Adamjee was not only a company but also a strong pillar of jute industries. "It is not a very good sign for a country that even cabinet ministers are not informed about many serious issues," he added. In his key-note presentation, Prof Barkat said World Bank's prescriptions are to down size the production capacity of jute mills and privatise and subsequently close down those units. "It is very mysterious that World Bank is providing assistance to India for expanding its jute sector while it is providing a sunshine package for the jute sector in Bangladesh." M Ali Behrouze Ispahani, vice-chairman of Ispahani Group and immediate past president of Jute Mills Association, said three expert committees were constituted in three regimes to salvage the Adamjee Jute Mills (AJM). The first committee in 1978 by late president Zia, second in 1988 by former president Ershad and third one in 1998 by former prime minister Sheikh Hasina but none of these committees suggested the closure of the AJM. Rather, these committees suggested re-organisation and modernisation of AJM, he said. Two sections of the AJM were highly profitable but all BJMC mills were incurring huge losses due to mismanagement and rampant corruption, Ispahani added. "We should run the mills in a business-like manner and not as a political unit. It is a great shame that the mills in India and Pakistan are making huge profits whilst mills in Bangladesh are being closed down one by one," he mentioned. K R Hasan, former executive director of Adamjee, mentioned several examples of corruption in Adamjee and said a chief whip of the parliament asked him to manage Tk two lakh. Besides, the attitude of the national leaders in case of Adamjee was not in favour of Adamjee and it was one of the other reasons for closure of the largest jute mills, he said.

title: Admin cadres form body to press demands
body: About 200 members of the BCS administrative cadre yesterday formed an action committee to press their seven-point demand including immediate implementation of upgradation of 321 posts in their cadre. The 31-member committee headed by Dr Mujibur Rahman, a deputy secretary in the finance ministry, was formed at a meeting at the conference room of the finance ministry. Earlier, they gathered in front of the Finance Secretary's office protesting a ministry decision on Thursday to put on hold a December 21 order, upgrading 321 posts, action committee sources said. They will hold a demonstration today at 9:30 am at the Finance Ministry, they said. Finance Secretary Dr Akbar Ali Khan told The Daily Star last night that they came to meet him and waited at the conference room of the ministry. But he could not give them time because of the Cabinet meeting. "I would see them tomorrow to hear their views," he said. The meeting yesterday was addressed by, among others, Khan Mohammad Blayet Hossain, Harunur Rashid, Sajjad Hossain, Badiur Rahman, Sirajul Islam, Abu Alam Shahid Khan, Mizanur Rahman, Abul Kalam Azad, Mosharraf Hossain, Tauhidur Rahman, Ajit Kumar Pal and Ansar Ali. They spoke about the problems facing the administrative cadre and expressed deep resentment over non-implementation of the upgradation of cadres, "approved by the Prime Minister." Such delay would hamper administrative and development activities, they asserted. The speakers further resented that vacant posts of additional secretary, joint-secretary and deputy secretary were not filled up despite ''specific directives by the Prime Minister." The seven-point demand is: (1) Promotion of competent officials to the vacant posts of additional secretary, joint-secretary and deputy secretary, (2) Inclusion of 50 per cent posts of cadre service in selection grade along with an order to upgrade posts of deputy secretary to the pay scale of Tk 7,100 (3) Creation of opportunities for promotion in administrative cadres as in the BCS foreign service, taxation, excise, revenue and police cadres, (4) Immediate implementation of upgradation of the 321 administration cadre posts 'approved by PM', (5) End to contract appointments and attempts to raise the retirement age, (6) Implementation of at least 12 per cent promotions in all cadres including the administrative cadre in the light of recommendations by the Matin committee, (7) Repeal of a 1992 order cancelling 25 per cent intake quota for administrative cadre in foreign service.

title: SUST teachers stage sit-in for study leave
body: Two teachers of Shahjalal University of Science & Technology (SUST) staged a sit-in for the second day yesterday to press for approval of their study leave they had applied for earlier. Assistant Professor of Anthropology Kazi Afzal Ahmed and Assistant Professor of Industrial and Production Engineering Md. Mostafizur Rahman alleged that despite approval by the 'Study Leave Committee', university authorities only granted them leave without salary, adding that they had been victims of the VC's grudge. The two teachers staged the sit-in from 10:00am to 5:00pm in front of the Registrar's Building. About 60 teachers of the university expressed solidarity with them and signed a petition in this regard. On the other hand, university authorities claimed that the appointments of the two teachers were yet to be included under the revenue budget and as such there were no legal provisions to let them go on a study leave with salary. However, they were granted study leave without pay on humanitarian grounds, the authorities added.

title: 'Boro' cultivation faces setback in Mymensingh
body: MYMENSINGH, Jan 4: Nabanna, the traditional festival of rural Bangladesh is not being celebrated during this season in the flood-hit shoal areas here. Last year's flood has swept over the low lying and shoal areas of the district. For this reason farmers of Sadar, Phulpur, Gafargaon and Dhubaura failed to avail of the chance to transplant 'Aman' seedlings in right-time. So the farmers have got a poor production of 'Aman' paddy which below their production cost. Even many farmers were not able to cultivate 'Aman' paddy as their seed-beds were damaged for washed away by the deluge. Lehaz Uddin, a farmer of shoal areas of sadar thana told this correspondent that he has harvested only seven mounds of paddy from 15 kathas of land where he harvested 21 mounds of 'Aman' paddy last year. He also informed that he would not be able to continue 'Boro' cultivation due to lack of sufficient capital. So the farmers here are not celebrating Nabanna, the traditional festival of rural Bangladesh in this season. Meanwhile, the small, marginal and landless share-croppers are passing their days in great hardship as there is no sign of fall in price of rice with the harvesting of new 'Aman' crops. Every year poor people buy rice between Taka 10 to Taka 13 per kg with the arrival of new 'Aman' crops. But the high price of rice in this season has created immense sufferings to them. If the flood-hit farmers do not set sufficient agricultural loan, they will not be able to cultivate 'Boro' paddy, many farmers of village Ramvadra Pur in Phulpur thana informed.

title: Cargo flights from Ctg begins January 18
body: Preparations are afoot to introduce cargo flights from the port city to different destinations particularly those in the East Asian cites for boosting trade and businesses. Goods in export-import category are the prime targets for such cargo flights, business circle said. State Minister for Civil Aviation and Tourism Mir Mohammad Nasir Uddin told BSS Monday that the cargo flight from the Shah Amanat International Airport (SAIA) will be formally inaugurated on January 18. Before the inauguration, a high powered meeting of senior officials and business community leaders will be held in the port to devise ways and means for smoother operation of the cargo flights and overcoming possible obstacles. Meanwhile, a 7-member Thai Cargo agents delegation based in Chiangmai arrived the port on Sunday on a four-day visit to have an on the spot assessment of the arrangement including infrastructures, security and other logistics as well as business prospects before dispatching of cargoes by air is initiated. Arthorm Dhamabutra, Manager (Cargo Mails & Sales) of the Thai Airways, is leading the delegation that comprised leading cargo operators and Thai Airways officials. The delegation has already visited the SAIA to see for themselves the infrastructure facilities for the cargo handling and held formal talks with the officials of Chittagong Customs House. They are scheduled to meet the leaders of trade circle to gather information about prospects and obstacles in this regard, delegation sources said. They also visited different export oriented factories particularly those in the garments and seafood sectors located in the city and in the Chittagong Export Processing Zone (CEPZ). Mohammad Ataullah, Manager (Cargo) of Thai Airways Bangladesh, who is accompanying the delegation, told BSS that the delegation has shown their keen interest in promoting business between Chiangmai and Chittagong through air cargo operation. He pointed out that the existing cargo terminal at SAIA is too small and there is hardly any noticeable security arrangement for the incoming or outgoing cargoes. "It should have been done much earlier as there are huge possibilities of business," Ataullah said. The state of the art SAIA was built with the Japanese assistance, having a cargo terminal building of only 2700 sq meter area and a 312 sq meter cargo agents building, has no cargo warehouse, which is a must for keeping export-import cargoes safely for the time takes before and after delivery and documentation, airport sources said. Manager of SAIA Mohammad Khurshed Alam Sarker said preparations are on to make a good start for the cargo flight from here but what was needed is necessary skilled manpower, requisite equipment and policy guideline as the Civil Aviation Authority may be assigned to operate the cargo terminal instead of Bangladesh Biman which at present is handling the cargo village at ZIA. Official sources said Customs officials are already posted there and a counter of Sonali Bank also set up at the cargo terminal building for assessment of duties and help documentation of cargoes. The port city's business circle see huge prospect of increasing trade and business particularly in the export-import sector between Bangladesh and some East Asian and Middle Eastern countries through introduction of cargo flight at SAIA against the backdrop of inauguration of flight operations by four separate aviation companies -- Bangladesh Biman, Silk Air, Fuket and Thai Airways to different destinations of those countries. Chittagong Chamber of Commerce and Industry President Amir Humayun Mahmud Chowdhury said besides reduction of carrying costs, it would tremendously help boosting trade with some neighbouring countries. Bangladesh Clearing and Forwarding Agents Association President M Salimullah said that it would help prompt export-import of garments products, raw materials and accessories, emergency medicine and also help find new markets in exporting perishable goods and sea foods of greater Chittagong region.
